articleData.chapterTitle_bc: What is Pokémon Scarlet & Violet?

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet are the latest Pokémon adventures for the Nintendo Switch, releasing on 18th November 2022. They are the first Generation 9 Pokémon games; the previous generation began with Pokémon Sword & Shield. The games are set in the Paldea region.

chapterContent.head: How are Pokémon Scarlet & Violet different?

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet are the next mainline Pokémon games, building upon the foundation set by Pokémon Red & Blue way back and continued by all the generations up to Pokémon Sword & Shield.

Scarlet & Violet feature all the key aspects you’d associate with the main Pokémon series: A vast world to explore, hundreds of Pokémon to battle with and catch (some old, some new) and dozens of characters to meet (whether they be friend or foe).

Like previous mainline games, Scarlet & Violet come in two separate versions: Scarlet version and Violet version. The differences between the two are very minor: certain Pokémon creatures only appear in one version and not the other. However, you can trade with somebody with a different version to catch them all.

chapterContent.head: An Open World Adventure

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Sword & Shield were the first Pokémon games to feature an open world-like area: The Wild Area. Later, Pokémon Legends Arceus featured multiple open world-like zones. With Scarlet & Violet, the entire game world of Paldea will be open world!
This means you can go anywhere you want, at any time. According to Nintendo, “you’re free to explore at your leisure and not in an order dictated by the story.”
On top of this, you can play multiplayer with up to four players, exploring the region of Paldea together!

chapterContent.head: Three Different Story Paths

chapterContent.content: New to Scarlet & Violet, there are three story paths that you can follow concurrently.
Victory Road is the traditional Pokémon storyline, where you travel Paldea in search of the eight gyms, with the aim of becoming the Champion.
Path of Legends is a quest where you search for Herba Mystica, rare herbs guarded by powerful Titan Pokémon.
Starfall Street pits you against the trouble-making Team Star, formed from rebellious students. There are multiple squads with their own base.

chapterContent.head: Travel with your Pokémon

chapterContent.content: An often requested feature: when exploring Paldea, you can have one Pokémon follow alongside you!
You can also order this Pokémon using the “Let’s Go!” feature, so they explore in the direction you indicate. The Pokémon may pick up useful items and auto-battle wild Pokémon.

Auto-Battles are a new way of battling. When using the “Let’s Go!” feature, your Pokémon will automatically engage wild Pokémon and fight without requiring any input from yourself. You can watch over the auto-battling Pokémon or go elsewhere and do something else.

When your Pokémon wins during Auto-Battle, they can earn experience points and items. However, it doesn’t sound like you can catch wild Pokémon this way, so be careful there aren’t any shiny Pokémon around!

chapterContent.head: The TM Machine

chapterContent.content: Every Pokémon Center has a useful contraption called the TM Machine. This lets you create your own TMs (Technical Machines) using League Points (LP) that you’ve earned plus materials dropped by wild Pokémon. LP can be earned by progressing the story and exchanging materials from Pokémon.

The types of TMs available to create will gradually increase as you continue your adventure. Each TM teaches a specific move to certain Pokémon. For example, TM85 Rest can teach Rest (user regains health, then falls asleep) to certain Pokémon. TMs can only be used once, but you can create multiple of each.

chapterContent.head: Picnic Time!

chapterContent.content: As you travel around Paldea and you feel like things are getting a tad too serious, perhaps it’s time to lie back and enjoy some quality time with your Pokémon!

Similar to the camping feature in Sword & Shield, you can set up a picnic area almost anywhere in the Paldea region. Your traveling Pokémon will all appear at once, in anticipation of the tasty picnic food you can make.

Sandwiches are the bread and butter of any good picnic and it seems Pokémon love them too. You can fill your sandwiches with all sorts of yummy ingredients, then carefully stack them with your bread to (hopefully) create a culinary masterpiece. Feeding sandwiches to your Pokémon can restore their HP and grant useful effects.

Besides this, you can interact with your Pokémon during picnics, chatting to them to make them perk up or cleaning them when they get dirty from traveling for so long. You can even invite other players via local or internet communication.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: New Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: With each new generation of Pokémon, there are lots and lots of new Pokémon creatures added to the mix–and it’s no different for Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
This page lists all the known Pokémon newly added to Scarlet & Violet that were showcased in pre-release media.

chapterContent.head: Starter Pokémon in Scarlet and Violet

chapterContent.content: Sprigatito the Grass Cat Pokémon is one of the three starter Pokémon that you can choose at the start of the game. It is a Grass-type with the classic Overgrow ability, boosting its Grass-type attacks when its HP falls below a third.

Fuecoco the Fire Croc Pokémon is one of the three starter Pokémon that you can choose at the start of the game. It’s a Fire-type with the Blaze ability, common for Fire-type starters, which boosts its Fire-type attacks in a pinch.

Quaxly the Duckling Pokémon completes the trinity of the three starters available at the start of the game. It’s a Water-type with the Torrent ability, enhancing its Water-type attacks when it has low HP.

chapterContent.head: Legendary Ride Pokémon

chapterContent.content: Koraidon is a Legendary Pokémon that appears in Pokémon Scarlet, featuring on the game’s cover art. You will receive a Koraidon to accompany you during your travels.
Koraidon has multiple forms to suit different traversal needs: Sprinting Build for moving fast on land, Swimming Build for going across water and Gliding Build for gliding through the air.
Miraidon is a Legendary Pokémon that appears in Pokémon Violet, featuring on the game’s cover art. You will receive a Miraidon to accompany you during your travels.
Miraidon has multiple forms to suit different traversal needs: Drive Mode for moving fast on land, Aquatic Mode for going across water and Glide Mode for gliding through the air.

chapterContent.head: New Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: Armarouge the Fire Warrior Pokémon is exclusive to Pokémon Scarlet. It’s a Fire and Psychic type with the Flash Fire ability, which boosts its Fire type attacks when hit by one. It has a new move called Armor Cannon that deals heavy Fire-type Special damage, but lowers Armarouge’s Def and Sp. Def stats.

Bellibolt the EleFrog Pokémon is a new Electric-type found in Paldea. It has a new ability called Electromorphosis, which causes it to be charged when hit by an attack, boosting the next Electric-type attack it uses.

Ceruledge the Fire Blades Pokémon is exclusive to Pokémon Violet. It’s a Fire and Ghost type with the Flash Fire ability, which boosts its Fire type attacks when hit by one. It has a new move called Bitter Blades, a Fire-type physical attack that restores Ceruledge’s HP by half the damage dealt to the foe.
Cetitan the Terra Whale Pokémon is a new Ice-type found in Paldea. It can have the Thick Fat (weakens the foe’s Fire and Ice-type attacks) or Slush Rush (boosts Speed during a hailstorm) abilities.

Cyclizar the Mount Pokémon is a new Dragon and Normal type. It has the Shed Skin ability, which may cure its own status conditions at the end of the turn. It has a new move called Shed Tail, which creatures a substitute with its own HP, before switching places with another Pokémon.

Farigiraf the Long Neck Pokémon is a Normal and Psychic type and the evolved form of Girafarig. It has two new abilities. Cud Chew lets Farigiraf eat a berry a second time at the end of the turn, if it ate a berry. Armor Tail prevents opponents from using priority moves (eg. Quick Attack).
Fidough the Puppy Pokémon is a new Fairy-type found in Paldea. It has the Own Tempo ability, which prevents it from being confused or intimidated.

Gimmighoul the Coin Chest Pokémon is a new Ghost-type discovered in Paldea. It has the Rattled ability, which boosts its Speed stat when intimidated or struck by a Bug, Dark or Ghost attack. Besides its Chest Form, which resembles a treasure chest, Gimmighoul has a Roaming Form where it carries a single coin on its back.

chapterContent.aside: At the time of writing, Gimmighoul’s Roaming Form has started appearing in Pokémon GO. However, it cannot be captured.

chapterContent.content: Grafaiai the Toxic Monkey Pokémon is a new Poison and Normal type found in Paldea. It can have the Unburden (doubles its Speed after its held item is used up) or Poison Touch (may inflict poison on foe when using a move that makes contact) abilities.

Greavard the Ghost Dog Pokémon is a new Ghost-type found in Paldea. It has the Pickup ability, which lets it obtain any held item consumed by other Pokémon in battle (temporarily if the other Pokémon belongs to a trainer). Also, there’s a chance it may obtain random items after a fight.

Klawf the Ambush Pokémon is a new Rock-type found in Paldea. It has a new Ability called Anger Shell that boosts its Attack, Sp. Atk and Speed stats, but lowers its defensive stats after falling below half HP.

Lechonk the Hog Pokémon is a new Normal-type found in Paldea. It can have the Aroma Veil (prevents attacks that restrict its move choices) or Gluttony (eats a berry at half HP instead of quarter HP) abilities.

Paldean Wooper is a new form of Wooper that’s Poison and Ground type. It can have the Poison Point (may inflict poison on foe if they use a move that makes contact) or Water Absorb (restores HP when hit by a Water-type attack) abilities.

Pawmi the Mouse Pokémon is a new Electric-type native to Paldea. It can have the Static (may inflict paralysis on foe if they use a move that makes contact) or Natural Cure (heals status conditions when switched out) abilities.
Smoliv the Olive Pokémon is a new Grass and Normal type found in Paldea. It has the Early Bird ability, which lets it wake up faster when asleep.

Wiglett the Garden Eel Pokémon is a new Water-type found in Paldea. It resembles Diglett, a Ground-type, but is a completely separate Pokémon. It can have the Gooey (lowers foe’s Speed if they use a move that makes contact) or Rattled (boosts Speed when hit by Bug, Dark or Ghost-type attack) abilities.

chapterContent.head: Unidentified Pokémon

chapterContent.content: Great Tusk is the prehistoric version of Donphan, only available in Pokemon Scarlet. It is one of the Titans on the legend’s paths and is a Ground/Fighting type Pokemon. It is only available in Pokemon Scarlet, and it can only be obtained after you reach the post-game and you go to Area 0.

Iron Treads is the futuristic version of Donphan, only available in Pokemon Violet. It is a Ground/Steel-type Pokemon that is part of the Path of Legends. To add this Pokemon to your team, you will need to beat the game and arrive at Area 0.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Pokémon Scarlet Exclusives Confirmed

chapterContent.content: This page details all the exclusive Pokémon that you’ll only find in Pokémon Scarlet. It includes new Pokémon and older generation Pokémon that can only be found in the Scarlet version of the game.

chapterContent.aside: We will update it with all the latest information on exclusive Pokémon as it comes out!

chapterContent.content: Head over to our page on All Pokémon Violet Exclusives for information on Pokémon Violet.

chapterContent.head: New and Returning for Pokémon Scarlet

chapterContent.content: Larvitar is a Generation II Rock/Ground-type Pokémon and has two evolution stages: Pupitar and Tyranitar. Pupitar is also a Rock/Ground-type Pokémon and Tyranitar is a Rock/Dark-type pseudo-type legendary Pokémon.
Stonjourner is a Big Rock Pokémon. Its a Generation VIII Rock-type Pokémon with no known evolutions. Stonjourner has the Power Spot ability, which increases the power of moves used by allies by 30%.

Armarouge the Fire Warrior Pokémon is exclusive to Pokémon Scarlet. It’s a Fire and Psychic type with the Flash Fire ability, which boosts its Fire type attacks when hit by one. It has a new move called Armor Cannon that deals heavy Fire-type Special damage, but lowers Armarouge’s Def and Sp. Def stats.

Not much is known about Great Tusk at this stage. The new Pokémon seems to resemble Donphan, a Ground-type Pokémon from the Johto region. Its key features include its large body and massive tusks. Perhaps a past version of Donphan?
Koraidon is a Legendary Pokémon that appears in Pokémon Scarlet, featuring on the game’s cover art. You will receive a Koraidon to accompany you during your travels.
Koraidon has multiple forms to suit different traversal needs: Sprinting Build for moving fast on land, Swimming Build for going across water and Gliding Build for gliding through the air.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Pokémon Violet Exclusives Confirmed

chapterContent.content: This page details all the exclusive Pokémon that you’ll only find in Pokémon Violet. It will includes new Pokémon and older generation Pokémon that can only be found in the Violet version of the game.

chapterContent.aside: We will update it with all the latest information on exclusive Pokémon as it comes out!

chapterContent.content: Head over to our page on All Pokémon Scarlet Exclusives for information on Pokémon Scarlet.

chapterContent.head: New and Returning Pokémon for Violet

chapterContent.content: Bagon is a Generation III Dragon-type Pokémon that has two evolution stages: Shelgon and Salamence. Shelgon is also a Dragon-type and Salamence is a Dragon/Flying-type pseudo-legendary Pokémon.

Eiscue is a Generation VIII Penguin Pokémon. It is an Ice-type Pokémon and currently it has no evolutions. Eiscue has the Ice Face ability. When Eiscue uses Ice Face and is then hit by a physical move, it takes no damage and transforms into its Noice Face form. Noise Face form has decreases Defense and Special Defense but increased Speed, and it can be damaged by normal attacks. This form will remain even when Eiscue is switched out, but Eiscue will revert back to standard form at the end of the battle.

Ceruledge the Fire Blades Pokémon is exclusive to Pokémon Violet. It’s a Fire and Ghost type with the Flash Fire ability, which boosts its Fire type attacks when hit by one. It has a new move called Bitter Blades, a Fire-type physical attack that restores Ceruledge’s HP by half the damage dealt to the foe.

Not much is known about Iron Treads at this stage. The new Pokémon has similarities to Donphan from the Johto region. It has a metallic, robotic body with a tire tread in front. Perhaps a future version of Donphan?
Miraidon is a Legendary Pokémon that appears in Pokémon Violet, featuring on the game’s cover art. You will receive a Miraidon to accompany you during your travels.
Miraidon has multiple forms to suit different traversal needs: Drive Mode for moving fast on land, Aquatic Mode for going across water and Glide Mode for gliding through the air.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: New Characters in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: It’s not just new Pokémon, because we’re in a new region, prepare to meet tons of new faces in Scarlet & Violet!

chapterContent.head: Characters You Will Meet in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: You’re a new student at the academy at Paldea, with sky-high aspirations. The outfit you wear depends on which version you’re playing: Scarlet or Violet.

Arven is a senior student at the academy. He’s good at cooking and is researching healthy recipes to make Pokémon feel better. What a nice guy! That said, he’s no good at Pokémon battles, so you may need to lend a hand.
He appears in the Path of Legends story.
Brassius is a Gym Leader from the town of Artazon, where flowers and art bloom. Unsurprisingly, he commands Grass-type Pokémon and is nicknamed the Verdant Virtuoso.
He’s one of your opponents in the Victory Road story.
Clavell is the director of the academy. He can appear strict, but it’s only out of the kindness of his heart. Seems to be friends with Professor Sada and Professor Turo.
Geeta is the chairwoman of Paldea’s Pokémon League, which manages the various Pokémon Gyms. Among the region’s Champions, she’s renowned as the strongest of them all.
You’ll encounter Geeta during the Victory Road story.

Grusha is the Gym Leader of the Glaseado Gym. He was once a professional snowboarder. As you might expect, he favors Ice-type Pokémon. Usually cool-headed, but when the battle gets heated, his normally hidden emotions may bubble to the surface.
He’s one of your opponents in the Victory Road story.

Iono is a Gym Leader from the city of Levincia. She’s an expert of Electric-type Pokémon and also a popular web celebrity, nicknamed the Supercharged Streamer. Try not to lose against her, because your battle may be live-streamed across Paldea!
She’s one of your opponents in the Victory Road story.

Jacq is your homeroom teacher, who teaches biology. He knows a lot about Pokémon biology and invented the Pokédex app for the Rotom Phone. Can be air-headed at times, often losing himself in his research.

Mela is the leader of Team Star’s Fire crew, the Schedar Squad. She’s an all-rounder who can fix any problems, although her methods can be heavy-handed. Gives off a rough and gruff impression, but her dedication has earned her the trust of her crew.
You’ll encounter Mela during the Starfall Street story.

Nemona is your Pokémon battle-loving friend. She’s cheerful and energetic and, since she’s an experienced Pokémon trainer, she frequently offers useful advice. Despite her skill in battling, she’s a bit careless when it comes to throwing Poké Balls.
Penny is in the same grade as you. She’s shy and rarely attends the academy for some reason. Often seen sporting a fluffy Eevee bag on her back. Where can we get one of those?
These Professors are studying the lore of the Paldea region. In Pokémon Scarlet, you’ll meet Professor Sada. Meanwhile, you’ll be acquainted with Professor Turo instead in Pokémon Violet.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Is Every Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet?

chapterContent.content: This page explains whether every Pokémon is in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet or not.

Over the course of 25+ years of the Pokémon series, the total number of Pokémon creatures has exceeded 1000. For a very long time, it has been possible to obtain every single Pokémon in one game, but recently this has stopped happening.
This has caused many Pokémon fans to wonder whether you’ll be able to obtain all 1000+ Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: Answer: No

chapterContent.content: The official game page for Scarlet & Violet suggests that not every Pokémon will appear in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
When discussing connectivity with Pokémon HOME, the webpage states that only Pokémon that appear in Scarlet & Violet can be transferred from HOME to Scarlet & Violet.
It also recommends that players should check later to see which Pokémon will appear in Scarlet & Violet.
Seeing how Pokémon Sword & Shield did not include every Pokémon, even after all the DLC for it, it was inevitable that Scarlet & Violet would follow suit.

chapterContent.head: What Pokémon are in Scarlet & Violet?

chapterContent.content: At the time of writing, nobody knows how many Pokémon will appear in Scarlet & Violet. But we imagine it’ll be at least 300, similar to Sword & Shield, without the DLC.

Here is an A-Z list of Pokémon that have physically appeared in trailers and other promotional material, alongside their evolved or unevolved forms. It’s a long list, so we recommend using the search function if you’re looking for a particular Pokémon.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Early Purchase & Pre-order Bonuses

chapterContent.content: This page lists all of the notable early purchase and pre-order bonuses for Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
In an attempt to get people to pre-order the game or buy it within the release window, Nintendo and other retailers are offering multiple in-game bonuses.

chapterContent.head: All Early Purchase Bonuses

chapterContent.content: Until 28th February 2023, every owner of Scarlet & Violet can receive a rare Pikachu via Mystery Gift. This Pikachu knows the move Fly and has the Flying Tera-Type, reminiscent of the old-school Flying Pikachu.

To receive this Pikachu, you must access the in-game Mystery Gift menu, then choose “Get via Internet”. Naturally, your Nintendo Switch must be connected to the Internet. A Nintendo Online Subscription is not required to obtain Mystery Gifts.

Evaluation: This sounds like a useful bonus, because it’ll probably be the only way to obtain Fly on Pikachu. Fly itself isn’t amazing, but it’s nice for countering Grass-types. Meanwhile, the Flying Tera Type is neat because it allows Pikachu to turn the tables against its number one enemy: Ground-types.

chapterContent.head: Pre-order Bonuses

chapterContent.content: Until 11th November 2022, if you pre-order Pokémon Scarlet, Pokémon Violet or the Double Pack from the Pokémon Center website (US, Canada or UK), you can obtain a serial code for a Floral-print Sport Backpack. You can input this serial code via the Mystery Gift menu, when you’re connected to the Internet, to obtain the backpack.

Evaluation: The backpack is a character customization accessory and has no gameplay benefit. So basically it’s just for looks. If you’re a collector, you may want to grab this, since it sounds like it’s exclusive. However, at the end of the day, it’s not a huge deal if you don’t have it.

Those who pre-order the Pokémon Scarlet and Pokémon Violet Double Pack will receive two serial codes for 100 Poké Balls each. This bonus is also included if you pre-order the digital version of the Double Pack (where available). The serial codes will not expire.

Evaluation: Considering one of the main draws of the games is catching Pokémon, 100 Poké Balls will be quite useful early on. That said, we imagine it’ll be quite easy to obtain Poké Balls as you progress through the game. This is a convenient bonus if you’re getting the Double Pack anyway, but don’t feel pressured to buy the Double Pack for the bonus.
If you pre-order Pokémon Scarlet or Pokémon Violet separately via the Nintendo eShop, you can receive a serial code for the Adventure Set, which contains the following items:

chapterContent.li: Potion ×10
Full Heal ×5
Revive ×3
Ether ×3
Rare Candy ×1
Nugget ×1

chapterContent.content: The serial code expires after 7th March 2023.

Evaluation: These items will probably be useful near the start, when you have very few items. But if it’s similar to previous games, the bonus items will soon become redundant. Like the Double Pack bonus, they’re nice if you’re already planning to get Scarlet or Violet from the eShop. Otherwise, they’re not worth fussing over.
If you pre-order a physical copy of the Pokémon Scarlet, Pokémon Violet or the Double Pack via BestBuy (US or Canada), you can receive a serial code for the Berry Set, which includes the following:

chapterContent.li: Cheri Berry x1
Chesto Berry x1
Aspear Berry x1
Pecha Berry x1
Persim Berry x1
Rawst Berry x1

chapterContent.content: Evaluation: Berries are nice, but this selection is pretty underwhelming, even compared to the Adventure Set. Although it’s currently unclear how you can obtain berries in Scarlet & Violet, these berries have always been extremely common.
If you pre-order a physical copy of Pokémon Scarlet, Pokémon Violet or the Double Pack via Amazon.com, you can receive a serial code for the Healing Set, which includes the following items:

chapterContent.li: Potion x10
Antidote x10
Revive x5

chapterContent.content: Evaluation: This is like a slightly worse version of the Adventure Set. You do get 10 Antidotes versus 5 Full Heals, but Full Heals can heal every status condition, so they’re worth more. Meanwhile you get 2 more Revives here, but you lose the Ethers, Rare Candy and Nugget. That said, neither set is really that good. The main advantage is that you can get this bonus with a physical copy of the game.
If you pre-order a physical copy of Pokémon Scarlet or Pokémon Violet via Amazon UK, you can receive a serial code for the following items:

chapterContent.li: Luxury Ball x10
Soothe Bell x1

chapterContent.content: Evaluation: This is a rather niche bonus that only experienced trainers will appreciate. Pokémon caught in Luxury Balls start with higher Friendship than normal and if you let them hold a Soothe Bell, their Friendship will increase at a faster rate. This is useful for Pokémon that require high Friendship to evolve, etc. In any case, it’s in the same boat as the Adventure, Berry and Healing Sets: Hardly essential, but better than nothing.
If you pre-order a physical copy of Pokémon Scarlet, Pokémon Violet or the Double Pack via The Source (Canada), you can receive a serial code for the Refreshment Set, which includes the following:

chapterContent.li: Fresh Water x5
Soda Pop x5
Lemonade x5

chapterContent.content: Evaluation: These are items that restore HP similar to Potions. Unless you have a soft spot for soft drinks, we don’t really recommend it; the Adventure Set and Healing Set are a bit better since they have Revives. But really, all of these item sets are largely skippable.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Bonuses for Playing Previous Pokémon Games

chapterContent.content: This page outlines all the bonuses you can get for playing previous Pokémon games.

As an incentive for making you buy ‘em all, some Pokémon games give you small bonuses for playing a previous game. For example, you can get a Gigantamax Pikachu or Eevee in Pokémon Sword & Shield if you played Pokémon Let’s Go Pikachu or Eevee.

chapterContent.head: What Bonuses Are Available for Playing Older Pokémon Games?

chapterContent.content: In Scarlet & Violet’s case, you can receive a unique phone case for your Rotom Phone depending on which Pokémon game(s) you’ve played.
The eligible games include:
For each pair of games (or singular game in Arceus’s case), you can obtain a phone case inspired by those game(s).

chapterContent.aside: You must have Play Records for the eligible games saved to your Nintendo Switch console. Play Records are created the moment you start a game. The Play Records must also belong to the Nintendo Account that’s currently playing Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.content: To physically receive the unique phone cases, you should speak to a woman with sunglasses standing in front of the stairs leading to the central plaza, in Mesagoza, the main city of the Paldea region. According to Nintendo, it can take roughly 2 hours to reach her.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Which Pokémon Starter Should You Pick in Scarlet & Violet?

chapterContent.content: This page will offer guidance on which Pokémon Starter you should pick in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. It will detail all we know so far about the starters and their types and moves. But ultimately, most people will choose their starter based on their preferences and the Pokémon’s aesthetic!

chapterContent.head: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet Starters

chapterContent.content: The three starters in this installment in the Pokémon franchise will be Sprigatito, Fuecoco and Quaxly! On this page you’ll find everything we know about the Starters! Remember, Pokémon Scarlet & Violet has an open world so you could switch out your starter Pokémon for something more to your tastes pretty early on!

chapterContent.head: Grass Type Starter: Sprigatito

chapterContent.content: Sprigatito is an adorable Grass Cat Pokémon is a Grass-type with the classic Overgrow ability, boosting its Grass-type attacks when its HP falls below a third.
Sprigatito’s design is probably the cutest out of the three starters, but Grass-types tend to be the weaker of the starter bunch.

chapterContent.head: Fire Type Starter: Fuecoco

chapterContent.content: Fuecoco the smiley Fire Croc Pokémon is a Fire-type with the Blaze ability, common for Fire-type starters, which boosts its Fire-type attacks in a pinch.
Fire-type Pokémon can sometimes be on the rarer side (though this might not be the case for the open-world of Paldea) and having a fire-type in your arsenal early on can help with team synergy.

chapterContent.head: Water Type Starter: Quaxly

chapterContent.content: Quaxly the Duckling Pokémon with a fancy hair-do is a Water-type with the Torrent ability, enhancing its Water-type attacks when it has low HP.

Quaxly will make a decent starter because Water-types tend to have the best move-pools and he’s also quite cool looking. We don’t know about his evolution yet but we reckon he’s gonna be a pretty suave fellow!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Customize Your Character

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to customize your player character in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
Customizing your character has always been a popular feature of the games, ever since Pokémon X & Y.

chapterContent.head: When Can You Customize Your Character?

chapterContent.content: Unlike previous games, you can freely customize your character from the very beginning of the game, after choosing your in-game language and character name.
You’ll have the option to select your character’s:

chapterContent.li:
Hairstyle:
Haircut
Hair color
Haircut
Hair color

Look:
Eye Shape
Color Contacts
Eyelash Shape
Eyelash Color
Eyebrow Shape
Eyebrow Color
Lip Shape
Lip Color
And more
Eye Shape
Color Contacts
Eyelash Shape
Eyelash Color
Eyebrow Shape
Eyebrow Color
Lip Shape
Lip Color
And more

chapterContent.content: Afterwards, you can modify your character’s Hairstyle and Look at salons in various towns and cities.

When you begin the game, you can choose from four kinds of school uniforms. Additionally, you can purchase a wide variety of accessories from boutiques in various towns and cities. You cannot purchase different outfits like previous games due to the emphasis on school uniform.
Other customization options, such as your character’s appearance and outfits can be changed via the in-game menu.

chapterContent.aside: Unlike previous games, appearance and outfit customization options are not restricted to male or female characters.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Catch Pokémon

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to catch Pokémon in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

Like in previous games, you can only catch wild Pokémon, not Pokémon that belong to other trainers. The open world makes catching Pokémon a little different than the older games in the series but if you played Pokémon: Legends Arceus then you will be somewhat familiar with the process.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Pokémon

chapterContent.content: You can find wild Pokémon roaming all across the Paldea region. Similar to Pokémon Sword & Shield, as well as Pokémon Legends Arceus, wild Pokémon are visible on the field.

To catch wild Pokémon, you will need to battle them. This can be done by simply touching the wild Pokémon. Alternatively, you can press  to throw your lead Pokémon at them. If you throw your lead Pokémon at their back, you’ll gain a turn bonus at the start of battle.

chapterContent.head: How to use Poké Balls

chapterContent.content: When you’re in a battle with a wild Pokémon, you can throw Poké Balls at them by pressing  or opening your Bag and navigating to the Poké Balls tab. Poké Balls can be purchased from shops.

After using a Poké Ball, the wild Pokémon will go inside the Poké Ball. However, they’re not captured yet! The Poké Ball will shake up to three times. During this window, the Pokémon may break out of the Poké Ball; if this occurs, you can try again during your next turn. Otherwise, if the Pokémon remains in the Poké Ball, congratulations, you’ve caught it!
You can improve the success rate of catching a wild Pokémon by doing many things.

chapterContent.head: After Catching a Pokémon

chapterContent.content: Upon catching a Pokémon, they’ll be automatically added to your party of 6. If your party is full up, you can send the newly caught Pokémon to your Boxes or one of your existing party members instead.

chapterContent.aside: Pokémon that you’ve caught will retain their HP, PP and status conditions from the last fight, so it’s a good idea to heal them up.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Use the "Let's Go!" Feature

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to use the “Let’s Go!” feature in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. It’s a new feature but takes its inspiration from past titles, notably the Pokémon: Let’s Go Pikachu & Eevee games.

chapterContent.head: What is the “Let’s Go!” Feature?

chapterContent.content: While exploring Paldea, you can have one Pokémon from your party follow behind you. Similar to Pokémon HeartGold & SoulSilver.
Press  at an empty space to throw out your first Pokémon. They will then follow behind you and automatically pick up items near them.

chapterContent.aside: The Pokémon follow you rather slowly. Also, if you stray too far, they will annoyingly return to their Poké Ball.

chapterContent.content: Additionally, you can order your Pokémon around using the “Let’s Go!” feature, which is perhaps named after the Pokémon Let’s Go Pikachu & Eevee games.
To trigger “Let’s Go!” simply press . Your Pokémon will travel in the direction you’re facing. They may pick up items and Auto-Battle wild Pokémon by themselves.

chapterContent.aside: Your Pokémon doesn’t need to be out, to use “Let’s Go!” If they’re inside a Poké Ball, they’ll come out instantly.

chapterContent.head: What is Auto-Battle?

chapterContent.content: The name basically tells you everything you need to know, but when your Pokémon is engaged in an Auto-Battle, they will fight without requiring any input from you. You can do whatever you want: stay and watch or go elsewhere and do something else.

If you win an Auto-Battle, your Pokémon can gain experience points and items. Auto-Battles are extremely quick–if you’re strong enough, they’ll be over in a single attack. So they’re a good way to farm EXP and items with minimal hassle. However, you cannot catch wild Pokémon in this manner.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: What are Gimmighouls?

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about Gimmighouls in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. These are hidden throughout Paldea and are required for completing the Pokédex.
As you travel around Paldea, you may often hear a spooky laughter, this indicates the presence of a Roaming Gimmighoul, one of two types of Gimmighoul you’ll find throughout Paldea.

chapterContent.head: Roaming Gimmighouls

chapterContent.content: Roaming Gimmighouls are the most common, and you’ll find them in places such as ruins, Pokémon Centers or even standing on the many signposts throughout the region. When you interact with these Pokémon, you’ll obtain between one and four Gimmighoul Coins before they run off.

These are used in the evolution for Gimmighoul’s Chest Form, but you’ll need 999+ of them to evolve it, so you’ll need to track down a lot of these Roaming Gimmighouls. Do note, however, you cannot battle a Roaming Gimmighoul so you can’t catch one in Pokémon Scarlet and Violet, but you may be able to do so in Pokémon Go soon.

With needed to get 999+ Coins, you may wonder if you have to track down every single Roaming Gimmighoul? The answer is an emphatic no, as the Roaming Gimmighouls will respawn in the same locations after some time has passed. Even better yet, there are alternatives to getting more Coins at once!

chapterContent.head: Gimmighoul Chests

chapterContent.content: The second type of Gimmighoul are the Gimmighoul Chests, and you’ll often find them situated at the top of Watchtowers or other well-hidden parts of Paldea. These are easy to identify, as they look like a typical chest that wouldn’t look out of place in a Final Fantasy or Dragon Quest.

Once you find one, interact with it and you’ll be thrust into battle against a Gimmighoul Chest. Note that you can catch Gimmighoul Chests, so try to catch the first one you come across if at all possible as they’re not overly difficult to deal with.
More importantly, once you defeat a Gimmighoul Chest, you’ll be awarded between 50-60 Gimmighoul Coins! This will make your life a lot easier when trying to farm the 999+ needed for the evolution.

With Gimmighoul Chests offering up 50-60 Coins, you may be wondering if you can just farm the same chest over and over to get the task over quickly. As of right now, we’ve found no way to respawn the chests, but as we continue to explore Paldea discover all of its secrets, we may soon learn of a way to respawn them.

chapterContent.aside: There have been some reports of putting the clock on your Switch forward a long time (a year or so) has caused some chests to respawn in some places. We’ve yet to verify this information, however.

chapterContent.content: Still, there are plenty of them scattered all over Paldea that it can make a serious dent into your Coin collecting extravaganza!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Best Starter Teams

chapterContent.content: When you start out in Pokemon Scarlet and Violet, you will have the starter of your choice, plus a Lechonk. Before you get to the academy, you can have a full team. We aren’t just talking about a ragtag bunch of mons either as there is plenty of variety in Pokemon to choose from. Below we go over the best starter team to have, as well as some tips for making your first few hours in Paldea easy.

chapterContent.head: Best Starter Picks and Where to Find Them

chapterContent.content: Diglett is a ground-type Pokemon that isn’t affected by electric attacks and can learn useful moves like dig. It can be caught in the Inlet Grotto, which you will be forced to walk through on your way to the academy.

This is a unique combo of poison and ground that makes it easy to deal with grass and electric types. Paldean Wooper can be found near the lake right below the East Los Platos Pokemon Center. Best of all, Paldean Wooper evolves into Clodsire at level 20.

This is a must if you didn’t pick Fuecoco as it adds both fire and flying moves to your team. Fletchling can be found from Pocco Path onward. Like most bird types, it evolves rather quickly. At level 17, your Fletchling will turn into a Fletchinder.

If you don’t go with the grass-type starter, Sprigatito, then grabbing a Hoppip is a solid choice. While this likely won’t be a forever choice for your team, it offers you a pull of solid grass-type moves for the start of the game. In addition, it also evolves pretty early at level 18.

If you don’t choose the water-type Quaxly, then go ahead and grab the nearest duck Pokemon you can find. Psyduck can use both psychic and water-type moves giving you a solid move set to choose from. He does take a bit to evolve into Golduck, though, as you will need to wait until h reaches level 33.

You can get an electric type right away. Just turn right when you hit the Pokemon Center outside of Mesagove and go up the small hill. This will put an early Electric Pokemon on your team, and let’s be honest, who doesn’t love to get Pikachu early on? Be sure to keep it on your team, though, as Pichu evolves when it’s happy.

This one is a bit hidden, but you can get a Gastly on your team before you even learn about the three different story paths. Once you make it to the East Los Platos Pokemon Center, take a right and head up the hill. You will want to keep walking further out until you see some ruins. Gastly spawns at high frequency in the middle of these. Gastly evolves at level 25 to Haunter and then can immediately be traded to get the Gengar evolution.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How do Pokémon Battles Work?

chapterContent.content: Battles are a key element of the Pokémon series–and this, of course, extends to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. So, how do they work this time around?

chapterContent.head: How do Battles Work in Scarlet & Violet?

chapterContent.content: There are two main ways of initiating a Pokémon battle:
One, you can begin a battle with a wild Pokémon by touching the wild Pokémon on the field. This is similar to starting a battle in Pokémon Sword & Shield.

Also, if you’re close enough to a wild Pokémon, you can press  to automatically throw your lead Pokémon at the wild Pokémon to trigger the battle. Doing this when the Pokémon is facing away from you will give you a bonus at the start of battle, akin to Pokémon Legends Arceus.

Two, you can begin a battle with a Pokémon trainer by walking next to them, when they’re ready for a battle (for example, when they’re bouncing a Poké Ball in their hands). Unlike previous Pokémon games, a Pokémon trainer will not force you to fight them when you enter their line of sight.

chapterContent.head: Battle Flow

chapterContent.content: After initiating a battle, you will send out the first available Pokémon in your party. If you’re facing an opposing Pokémon trainer, they will do the same.
Next, you and your opponent(s) will take turns to choose an action to perform.
During a battle, the following actions will be available to you:

chapterContent.li: Battle: This lets you select your current Pokémon’s moves. Each Pokémon can learn up to 4 moves. The number next to a move (its PP value) indicates how many times it can be used. You can press  to learn what a move does.
Pokémon: Choose this to view your Pokémon party. From here, you can check the stats of your Pokémon or switch out your current Pokémon for a new one.
Bag: This lets you open your bag to use various items, such as recovery items or items that temporarily boost stats.
Run: If things are looking dire, choose this to attempt to flee from the battle.

chapterContent.aside: When facing a wild Pokémon, you can also press  to bring up your Poké Balls, which you can use to try and catch the wild Pokémon.

chapterContent.content: After all sides have selected an action, anyone who opted to switch Pokémon, use items or flee the battle will go first.

From there, the Pokémon with the higher Speed stat will generally go first, followed by the remaining Pokémon. However, some moves like Quick Attack have increased priority, so be cautious–especially when your Pokémon are at low HP.

If a Pokémon is hit by a move, their HP may decrease. Once a Pokémon’s HP falls to 0, it will faint and exit the battle. If the fainted Pokémon belongs to a Pokémon trainer, the trainer must send out a replacement Pokémon from their party; if they have no more, they lose the battle. Meanwhile, when a wild Pokémon faints (or is captured), the battle immediately ends.

When you knock out (KO) or capture a Pokémon, all of your Pokémon will earn experience points, although Pokémon that didn’t contribute to the fight will earn less. Once a Pokémon has gained enough experience, they will Level Up, increasing their stats. Additionally, they may learn new moves or even evolve into a stronger form. Defeating a trainer will also reward you with money.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Type Match-Up Chart (Scarlet & Violet)

chapterContent.content: This page explains how Type Match-Ups work in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet and what, if anything, has changed for this entry in the series.

To excel in Pokémon battles, it’s important to understand your Type Match-Ups. These have been around since Pokémon Red & Blue, so perhaps you already know all of them. Otherwise, if you’re a new Pokémon trainer or need a refresher, we’ve got you covered!

chapterContent.head: Pokémon & Move Types

chapterContent.content: Each Pokémon belongs to one or two Types, visible in various places like the Pokémon menu or the Pokédex.

There are 18 Types ranging from Normal, Fire, Water, Grass to Dark, Steel and Fairy. Generally speaking, a Pokémon’s Type(s) reflect their characteristics. So if a Pokémon looks like it’s made of rock, it’s probably a Rock-type.

Similarly, every move that a Pokémon can use is assigned to one of the same 18 Types. A move called “Flamethrower” would be Fire-type, for example. Pokémon can learn moves that belong to their Type(s), but they may also learn moves of other Types.

chapterContent.head: Type Interactions

chapterContent.content: Like real life, certain Types fare better or worse against other Types. For example, water can put out fire, so Water-type moves are strong against Fire-type Pokémon. Conversely, fire struggles to evaporate water so Fire-type moves are bad against Water-type Pokémon. This is a huge simplification, but you get the idea.

chapterContent.li: If a move is strong against a particular Type, it will deal super-effective damage, which is double the normal amount.
If the move is weak, it will deal not very effective damage, which is half the normal amount.
On the far extreme, moves can even have no effect against a certain Type, resulting in zero damage.

chapterContent.content: As you can hopefully see, it pays to know your match ups!

chapterContent.aside: To make things easier, when encountering a Pokémon you’ve already fought before, when viewing your moves, the game will indicate how effective they are against that Pokémon.

chapterContent.head: Our Handy Match-Up Chart

chapterContent.content: With 18 Types, that means there are 324 possible combinations. Which is quite a lot to memorize! That said, not every match up leads to an interesting result; in roughly half of all cases, the chosen Type is neutral against the targeted Type, resulting in the standard amount of damage. Still, that’s over a hundred to remember.

To assist you, we’ve create a useful chart that shows all the Type interactions, which you can refer to whenever you’re unsure. If you’re new to battling, we recommend learning the match ups for Fire, Water and Grass to begin with. Then see how you go from there. (Or you could always save the match up chart to your phone, etc.)

chapterContent.aside: First, check the left-most column and identify the Type of your chosen move. Then follow the row across until you reach the column that corresponds to your opponent’s Type.

chapterContent.head: Dual-Type Pokémon

chapterContent.content: If your opponent has two Types, it’s slightly more complicated, but not that much. All you have to do is multiply the individual damage multipliers together.

For example, you’re fighting a Dragonite, which is a Dragon and Flying-type. Normally, Electric deals 2x damage to Flying. However, it also deals 0.5x damage to Dragon. So if you combine the numbers, it does 2 times 0.5 equals 1x damage. In other words, Electric is neutral against Dragonite.

On the other hand, what if you used an Ice-type move against Dragonite? Well, Ice deals 2x damage to Dragon and it also deals 2x damage to Flying. So that means Dragonite will take a massive 4x damage from Ice-type moves!

chapterContent.head: Other Factors

chapterContent.content: In most situations, the Type Match-Up chart is all you need. But keep in mind that it’s not completely foolproof. You also need to pay attention to other things like the Pokémon’s Abilities or held items.

A common thing to watch out for is the Levitate Ability, which confers immunity to Ground-type moves. If a Pokémon seems to be floating, it may have Levitate. Likewise, Pokémon with the Dry Skin Ability are immune to Water-type moves. This is less obvious than Levitate, but fortunately not as common.

On the flip side, Normal and Fighting moves are useless against Ghost-types. But if a Pokémon has the Scrappy Ability, they’ll be able to hit their spooky opponent with their Normal and Fighting type moves! The moves Foresight and Odour Sleuth have a similar effect as well.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Pokémon Nature Chart (Scarlet & Violet)

chapterContent.content: This page includes a nature chart for Pokémon Scarlet & Violet, as well as explaining how natures work.

chapterContent.head: What are Natures?

chapterContent.content: Every Pokémon has a Nature, which reflects their personality: for example, you could have a Sylveon that’s Lonely. Natures are randomly assigned and you can directly identify a Pokémon’s Nature by going to the 3rd tab of their status screen.

More importantly, Natures slightly influence a Pokémon’s stats. Depending on the Nature, one stat will be boosted by 10% and another stat will be decreased by 10%. Furthermore, a Pokémon’s Nature determines the flavor of sandwiches they like.

chapterContent.head: Nature Chart

chapterContent.content: The following chart shows which stats are boosted or decreased for each Nature, as well as the liked and disliked flavors.

chapterContent.aside: If a Nature has the same boosted and decreased stat, then the effect cancels out and there won’t be a boosted or decreased stat.

chapterContent.head: How Important are Natures?

chapterContent.content: If you’re checking your party now and disappointed at the random mishmash of Natures, don’t worry. Because you can easily beat the main story with sub-optimal Natures.
Still, when you’re competing against other human trainers or the tougher post-game battles or raids, having a beneficial Nature is one of the first things you should fix.
Although Natures only increase/decrease a stat by 10%, this is massive during serious battles. You’ll absolutely want Natures that boost your Pokémon’s key stats and ones that don’t lower them.

chapterContent.head: What is the Best Nature for a Pokémon?

chapterContent.content: When deciding what Nature is ideal for a Pokémon, first you should identify what their role is. For example, if your Pokémon is a physical powerhouse, you’ll probably want an Attack-boosting Nature such as Adamant. A Speed-boosting Nature could be useful as well, since Pokémon with higher Speed go first.

In most cases, avoid picking a Nature that doesn’t boost any stats, such as Hardy. You may think it’s smart to have no weaknesses, but in the dog eat dog world of Pokémon battling, having no strengths is a bad thing. If you want to use both Physical and Special moves, go for a Nature that lowers a Defense stat instead.

Likewise, whatever you do, don’t pick a Nature that covers for a weakness. The boost from a Nature is a 10% multiplier and multiplying a low stat is never as effective as multiplying a high stat. If a Pokémon has a low stat, you’ll just have to work around it or use a different Pokémon for the job.

chapterContent.head: How to Manipulate Natures

chapterContent.content: Normally, Pokémon have random Natures, so you won’t be able to choose what you get. However, there are some ways to get the Nature that you want.
You can occasionally find mints when inspecting the random shiny spots on the ground.

To consistently get the Mints you want, visit a Chansey Supply shop found in various cities after obtaining the 6th Gym Badge. You can can buy all 25 types of Mints, but they are expensive, costing 20,000 Poké Dollars each.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: What Are Picnics and How Do They Work?

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about the new picnic feature in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet. It’s a great mechanic and can be used in advanced ways as you progress through the game.

chapterContent.head: What are Picnics in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet?

chapterContent.content: Picnics are the latest way to get cozy with your Pokémon while exploring, similar to the camping feature in Pokémon Sword & Shield.
You can have a picnic almost anywhere while traveling.

chapterContent.head: What Can You Do at Picnics?

chapterContent.content: There are a few activities available during picnics.
During a picnic, your party Pokémon, as well as your Legendary Pokémon (Koraidon or Miraidon) will come out of their Poké Balls and wander around nearby.
You can go up to one of these Pokémon, to speak to them or play with them using toys.
In addition, as you travel around a lot, your Pokémon can get a little dirty. When this happens, you can wash your Pokémon. Doing this will also restore their HP and improve their Friendship.
While your Pokémon are all gathered outside, this is the perfect opportunity to take some photos! You can also choose from various photo filters, which can alter the mood of the photo.
You can’t very well have a picnic without some food. Thankfully, your player character is quite skilled at making sandwiches.
Before making a sandwich, you can choose what fillings and condiments to use, as well as the sandwich pick to hold everything together.
After deciding, you’ll then need to carefully arrange your ingredients on the bread, doing your best to stack them together. If you don’t balance them properly, they may slip off your bread!
Succeed and you may end up with a sandwich to end all sandwiches. Eating sandwiches will restore the HP of your Pokémon and may confer buffs.
It’s possible to obtain Pokémon Eggs, while on a picnic. At the time of writing, the mechanics of this are unknown.
In past games, you can walk around with a Pokémon Egg in your party and eventually it’ll hatch into a Level 1 Pokémon.
If you want to liven things up, you can play with other players (either locally or online) via the Union Circle. To do so, you simply approach another player’s picnic.
Up to four players can play together, creating sandwiches, taking photos, etc. You can even find Pokémon Eggs.

chapterContent.aside: To play online, you need an active Nintendo Switch Online subscription.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: All TM Crafting Materials & Where to Get Them

chapterContent.content: This page lists all TM Materials in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. It also lists up to four source Pokémon drops for each TM Material. TM materials are found by players after winning battles and defeating wild Pokémon. You can find more information by clicking the individual TM Material’s and visiting our corresponding TM Materials database page. You can also vist our Pokédex to learn more about each Pokémon!

chapterContent.head: List of TM Crafting Materials & Pokémon Drops

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: When Will Pokemon HOME Come to Scarlet and Violet

chapterContent.content: This page explains what Pokémon HOME is and how it relates to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

Pokémon HOME is a cloud-based storage system that lets you transfer and store Pokémon creatures from various Pokémon games. You can download it via the Nintendo Switch and mobile devices. It’s the successor of the Pokémon Bank app for the Nintendo 3DS, which had a similar purpose.

chapterContent.head: Are Scarlet & Violet Compatible with Pokémon HOME?

chapterContent.content: Because Pokémon Scarlet & Violet are mainline games, you’ll be able to connect them to Pokémon HOME. However, this won’t be possible straightaway.
During early 2023, there will be an update to Pokémon HOME that adds compatibility with Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: How to Download Pokémon HOME

chapterContent.content: On a Nintendo Switch, you can download Pokémon HOME via the Nintendo eShop.
On a mobile device, you can download Pokémon HOME via the Apple Store (iOS devices) or Play Store (Android devices).

chapterContent.aside: Pokémon HOME is free to download, but there are limitations unless you pay for a subscription.

chapterContent.head: Requirements For Using Pokémon HOME

chapterContent.content: Because Pokémon HOME is a cloud-based service, your Nintendo Switch or mobile device must have Internet access while using it.

When you first open Pokemon HOME, you must link a Nintendo Account. If you don’t have a Nintendo Account, you can create one for free via your Nintendo Switch or Internet browser on your computer/mobile device.

chapterContent.aside: If you link the same Nintendo Account to the Nintendo Switch version of Pokémon HOME and the mobile device version of Pokémon HOME, you can share Pokémon between the two version.

chapterContent.head: Premium Plan

chapterContent.content: As mentioned, you can download and use Pokémon HOME for free. But certain features are limited, unless you pay.
Please refer to the official website for the subscription costs.

chapterContent.head: Difference Between Nintendo Switch and Mobile Versions

chapterContent.content: Additionally, some features are exclusive to the Nintendo Switch version or the mobile device version.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: What Games Can Connect to Pokémon HOME?

chapterContent.content: This page explains which Pokémon games can currently connect with Pokémon HOME.

chapterContent.head: Compatible Games

chapterContent.content: The following Pokémon games can connect with Pokémon HOME:

chapterContent.aside:
One-way means that you can transfer the Pokémon from the original game to Pokémon HOME, but you can’t transfer them back.
Freely means that you can transfer the Pokémon from the original game to Pokémon HOME and vice versa.

chapterContent.head: Pokémon Bank

chapterContent.content: It’s worth noting that you can potentially transfer Pokémon from the first seven generations by passing them through Pokémon Bank, then Pokémon HOME.

chapterContent.aside: Pokémon Bank is only available to download before the end of March 2023.

chapterContent.content: The following Pokémon games can connect with Pokémon Bank:
The following Pokémon games can connect with Pokémon Bank’s companion app Poké Transporter, which sends them to Pokémon Bank:

chapterContent.head: Legacy Games

chapterContent.content: For the remaining games:

chapterContent.li: You can transfer Pokémon from Ruby, Sapphire, Emerald, FireRed and LeafGreen (Gen 3) to Diamond, Pearl, Platinum, HeartGold and SoulSilver (Gen 4) via the Pal Park in the Gen 4 games (one-way). You will need a Nintendo DS or Nintendo DS Lite with a GameBoy Advance slot.

You can transfer Pokémon from Diamond, Pearl, Platinum, HeartGold and SoulSilver (Gen 4) to Black, White, Black 2 and White 2 (Gen 5) via the Poké Transfer Lab in the Gen 5 games (one-way). You will need two Nintendo DS, 2DS or 3DS consoles.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Fastest Way to Make Money in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This page will provide you with the necessary methods to earn Poke Dollars in Pokemon Scarlet and Violet.

chapterContent.head: Best Way to Make Money in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: As you start your journey through Paldea you may come across several Pokemon Centers and Shops which offer items you can purchase like Ultra Balls and Hyper Potions. However, these items aren’t cheap, so you’ll need to find ways to build up your savings, so you can purchase these items when you need them.

Head to East Province (Area Three) or Asado Desert, as this area has lots of items you can pick up to sell for a good amount of Poke Dollars. Ideally, you’ll want to search both areas and gather everything, then visit any Pokemon Center and sell them. Below you can see what items you can find:

The next step on your money making journey is to acquire the Amulet Coin which can be obtained by defeating 5 Trainers in West Province (Area 3). If you’re struggling to find them, then you can find all the Trainer locations in this area on our map. Once you’ve defeated at least five trainers, speak with the Pokemon League Representative at the Pokémon Center Medali and he’ll give you the Amulet Coin.

You’ll want to give this item to a Pokemon in your team to hold, then the prize money will be doubled as long as you use them at least once during the battle. With this item in your possession you’ll want to continue defeating Trainers, as this will reward you with lots of cash if you are fighting Trainer at a slightly higher level then you.
Additionally, if you’ve beaten all 8 Gyms in the Starfall Street Path, then you can keep taking on the Academy Ace Tournament with a Pokemon holding the Amulet Coin.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Fastest Way to Level in Pokemon Scarlet and Violet

chapterContent.content: This page will provide you with the necessary methods to level up your Pokemon in Pokemon Scarlet and Violet.

chapterContent.head: Best Way to Level Pokemon in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: As you start your journey through Paldea you may come across several Pokemon which are a higher level then your current team, so you may need to quickly give your Pokemon some levels before you can continue. Pokemon Scarlet and Violet offers you 3 different storylines you can playthrough at the same time: Victory Road, Path of Legends and Starfall Street, so if the storyline you’re currently working through puts you up against a high level Pokemon try a different path. You can find the best way to tackle the game via our What is the Best Story Order in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet, as this will cause you to fight opponents around your Level.

Outside of the story another good way of leveling your Pokemon is via defeating the many Pokemon Trainers you’ll find throughout Paldea. You’ll want to defeat Trainers which are a slightly higher level than you, as this will reward you with more EXP. Additionally, if you defeat the required amount of Trainers in an area, then you can speak with the Pokemon League Representatives for a variety of useful rewards, such as TMs and Battle Items.

Chansey is a rare Pokemon which can be found around West Province Two / Three which will provide you with lots of EXP, but this method is only good if you can find lots of Chansey’s quickly. In order to make them spawn more regularly, then you’ll want to consume a Sandwich that increases Encounter Power: Normal. Below you can find some of the sandwiches that provides this stat boost:

Tera Raid Battles is a good way of boosting your Pokemons Level in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet, as they will reward you with Exp. Candy. There are different types of Tera Raid Battles which range from 1 Star to 7 Star. The Star will change the level of Pokemon you’ll face inside and will also provide you with better rewards. For example in the lower star raids you’ll only get Exp. Candy S, but in the higher star raids you’ll get Exp. Candy L which will provide your Pokemon with a lot of EXP.

You can use the Exp. Candy on a Pokemon of your choosing, so you can freely take in your most powerful Pokemon into the raid to ensure you can complete it, as you dont directly get EXP from the Raid itself. If you’re struggling to complete this Tera Raids solo, then you play with other Online Players via the Poke Portal. Unlocking the higher level Tera Raids will require doing certain things which can be found via this page: How do you Unlock 5 and 6 Star Tera Raids

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: What is the Best Story Order in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet?

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet is a true open world Pokémon experience and as such, you are free to tackle the three main storylines in any order. This page will guide you on the best route through the game, based off levels.

chapterContent.head: Where to go First?

chapterContent.content: After you start your adventure, you’ll soon be directed to head to the academy at Mesagoza, the capital city of the Paldea region. You’ll find yourself in South Province (Area 1), and you’re free to explore this area as you head north to Mesagoza.

Once you reach the academy follow the mandatory story events and soon, the Treasure Hunt will begin. At this time, you’ll begin Victory Road, Starfall Street, and Path of Legends, the three main storyline paths for Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. This is where you’re truly left to your own devices as you explore this vast region however you see fit.

chapterContent.head: Victory Road, Starfall Street, or Path of Legends?

chapterContent.content: As mentioned above, you’ll begin all three of these storylines once you leave the Mesagoza academy for the first time. Each of these will focus on a different theme with different unlocks so it’s important to understand what each one is.

Victory Road is your typical Gym adventure you’ll find in every other Pokémon. As such, you’ll need to travel around Paldea, completing the Gym Tests at the various settlements before defeating each Gym Leader. You’ll want to mix these in if you’re going for a random progression as each badge will allow higher level Pokémon to obey you.

Starfall Street involves heading to certain encampments scattered around Paldea to take on a squad of Team Star before battling their leader. You’ll take part in raid battles here by having up to three Pokémon wander and auto-battle. Once you take out the required number of Pokémon, you’ll have a showdown with the leader. Taking down a Squad will often reward you with lots of TM materials.

Path of Legends is the final storyline and it focuses on battling the Titans, all of which have a different type. As there’s only five of these, their level ranges tend to jump quite a bit, but they’re well worth you seeking out as defeating each one will unlock a new Travel ability such as the ability to Dash and Glide!

chapterContent.head: The Best Gym Route

chapterContent.content: As mentioned above, you’re free to tackle the game in any order you like, but there is a natural Level progression for each of the storylines and as such, you can follow this table for the most natural progression through Paldea. |
Once you’ve completed everything here, you will get the credits roll which will round off the adventure for Pokémon Scarlet & Violet and begin the post-game.
If you wish to know a bit more detail about specific routes (for example, if you wanted to focus on one at a time), then head to the following pages for more information:

chapterContent.li: Best Victory Road Route in Pokémon Scarlet and Violet
Best Starfall Street Route
Best Route for Path of Legends Story

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Evolve the New Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to evolve all the new Pokémon in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

With each new generation of Pokémon, it’s always exciting catching new Pokémon and training them. That said, sometimes you may wonder how a particular new species of Pokémon will evolve. There’s nothing worse than training a Pokémon to crazy high Levels, only to realize they evolve through some really obscure method…

chapterContent.head: List of New Pokémon and Their Evolution Methods

chapterContent.aside: When a Pokémon must Level Up to evolve, it won’t count if they Level Up passively via “Let’s Go!”

chapterContent.content: Simply raise the Pokémon to the specified Level and they’ll evolve.
These Pokémon are picky and won’t evolve unless the conditions suit them.
These Pokémon require a specific item to evolve. When you have the required item, use it from your Bag.
These Pokémon require specific moves (which they can learn) to evolve.
To evolve these Pokémon, you need to make them walk a certain number of steps with the “Let’s Go!” feature.
Because there’s always one that has to be special…
You can evolve Gimmighoul (Chest Form) after collecting enough coins from Gimmighoul (Roaming Form) scattered throughout the Paldea region.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Get Shiny Pokémon

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining Shiny Pokémon in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. It has become a little trickier to spot Shiny Pokémon this time around. However, if you’re an avid shiny hunter, you’ll be pleased to know there are ways to obtain Shiny Pokémon more easily!
Acknowledgements: Anubis

chapterContent.head: How to Find Shiny Pokémon

chapterContent.content: Shiny Pokémon, first appearing in Pokémon Gold & Silver, are extremely rare Pokémon that you may (or may not) encounter in the game.

They are called Shiny Pokémon because they sparkle at the beginning of battle. In addition, they are different color compared to Pokémon of the same species. For example, a shiny Eevee is silver-colored instead of brown.

chapterContent.aside: Besides the rarity and different color, Shiny Pokémon are otherwise identical to normal Pokémon. They don’t have better stats, for example.

chapterContent.content: There are generally two ways to obtain Shiny Pokémon, but neither of them are easy.
(Video credit: Zapph)

While exploring the Paldea region, any wild Pokémon can be shiny. Like in Pokémon Let’s Go Pikachu & Eevee and Pokémon Legends Arceus, you can identify Shiny Pokémon while on the field. Unfortunately, there is no visible sparkle or chime sound like in past games so you will simply have to pay attention to the wild pokemon.
Just like past games, there will be a 1 in 4096 chance that a Pokémon will be shiny.
Any Pokémon hatched from Eggs can be shiny, just like wild Pokémon. Likewise, the chance of the hatched Pokémon being shiny is 1 in 4096.
Pokémon breeding is a bit different in Scarlet & Violet, compared to previous games. There is no Daycare Center anymore; instead, you simply begin a picnic.

If there are Pokémon among your party that can breed with each other, you may discover Eggs when inspecting the picnic basket. After obtaining an Egg, place it in your party and, after traveling a certain number of steps, the Egg will eventually hatch into a Pokémon.

chapterContent.head: How to Increase the Chance of Finding Shiny Pokémon

chapterContent.content: By default, the chance of obtaining a shiny Pokémon is incredibly slim. However, there are ways to slightly increase the chance.

chapterContent.aside: The methods of increasing the shiny rate all stack, unless noted.

chapterContent.content: Here is a quick run down of your chances for each category below.
The Shiny Charm is a key item that provides 2 additional chances for a Pokémon to be shiny, increasing the base chance to 3 in 4096 (roughly 1 in 1365).

Similar to past games, you can receive the Shiny Charm by completing the Paldea Pokédex. Once you’ve accomplished this herculean task, return to Naranja/Uva Academy and speak to Professor Jacq to receive it.

One of the Meal Powers that you can get when crafting or cooking sandwiches (Sparkling Sandwiches) in picnics is Sparkling Power, which boosts the rate of finding Shiny Pokémon. Click here for all the Sparkling Sandwich recipes.
Sparkling Power Level 3 grants 3 additional chances for a Pokémon to be shiny, increasing the base chance to 4 in 4096 (1 in 1024).

chapterContent.aside: Sparkling Power only works for wild Pokémon, not Eggs.

chapterContent.content: This is an obscure (for new trainers) but incredibly effective method of boosting the shiny rate, when hatching Pokémon from Eggs.

If you obtain an Egg between two parents who have a different language tag from one another, there will be 6 additional chances for the hatched Pokémon to be shiny. This increases the base chance to 6 in 4096 (roughly 1 in 683). (Logically, it should be 7 in 4096, but it’s a bit weird.)
For example, if you have an English Magikarp that belongs to you and breed it with a Japanese Magikarp or other Pokémon that can breed with the ’karp.

chapterContent.head: What’s the Highest Chance of Finding Shiny Pokémon?

chapterContent.content: Since some methods don’t overlap with others, there are two routes you can take to get the highest shiny rate.
If you’re hunting for a wild Pokémon, you’ll want to:

chapterContent.li: KO 60+ of the same species in a mass outbreak.
Have Sparkling Power Level 3 from a sandwich.
Have the Shiny Charm.

chapterContent.content: This gives a total of 8 shiny rolls, for a 1 in 512 chance.
If you’re hatching Eggs, you’ll want to:

chapterContent.li: Have the Shiny Charm.
Use the Masuda Method.

chapterContent.content: This also gives 8 shiny rolls, for a 1 in 512 chance.

Both routes have their upsides and downsides. If you do the wild Pokémon route, it’s a bit bothersome to set up at first, but after scoring 60+ KOs, you can keep opening/closing picnics to quickly respawn Pokémon.

Meanwhile, if you decide to hatch Eggs, you have less work to do to get started, but it can be bothersome running around hatching Eggs and managing your surplus offspring. However, there are some Pokémon you can’t find in the wild easily (or at all) like the three starters.
If you want a shiny from a raid, you have to deal with the full 1 in 4096 odds. Sorry… But there’s generally no reason you’d have to do this.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to get the Shiny Charm in Pokémon Scarlet and Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining the Shiny Charm in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. If you’re an avid shiny hunter, you’ll want to use every tool at your disposal to increase your chances and that’s where the Shiny Charm comes in.

chapterContent.head: What is the Shiny Charm

chapterContent.content: The Shiny Charm existing will come as no surprise to veterans of the Pokémon series, but for those of you newer to the series, or maybe looking into Shiny Hunting for the first time, you may not know about this invaluable tool.

Once obtained, the Shiny Charm is a Key Item that will provide an additional two chances Pokémon to be shiny, increasing the base chance to 3 in 4096 (roughly 1 in 1365). Considering the base chance is 1 in 4096, this makes life a lot easier when Shiny Hunting, especially when you can boost that rate further with methods such as using Shiny Hunting Sandwiches.

chapterContent.head: Rewards for Completing the Pokédex with Mr. Jacq

chapterContent.content: As with all Pokémon titles, the Shiny Charm will come from completing the Pokédex. In the case of Pokémon Scarlet and Violet, that means capturing all 400 Pokémon so don’t expect this to be something you’ll complete early on in your adventure, this is very much a post-game activity.

Where you turn in your progress is where it gets tricky, because you get rewards for your Pokédex progress from two different places. The first is by accessing the Pokédex and going to the Trophy icon, at which point you’ll be awarded for every 10 entries collected. This is useful, but this is not where you’ll get your Shiny Charm.
If you’ve been attending Mr. Jacq’s Biology Classes at Naranja (Scarlet)/Uva (Violet) Academy, you’ll learn early on that he’s responsible for the creation of the Paldea’s Pokédex.

Head to the Biology lab and you’ll find Mr. Jacq here and after speaking with him, he’ll ask if you can show him your progress and he’ll give you something at specific milestones, this is where you’ll obtain the Shiny Charm. In the table below, you’ll find the full list of rewards that Mr. Jacq will hand out:

chapterContent.head: Tips for Completing the Pokémon Scarlet and Violet Pokédex

chapterContent.content: Now that you know what you need to get that elusive Shiny Charm, how do you go about doing it? Of course, catching every new Pokémon that you come across is always useful, and our Interactive Map will help you track down as many of them as possible. Beyond that, these tips below should help in completing your Pokédex.

chapterContent.li: Evolve as many of your caught Pokémon. Check our page on how to evolve the new Pokémon for some tips for the newer Pokémon.
Trade with other players online, especially for those Pokémon exclusive to the other version of the game you’re playing.
Use Mass Outbreaks to find rarer Pokémon, this also acts as a useful way to level up your Pokémon.

chapterContent.content: Beyond just the Shiny Charm, you’ll also obtain a Diploma from Director Clavell along with a Ribbon added to your profile.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Where to Get Ability Patches

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining the Ability Patches in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. It’s a great item for avid breeding and training players. Below we’ll navigate you through the necessary steps to obtaining them.

chapterContent.head: What are Ability Patches

chapterContent.content: Ability Patches are a single-use item that’ll allow you to change your Pokemon’s current ability over to a Hidden Ability. Due to the fact that these abilities aren’t the easiest to get you’ll find that the Hidden Abilities are in high demand in the competitive breeding and training side of the game..

chapterContent.head: How to Get Ability Patches in Pokémon Scarlet and Violet

chapterContent.content: Currently the only way you can get your hands on Ability Patches in Pokémon Scarlet and Violet is by completing 6-star Raids Tera Raid Battles. However, before you can gain access to the 6 star raids you’ll need to complete all three story paths, post-game tournaments and then fight a number of 5 star Tera Raid battles.

Additionally, 6-star Tera Raid will require you to defeat Level 90 Pokemon which as you may have guessed is very difficult with AI teammates, so you’ll want to do this online if possible, to give yourself a better chance of completing these battles. Make sure to use Battle Items, such a X-Attack, as this will improve the amount of damage you do against the Tera Pokemon.

chapterContent.head: How to Use Ability Patches

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve got your hands on an Ability Patch, open up your bag and navigate your way over to the “Other Items” Tab and select it. This will allow you to select a Pokemon in your Team to change its Ability to a Hidden Ability of its species. However, not every Pokemon has a Hidden Ability, but you can see which ones do or don’t as it’ll say “Can Use” or “Cant use” below its icon.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Where to Get Bottle Caps

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining the Bottle Caps which is an item you can use to improve your Pokemon’s Strength in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: How to Get Bottle Caps

chapterContent.content: You can sometimes get Bottle Caps as a drop from Five Star Tera Raids. However, this will require you to fight a Level 75 Pokemon which as you may have guessed is very difficult with AI teammates, so you’ll want to do this online if possible, to give yourself a better chance of completing these battles. Make sure to use Battle Items, such a X-Attack, as this will improve the amount of damage you do against the Tera Pokemon.

Unfortunately, you’ll have to farm a lot of these Tera Raids in order to get a good amount of Bottle Caps so this isn’t the best method. Alternatively, once you’ve obtained six badges from the Victory Road Storyline you’ll be able to purchase Bottle Caps from any Delibird Presents Shops for 20,000 Poke Dollars. Additionally, you can get Gold Bottle Caps from the Porto Marinada Auction House.

chapterContent.head: What are Bottle Caps

chapterContent.content: Bottle caps is a resource you can use to train your Pokémon IV (Individual Value). In order to do this you’ll want to visit the Hyper Trainer who can be found near the Ghost Gym in Montenevera. You’ll need to have the Pokemon you wish to Hyper Train be at atleast level 50 before you can raise one of the following IV: HP, Attack, Defense, Sp. Attack, Sp. Speed and Defense. If you’ve got a Gold Bottle Cap, then you can level all the stats at once!

As you approach the end of the game and start tackling the Elite 4 or the 6 Star Tera Raids you’ll notice that your Pokemon may begin to start struggling in these battles, so you’ll want to look into Hyper Training them. As the extra points in these stats could give you the upper hand.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How Does Hyper Training Work
