chapterContent.content: If you are wanting to play the Pokemon meta. Then you need to get familiar with special types of training. Hyper Training is an easy way to expedite the process of getting good IVs without having to hatch a million eggs. This is an expensive process and you can only get Hyper Training at one specific location in the game. If you’re new to the tournament world, then you likely have a ton of questions. Below we go over everything you need to know about Hyper Training, what it does, and how to go about unlocking it in Pokemon Scarlet and Pokemon Violet.

chapterContent.head: What is Hyper Training

chapterContent.content: Hyper Training is a specialized type of training that you can use to raise a Pokemon’s stats. Having a Hyper Training session will raise the IV you selected to 31, which is the maximum possible stat in the game. If you already have a Pokemon with a maxed-out IV stat, the game will even mark it with a crown so that you don’t waste training.

This is what trainers have been doing to prepare for professional tournaments for years. At one time, this was a complicated process that could only be done through selective breeding and RNG luck. Pokemon Violet and Pokemon Scarlet continued this streamlined process from Pokemon Sword and Pokemon Shield.
Keep in mind that while Hyper Training does help, you will still need to level your Pokemon and equip them with proper moves to succeed in battle.

chapterContent.head: Where is Hyper Training Located

chapterContent.content: You can only use Hyper Training if you go to Montenevera. The NPC is a male standing next to an Abomasnow located directly behind the town’s Pokemon Center.

chapterContent.head: How to Hyper Train in Pokemon Scarlet and Pokemon Violet

chapterContent.content: You will need to meet a few requirements before being able to Hyper Train a Pokemon. Here is what you need to do before unlocking the feature.

chapterContent.li: Have Your Pokemon at Level 50.
Unlock the ability to get bottle caps.

chapterContent.content: Once you are able to Hyper Train, you will be given a list of stats to choose from. Before selecting which Pokemon to train, you can even check their summary to see just how well off they are. This allows you to optimize the process.

Once you select which Pokemons stat to train, Hyper Training will instantly happen. The cost of Hyper Training is very high, so only choose the Pokemon you plan to use long term unless you are seriously looking at getting into the competitive scene.

chapterContent.head: How Do I Pay For Hyper Training?

chapterContent.content: There are two waves to pay for Hyper Training. One is with regular bottle caps, which will only max out one IV. The other is with golden bottle caps, which will max out all of one Pokemon stats. These caps can be obtained through raids or bought from Delibird Presents. For more in-depth info on bottle caps, check out our guide here.
Here is a breakdown of the total cost of training a team of six to full IVs in Pokemon Scarlet and Pokemon Violet.

To put this into more of a perspective, even if you have the Amulet Coin, you would have to run the Elite Four about around six times to max out an entire team without losing. If you don’t have the Amulet Coin, this double to twelve. While this isn’t awful, you will also have to put in the work to raise each Pokemon to level 50, and if you’re serious about playing professionally, you will need several well-built teams put through this process.

You can also sell items, but this is a much slower process, and the rarest item, the nugget, only sells for 5,000 a piece, making it a long-winded waste of time. This makes bottle caps your best bet, as the golden ones are way too expensive for what they are and should just be considered a happy raid reward.
When you go for training, their menu will tell you how many bottle caps you have in your possession so use them wisely.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: All Pokédex Rewards in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This page lists all the Pokédex rewards in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
Separate to rewards given to you by Jacq, your homeroom teacher, when you visit him at school, you can receive various gifts simply through the Pokédex app on your Rotom Phone.

When using the Pokédex app, select the main Pokédex near the top, which lists all 400 Pokémon in the Paldea region. Near the bottom-left, there’s a trophy icon with a  prompt. Press  to view the Pokédex rewards.
For reaching certain completion milestones, you’ll get some useful and rare items sent straight to your bag.

chapterContent.head: List of Milestone Rewards

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Get The Mirror Herb

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining the Mirror Herb which is an item you can use to improve your Pokemon’s Stats or Transfer Moves in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: How to Get Mirror Herb

chapterContent.content: You can purchase a Mirror Herb from the Delibird Presents Shop in Cascarrafa for 30,000 Poke Dollars. However, as you may of noticed 30,000 isn’t cheap, but there are some things you can do to get lots of money quickly, such as Selling Item, Fighting Trainers. If you would like more in-depth information on how to farm Pokem Dollars, then refer to this page: Fastest Way to Make Money in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.head: What Are Mirror Herbs

chapterContent.content: Mirror Herbs are a single use item which has many uses, such as copying opponents stats or transferring Pokemon Moves. If you have a Mirror Herb, then you can give it your Pokemon to hold and it’ll copy the opponents stats in battle.

Alternatively, you can use the Mirror Herb for transferring Moves from one Pokemon to another. In order to do this you’ll have to make sure you only have two Pokemon in your team, then remove one of the moves from the pokemon you wish to put the new move on, so it has one spot free. Once you’ve done that you’ll want to participate in a picnic and the move will automatically be transferred.

Transferring Moves is an excellent way of creating powerful moves which can make completing Tera Raids a lot easier. For example, putting Belly Drum on Azumarill will allow it to increase its attack by 6 stages which will allow you to easily defeat the 5-6 Star Raids.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Get The Shell Bell

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining the Shell Bell which is an item you can use to restore health in battle in Pokemon’s Strength in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: How to Get Shell Bell

chapterContent.content: You can purchase a Shell Bell from the Delibird Presents Shop in Levincia for 20,000 Poke Dollars. However, as you may have noticed 20,000 isn’t cheap, but there are some things you can do to get lots of money quickly, such as Selling Item, Fighting Trainers.

If you would like more in-depth information on how to farm Poke Dollars, then refer to this page: Fastest Way to Make Money in Pokemon Scarlet & Violet. Alternatively, you can defeat 6 Trainers in South Province (Area Three) and then speak with the Pokemon League Rep and he’ll reward you with it.

chapterContent.head: What Does The Shell Bell Do

chapterContent.content: The description of the Shell Bell is “An item to be held by a Pokemon. The holder restores a little HP to itself every time it inflicts damage with an attack”, so basically if the Pokemon that you have holding the item successfully damages the opposition, then you’ll get a little bit of health returned to you which makes it a great item to prevent you from having to waste turns on using Potions.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Get the Master Ball in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining the Master Ball in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: What is the Master Ball?

chapterContent.content: For those new to Pokémon, the Master Ball is the ultimate Poké Ball, with a 100% chance of catching any wild Pokémon. Typically, there is only one Master Ball in the game and you get it very late.

chapterContent.head: Master Ball Location

chapterContent.content: You can obtain the Master Ball in Scarlet & Violet after completing the Area Zero story (when the credits roll), as soon as the postgame begins.

The next day, you’ll be promoted to visit the Director’s Office in Naranja/Uva Academy. You can skip this and leave the academy. However, if you visit the Director’s Office (by using any of the turnstiles at the Entrance Hall), you’ll witness the aftermath of the story and receive a Master Ball as a reward!

chapterContent.aside: At the time of writing, there is no other way to obtain additional Master Balls.

chapterContent.head: Best Use for the Master Ball

chapterContent.content: It depends on your play style, but the Master Ball is best used for:

chapterContent.li: Extremely hard-to-catch Pokémon. So perhaps one of the Treasures of Ruin or the other Koraidon or Miraidon at Area Zero.
Emergencies. Such as a chance shiny Pokémon that you didn’t prepare for. It could be that they know Self-Destruct or Explosion and you don’t have a Golduck with Damp to stop it.

chapterContent.content: Or if you’re like us, it’ll probably just stay in your bag forever!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Get the Beast Ball in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining the Beast Ball in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: What is the Beast Ball?

chapterContent.content: The Beast Ball is a high-tech Poké Ball introduced in Pokémon Sun & Moon whose main purpose is capturing the Ultra Beasts. When used on an Ultra Beast, it provides the best chance of catching them. However, when used on regular Pokémon, they have an extremely low success rate.

chapterContent.head: Beast Ball Location

chapterContent.content: If you want your hands on a Beast Ball, you’ve got your work cut out for you! It’s a reward from the Pokédex app for obtaining 400 volumes. This means catching/obtaining all 400 Pokémon in the Paldea Pokédex!

If you haven’t obtained any rewards from the Pokédex app before, open your Rotom Phone by pressing  on the field. Select the main Pokédex along the top, to view the entire Pokédex. Now press  to view and claim your rewards.

chapterContent.aside: At the time of writing, there is no other way to obtain additional Beast Balls.

chapterContent.head: Best Use for the Beast Ball

chapterContent.content: To cut to the chase, there are no Ultra Beasts in Scarlet & Violet; you’re not supposed to use the Beast Ball for capturing Ultra Beasts in this game.
Instead, the Beast Ball mainly serves as a cosmetic Poké Ball. In other words, you can use it to catch an extra-special Pokémon, then marvel at or brag about its fancy Beast Ball.
Unlike the other cosmetic balls, the Beast Ball has an atrocious catch rate. So you may need to soft-reset and try again many, many times…
If you don’t care about cosmetics, you could just keep it as a trophy for your hard work. Or maybe offer it as a trade with somebody who does care.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Get a Choice Band in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining a Choice Band in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: What is a Choice Band?

chapterContent.content: Choice Band is a recurring hold item that’s extremely popular among competitive players. It boosts the Pokémon’s Attack by 50%, but the Pokémon will be locked into the first move they use until they leave the field (eg. when they switch out).

It’s great for powerhouse Pokémon with a really high Attack stat to begin with, enabling them to one-shot more Pokémon. However, you must be careful when using it, because you’ll be stuck using the same move. Also, you cannot run status moves–well, you could, but it’d be terrible.

chapterContent.head: Choice Band Location

chapterContent.content: Obtaining a Choice Band is pretty simple. You need to visit the Mesagoza branch of Delibird Presents and buy it for the princely sum of 100,000 Poké Dollars.

chapterContent.aside: You must be in the postgame to see the updated stock!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Get a Covert Cloak in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for obtaining a Covert Cloak in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: What is a Covert Cloak

chapterContent.content: Covert Cloak is a new hold item with a powerful effect: it prevents the secondary effects of the opponent’s moves from affecting your Pokémon.

This hold item functions a bit like the Sheer Force ability in reverse. It can negate status ailments from moves like Nuzzle, Flamethrower, Ice Beam, etc. Plus trapping effects from Fire Spin, Sand Tomb, etc. Furthermore, it prevents flinching from moves like Fake Out and Rock Slide!
However, it doesn’t work for primary effects. So moves like Thunder Wave will still Paralyze and Confuse Ray will still cause confusion, since that’s their main purpose.

chapterContent.head: Covert Cloak Location

chapterContent.content: You can find a Covert Cloak in the snow town of Montenevera. Search the tree behind the Sushi High Roller restaurant for an item ball containing a Covert Cloak!

If you need another Covert Cloak or don’t want to trek up the mountains, you can also buy one from the Levincia branch of Delibird Presents. It’ll cost you 20,000 Poké Dollars. Might be a little steep near the beginning, so don’t fret if you can’t afford it.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: All Paradox Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for the new Paradox Pokémon in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet that covers version differences and what they actually are.

chapterContent.head: What are Paradox Pokémon?

chapterContent.content: Paradox Pokémon are mysterious creatures that resemble existing Pokémon, depicted in the Scarlet Book or Violet Book. Paradox Pokémon in Pokémon Scarlet are ancient-themed, while Paradox Pokémon in Pokémon Violet are futuristic-themed.

Although Paradox Pokémon are based on existing Pokémon, they are completely unconnected to those Pokémon. For example, Paradox Donphan is a separate entity; it does not evolve from Phanpy or a normal Donphan.

chapterContent.head: All Paradox Pokémon in Scarlet

chapterContent.aside: All of the Pokémon featured below have the Protosynthesis ability.

chapterContent.content: Great Tusk looks like a Donphan with massive tusks, hence its name. It is a  and  type. Its Attack and Defense are high, but its special-based stats are poor.
Brute Bonnet looks like an Amoonguss that’s well past its expiry date. It is a  and  type. It has high Attack and decent defensive stats, but is slow.
Sandy Shocks looks like a Magneton walking on stilts. It is an  and  type. It has high Special Attack and otherwise OK to good stats.

We kind of want to scream after seeing this monstrosity of a Jigglypuff. Let’s distract ourselves by checking its type:  and . Nope, maybe studying its stats will help? It has good defensive stats and Speed. That’s enough, we’re out of here!
Flutter Mane looks like a Misdreavus who’s decided to let loose. It’s a  and  type. In exchange for poor HP and physical stats, it has excellent special-based stats and Speed.
Slither Wing resembles a Volcarona whose wings haven’t developed yet. It’s a  and  type. It boasts impressive Attack and otherwise decent to good stats.
Roaring Moon looks a bit like a wilder version of Mega Salamence if you blur your eyes. It’s a  and  type. It has high Attack and good Speed, but poor Special Attack.

chapterContent.head: All Paradox Pokémon in Violet

chapterContent.aside: All of the Pokémon featured below have the Quark Drive ability.

chapterContent.content: Iron Treads looks like a robotic version of Donphan. It’s a  and  type. It has good physical stats, although lower than Great Tusk, but its Speed is higher.
Iron Moth looks like Volcarona if it was a robot. It’s a  and  type. It has excellent Special Attack, but poor HP and Defense.
Iron Hands resembles a Hariyama, but fully encased in metal. It’s a  and  type. It boasts excellent HP and Attack, but poor special-based stats and Speed.
Iron Jugulis is basically a mecha version of Hydreigon. It’s a  and  type. Stat-wise, it has great Special Attack and good Speed; everything else is average.
Iron Thorns looks like Tyranitar, but… y’know, a robot. It’s a  and  type. It has high Attack and good HP and Defense; everything else is so-so.

Iron Bundle is a cute robot version of Delibird. We wouldn’t mind being visited by one of these contraptions during Christmas. Provided they’re not hiding any lasers or chainsaws, etc. Anyway, it’s an  and  type. It boasts superior Speed and high Defense and Special Attack. But its low HP and Special Defense let it down.
Iron Valiant is essentially Gallade reimagined as a robot. It’s a  and  type. Has excellent Attack, Special Attack and decent Speed. Its weakness is its low Special Defense.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Where to Find All Gimmighoul Chests

chapterContent.content: Due to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet being a true open world Pokémon experience, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every Gimmighoul Chests.

chapterContent.head: What are Gimmighouls?

chapterContent.content: Gimmighoul Chests, and you’ll often find them situated at the top of Watchtowers or other well-hidden parts of Paldea. These are easy to identify, as they look like a typical chest that wouldn’t look out of place in a Final Fantasy or Dragon Quest. Once you find one, interact with it and you’ll be thrust into battle against a Gimmighoul Chest.

chapterContent.aside: Note that you can catch Gimmighoul Chests, so try to catch the first one you come across if at all possible as they’re not overly difficult to deal with.

chapterContent.content: More importantly, once you defeat a Gimmighoul Chest, you’ll be awarded between 50-60 Gimmighoul Coins! This will make your life a lot easier when trying to farm the 999+ needed for evolution. If you would like more information on Gimmighouls, then refer to this page: What are Gimmighouls?.

chapterContent.head: What are Gimmighoul Coins Used For?

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve found and caught a Gimmighoul, you may wish to know how you go about evolving it into Goldengo. The bad news is, this is not a quick procedure and will involve scouring all of Paldea. To evolve a Gimmighoul into Gholdengo, you’ll need to first go out into the world and accumulate 999+ Gimmighoul Coins which are obtained from Roaming Gimmighouls and Gimmighoul Chests found throughout the region. If you would like more information on how to evolve Gimmighouls, then refer to this How to Catch and Evolve Gimmighoul into Gholdengo

chapterContent.head: All Gimmighoul Chest Location

chapterContent.aside: We’ve come across 20 Gimmighoul Chests so far, but if we find anymore then we’ll update this page with their location!

chapterContent.content: Head to the Los Platos (East) Pokemon Center and follow the path south to find the Gimmighoul Chest sitting up on the cliff to the left just before you reach Poco Path Lighthouse.

Head to the South Province (Area Two) Pokemon Center and sprint south until you reach South Province Area 4, then climb up the watchtower in the center of the area to find the Gimmighoul Chest sitting on top.

Head to the South Province (Area Two) Watchtower then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest. If you haven’t found the watchtower yet, then you can reach by heading north from the South Province (Area Two) Pokemon Center.
Head to the South Province (Area Five) Watchtower then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the South Province (Area Three) Watchtower then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the East Province (Area Two) Pokemon Center and walk northwest and climb up onto the cliff to find the Gimmighoul Chest sitting at the edge.
Head to the East Province (Area Two) Pokemon Center and follow the path along to the east until you reach the Watchtower, then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the East Province (Area Three) Watchtower, then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the Fury Falls Watchtower and follow the path southwest until you reach a small lake, then you’ll find the Gimmighoul Chest in the center.
Head to the North Province (Area Two) Pokemon Center and make your way northwest until you reach the Ruins. Here you’ll find the Gimmighoul Chest in the corner.
Head to the North Province (Area One) Watchtower then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the Glaseado Mountain Watchtower then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the Casseroya Watchtower No.2 then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the Casseroya Watchtower No.2 then travel southwest until you reach ruins. Here you’ll find the Gimmighoul Chest sitting on a wall.
Head to the Casseroya Watchtower No. 1 then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center and sprint northwest through the desert until you come across a Ruins. Here you’ll find the Gimmighoul Chest sitting on a wall.

Head to the Asado Desert Watchtower and then either glide or swim over to the island in the distance to find the Gimmighoul Chest. If you haven’t unlocked these Travel Abilities, then you’ll need to defeat Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan or Great Tusk, the Quaking Earth Titan.
Head to the Casseroya Watchtower No.3 then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the Glaseado Mountain Pokemon Center and head east, then climb up to the top of the waterfall to find the Gimmighoul Chest.
Head to the West Province Area 1 Watchtower then climb up to the top to find the Gimmighoul Chest.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Find All 4 Paldean Legendaries

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about finding and catching the four Paldean Legendaries in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. These are part of the Black Stake quest that can be found all over Paldea.

chapterContent.head: What are the Ruinous Legendary Pokémon?

chapterContent.content: As with all Pokémon games, Legendary hunting is one of the most exciting activities you can undertake. Pokémon Scarlet and Violet are no different there, and there are four Legendary Pokémon you can work on as soon as you gain full access to the open world.

Each of the four Legendary Pokémon are known as Ruin Pokémon in the Pokédex and appears to have ties to Chinese myths. All four are Level 60, and have dual Types, all of which are Dark, and then an additional one. You can find out more in the table below.

Each of the four Legendary Pokémon also have an exclusive move which fits the theme as Ruinous Pokémon. Ting-Lu’s Vessel of Ruin lowers the Sp. Attack of all Pokémon other than itself. Chien-Pao’s Sword of Ruin is the same but for Defense, Chi-Yu’s Beads of Ruin impacts the Sp. Defense stat, and Wo-Chien’s Tablets of Ruin affects Attack.

chapterContent.head: When Can you Fight the Paldea Legendary Pokémon?

chapterContent.content: Unlike past Pokémon games, where you usually have to defeat the Elite Four before going on the Legendary hunt but that is not the case here. You can start finding the Black Stakes as soon as you can explore the world (although you will need a few travel abilities for some of them).

You can even catch them at this point too, although you may wish to wait on when you can purchase Ultra Balls as it will be a painful experience trying to catch one with a Great Ball (as we learned the hard way). If you’re lower level and wish to attempt to catch one, you can try and Poison them (which all are susceptible to) and then try and toss Ultra Balls while you look to survive (we caught Chi-Yu with a Level 33 Arcanine ).

chapterContent.head: Paldea Legendary Pokémon Locations

chapterContent.content: As mentioned above, all four of these Ruinous Legendary Pokémon are part of the Black Stake quest which has no indicators. You will find four Shrines in the corners of Paldea, each with their own color and you must remove eight stakes of the same color to break the seal. Once broken, you can examine the seal and a battle with respective Pokémon will begin.
If you wish to track down every stake, look no further than our pages below:

chapterContent.li: All Orange Stake Locations
All Green Stake Locations
All Blue Stake Locations
All Purple Stake Locations

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Catch Rotom and Change Its Form

chapterContent.content: This page explains where you can catch Rotom and change its form in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
Rotom is a rather unique Pokémon. Normally it’s an Electric  and Ghost  type, but by using a certain item, you can drastically change its form and type.

chapterContent.head: Rotom Location

chapterContent.content: You can find Rotom in Scarlet & Violet in the vicinity of Porto Marinada and Levincia, located at the far west and far west of Paldea, respectively.

Rotom are a rare spawn, so you might not see them initially. Feel free to pop in and out to refresh the spawns. When Rotom spawns, it’s kind of small, but easy to notice thanks to its erratic movement pattern.
After spotting Rotom, there’s a decent chance it’s floating slightly where you can reach. Hold  to target it, then press  to throw a Poké Ball to trigger a fight.
Since Rotom is a Ghost  type, you can’t use False Swipe to safely lower its HP. Also, since it’s Electric , you cannot paralyze it either.

Your best bet is to battle it with a Pokémon of a similar Level and stick with weak moves like Ember. If Rotom is breaking out of your balls, consider sending it to sleep with moves like Hypnosis or Yawn.

chapterContent.head: How to Change Rotom’s Form

chapterContent.content: Rotom is pretty neat, but its true potential won’t be realized until you change its form. Once you have a Rotom, make your way to the main market building in Porto Marinada.
If you completed the Water Gym, you should be familiar with this place. Look for the auctioneers near the east side of the building.
There should be a new auctioneer peddling a Rotom Catalog. The starting bid is 500 Poke Dollars and the winning bid is around 4,000 Poké Dollars.

chapterContent.aside: If you own certain Mythical Pokémon, the auctioneer may offer other items, before the Rotom Catalog.

chapterContent.content: After securing the Rotom Catalog, you can select it from the Key Items tab of your Bag. This will let you choose from multiple appliances. After choosing the alliance, select a Rotom in your party to change its form to match the appliance.
After Rotom changes type, it will learn a new move of that type. For example, Wash Rotom will learn Hydro Pump.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Catch and Evolve Gimmighoul into Gholdengo

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about catching the Gimmighoul Chest in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. These are hidden throughout Paldea and are required for completing the Pokédex.
Gimmighoul is a new Pokémon to the Pokédex and is a Ghost  Type.

chapterContent.head: Best Places to Catch Gimmighoul Chest

chapterContent.content: By now, you’ve probably encountered a lot of Gimmighouls in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet and may be wondering how you go about adding them to your Pokédex. Well, the bad news is, you can’t catch the Roaming form of Gimmighoul just yet. You can, however, catch the Chest form of Gimmighoul!

What makes this tougher is that you need to seek out the Gimmighoul Chests that are hidden throughout the world. The easiest way of doing it is by seeking out the Watchtowers that are scattered around Paldea as most of them are guaranteed to have a Gimmighoul Chest at the top. The Watchtowers in South Province (Area Two) and (Area Three) are good choices early in the game, as the battle against the Gimmighoul Chest will only be Level 10.

chapterContent.head: How to Evolve into Gholdengo

chapterContent.content: Now that you have your Gimmighoul, you may wish to know how you go about evolving it into Goldengo. The bad news is, this is not a quick procedure and will involve scouring all of Paldea.

To evolve into Gholdengo, you’ll need to first go out into the world and accumulate 999+ Gimmighoul Coins! These are obtained from the Roaming Gimmighouls and Gimmighoul Chests found throughout the region.

As you can see, you’ll want to make a concentrated effort to seek out all of the Gimmighoul Chests as they will give you between 50-60 Gimmighoul Coins and make this step much much quicker. Unfortunately, as of right now, we’ve come across no way to respawn the Chests, but we’ll update you as soon as we discover more.
As mentioned above, the best place to find these Gimmighoul Chests are around the various Watchtowers but there are some that are hidden in the rest of the world too.

Alternatively, you can also add to your collection by interacting with the Roaming Gimmighoul that are much more numerous in Paldea. You’ll only get one-four Coins per each, but they add up quickly as you’ll come across plenty of them through general exploration. Typically, you’ll always find Roaming Gimmighouls in areas such as ruins (often multiple Roaming Gimmighouls at once) and on the top of signposts.

Once you’ve accrued 999+ Gimmighoul Coins, the final step is a simple one. You need to Level Up Gimmighoul to trigger an evolution, at which point your Gimmighoul will evolve into Gholdengo, congratulations!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Evolve Bramblin Into Brambleghast

chapterContent.content: There are some strange ways to evolve Pokemon in the games, and Pokemon Scarlet and Pokemon Violet add on to this trend. You can’t just level up your team and expect them to evolve into stronger forms. You have to do a bit of detective work to learn how each one evolves. In fact, even some of the most simple-looking Pokemon have special evolutions, like Bramblin. If you have been trying to get Brambleghast then keep reading our guide below, as the Pokemon will only evolve after meeting specific conditions.

chapterContent.head: Where to Get Bramblin

chapterContent.content: If you haven’t yet caught yourself a Bramblin then head to East Zone Three, right above Iono’s Electric-type gym. These tumbleweeds are rolling around all over the place and are generally pretty easy to capture. They are a grass/ghost-type Pokemon, and if you’re lucky, they will come with a host of great moves like Bullet Seed, Mega Drain, and Hex.

chapterContent.head: How to Evolve Bramblin into Brambleghast

chapterContent.content: Once you have your Bramblin, you can start working on evolving them immediately. There is no level requirement to evolve Bramblin, instead, you need to worry about walking it. You will need to use the Let’s Go feature to let Bramblin walk alongside you for 1,000 steps.

While this may seem like a lot, it actually doesn’t take all that long to hit your goal. Some things that you need to keep in mind are that Bramblin will need to be in your first slot. If you try to ride around, Bramblin will end up getting put up as it can’t keep up with you. You will need to actually walk, with short stops along the way, to evolve this Pokemon. You also should note that it will fight any nearby Pokemon, so it’s best to run around in a town.

Just about any town will do as a Bramblin walking zone. If you walk non-stop, it should take about 5 to 10 minutes for Bramblin to get in enough steps. Once this is done, simply** level him up** using candy or in battle, and he will evolve into Brambleghast.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Evolve Greavard Into Houndstone

chapterContent.content: While many Pokemon will level up just by going through battles, some have special circumstances that need to occur in order for them to evolve. Pokemon Scarlet and Pokemon Violet have added in several new Pokemon that have evolution tricks like having to walk a certain number of steps. The adorable Greavard, which was teased before the game’s release, has an evolution that only occurs under special circumstances. Below we go over where to find your very own Greavard and how to evolve it into Houndstone.

chapterContent.head: Where to Catch Greavard

chapterContent.content: You will need to make it quite a ways into the game before being able to catch and command Greavard. The Ghost-type Pokemon is only found in the northern region of the map in North Area 3. Pokemon in this area are in their high 30s, so they won’t obey you until you have five gym badges. Luckily, Greavard is a rather common spawn, especially on your way to Montenevera. Just look for the little candles sticking out of the ground and approach them to find Greavard.

chapterContent.head: How to Evolve Greavard Into Houndstone

chapterContent.content: Since you will likely catch your first Greavard in the high 30s, you don’t have to do much work to get it to evolve. There are two requirements to get Houndstone, the first is the Greavard is at least level 30, and the second is that it levels up at night. The in-game clock takes around 35 minutes to cycle around, so keep busy until you see the time of day change from evening to night. At this point, simply go on a battling spree or use some candies to level up your Greavard so that it will evolve into Houndstone.
There is also the option to go out and catch a Houndstone, but it’s a rare spawn that is a little less happy with the thought of being placed inside a Pokeball.

You can find Houndstone around the same area where you found Greavard in North Area 3. You will usually find it around a bunch of Greavards, and it will be in its 40’s. Exercise caution when fighting this Pokemon as it may have the move Last Respects, which becomes more powerful with each Pokemon that has fainted on your team.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Evolve Charcadet into Ceruledge or Armarouge

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about catching a Charcadet in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. These are hidden throughout Paldea and are required for completing the Pokédex.
Charcadet is a new Pokémon to the Pokédex and is a Fire  Type

chapterContent.head: Where to Catch Charcadet

chapterContent.content: If you haven’t yet caught yourself a Charcadet, then there’s a few locations where you can find one. Head to West Province Area 1 and you’ll find it roaming around to the east of the Flying Titan Bombirdier (Level 19). Alternatively, if you would like to catch a little earlier in the game, then make a visit over to South Province Area 2 and you can find it hiding over to the northwest of the South Province Area 3 Pokemon Center.

Charcadet is extremely weak to Water , Rock  and Ground  and will take 2x damage from them, so you want to use those Pokemon Types which are slightly above its level to lower its health before attempting to catch it. If you picked Quaxly, then that’ll be great candidates here. Additionally, there isn’t a level requirement for when you can evolve Charcadet, so feel free to do it once you have the required item.

chapterContent.head: How to Evolve Charcadet into Ceruledge or Armarouge

chapterContent.content: Charcadet evolution will change depending on the version of Pokemon Scarlet or Violet. If you chose Scarlet then Charcadet will evolve into Armarouge which is a Fire  and Psychic  Type. If you chose Violet then Charcadet will evolve into Ceruledge which is a Fire  and Ghost  Type.

In order to evolve your Charcadet you’ll need to give items to a man in Zapapico which is located in East Province Area 3. For those with the Scarlet Version you’ll need to trade him 10 Bronzor Fragments for the Auspicious Armor and for those with Violet you’ll need to trade 10 Sinistea Chips for the Malicious Armor. Once you have the item, use it on your Charcadet to evolve it.

However you may be wondering how you obtain Sinistea Chips or Broznor Fragments. You’ll have a better chance of obtaining these items by defeating Bronzor and Sinistea. Brozor can be found around the Asado Desert Ruins or in East Province Area Two and Sinistea can be found east of Zapapico or east of Alfornado.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Evolve Sinistea into Polteageist

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about catching and evolving Sinistea into Polteageist in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. You will need to seek out special items to get the evolution to take place.

chapterContent.head: Best Places to Catch Sinistea

chapterContent.content: Before you can get the process started, you’ll need to begin by tracking down a Sinistea and catching one. There are two prime locations when it comes to tracking down a Sinistea, with their Levels varying based on the area you catch it.

The first is by heading, to Zapapico in East Province (Area Three), the Sinistea out here will be around Level 28. Alternatively, you can head just outside Alfornada in South Province (Area Six) to find Sinistea that are around Level 41.

Knowing the locations of Sinistea is also useful for those of you who are looking to evolve Charcadet where you’ll need to farm Sinisteas for 10 Sinister Chips that you’ll need for your trade for the Malicious Armor.

chapterContent.head: Evolving Sinistea into Polteageist

chapterContent.content: So now you have your Sinistea finally, you may be wondering how you evolve this lovable teacup into Polteageist, and here is where it gets a bit complicated. Despite there being no difference in terms of stats and moves, there are actually two forms of Sinistea (although you only need one form for your Pokedex).

The most common form of Sinistea is the regular form, and you’ll need a Cracked Pot to evolve it from your inventory. If this doesn’t work, that means you’ve managed to catch an Antique Form Sinistea, at which point you’ll need a Chipped Pot to be able to evolve it.

How can you tell which Form you have? Beyond checking if the Cracked Pot works or not, the only other way to tell which form of Sinistea you have is by using the Let’s Go! feature and looking on the underside of it, the Antique Form will have a blue circle which appears to hint towards its authenticity.

chapterContent.aside: If you’re determined to get a Sinistea in its Antique form, be prepared to farm a lot of Sinistea as it’s very rare.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Cracked Pots and Chipped Pots

chapterContent.content: So now it’s time to actually track down the pots you need to evolve your Sinistea into Polteageist. You’ll need to progress Victory Road to the point where you’ve undertook and completed the Water Gym Test where you’ll need to win an item at the auctions held there.

Once you’re done with this part of Victory Road, you can return to Port Marinada and the Auction to bid on certain items, of which the stock will change after a few hours. Both the Chipped Pot and the Cracked Pot can appear here as items, so if you’re in a hurry, you can look to advance the internal clock on your Switch. Otherwise, return here from time-to-time to see if either are available although expect to spend around 15,000+ poke dollars for either of the items.
Alternatively, you can find a Chipped Pot out in the wild. Head along the winding path east of Port Marinada and check near a large tree to find a Chipped Pot sitting there.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Evolve Varoom into Revavroom

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about catching a Varoom in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. These are hidden throughout Paldea and are required for completing the Pokédex.
Varoom is a new Pokémon to the Pokédex and is a Steel  & Poison  Type.

chapterContent.head: Where to Catch Varoom

chapterContent.content: If you haven’t yet caught yourself a Varoom, then there’s a few locations where you can find one. You’ll most likely have a better chance of catching one in North Province Area One and you’ll find roaming about to the north of the area. You can reach it by heading north from the North Province (Area One) Pokemon Center.

Varoom is extremely weak to Fire  and Ground  Type Pokemon and will take 2x damage from them, so you want to use those Pokemon Types which are slightly above its level to lower its health before attempting to catch it. If you picked Fuecoco, then that’ll be great candidates here.

chapterContent.head: How to Evolve Varoom into Revavroom

chapterContent.content: In order to evolve Varoom into Revaroom you’ll need to get it up to Level 40 which can be done via a variety of methods. Defeating Trainers that are at a slightly higher level throughout the Paldea region. If you are struggling to locate them, then refer to our map, as we have their locations for all areas in the game! You can also catch or defeat Pokemon which are a slightly higher level then you for large chunks of EXP.

Alternatively, you can complete Tera Raids, as this will reward you with Exp. Candy that you can use to level your Varoom. However, you wont get your hands on the Exp. Candy M until you tackle the 3 star raids. Whilst you’re trying to level your Pokemon you may want to consider giving it an item to hold, such as the Lucky Egg as this will cause them to earn more EXP after battles.

Finally, you can eat Sandwiches which have the Exp. Point Power buff on it to allow you Pokemon to get more exp from defeating Pokemon of that specific type. You can find all the available Sandwiches in the game via this page: Every Sandwich Recipe in Scarlet & Violet.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How To Evolve Finizen Into Palafin

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about catching a Finizen in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. These are hidden throughout Paldea and are required for completing the Pokédex.
Finizen is a new Pokémon to the Pokédex and is a Water  Type

chapterContent.head: Where to Catch Finizen

chapterContent.content: If you haven’t yet caught yourself a Finizen, then there’s a few locations where you can find one. Finizen can be found in the North, East and Paldean Sea. The quickest way of reaching it is by fast traveling over to either the Porto Marinada Pokemon Center or Levincia Pokemon Center and then heading out into ocean to find them nearby. However, you’ll need to access to the swim travel ability which is acquired from defeating Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan.

Finizen is extremely weak to Electric  and Grass  and will take 2x damage from them, so you want to use those Pokemon Types which are slightly above its level to lower its health before attempting to catch it. If you picked Sprigatito, then that’ll be great candidates here.

chapterContent.head: How To Evolve Finizen Into Palafin

chapterContent.content: The requirement for evolving Finizen Into Palafin is to get it up to Level 38 whilst playing with friends. In order to play with friends you’ll want to visit any Pokemon Center and stand in the yellow circle and create a Union Circle, then invite them. As for the leveling side you can defeat Trainers that are at a slightly higher level throughout the Paldea region. If you are struggling to locate them, then refer to our map, as we have their locations for all areas in the game! You can also catch or defeat Pokemon which are a slightly higher level then you for large chunks of EXP.

Alternatively, you can complete Tera Raids, as this will reward you with Exp. Candy that you can use to level your Finizen. However, you wont get your hands on the Exp. Candy M until you tackle the 3 star raids. Whilst you’re trying to level your Pokemon you may want to consider giving it an item to hold, such as the “Lucky Egg” as this will cause them to earn more EXP after battles.

Finally, you can eat Sandwiches which have the Exp. Point Power buff on it to allow you Pokemon to get more exp from defeating Pokemon of that specific type. You can find all the available Sandwiches in the game via this page: Every Sandwich Recipe in Scarlet & Violet.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How To Evolve Girafarig Into Farigiraf

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about catching and evolving Girafarig in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. These are hidden throughout Paldea and are required for completing the Pokédex.
Girafarig is a Normal and Psychic  Pokemon

chapterContent.head: Where to Catch Girafarig

chapterContent.content: If you haven’t yet caught yourself a Girafarig, then there’s a few locations where you can find one. You’ll most likely have a better chance of catching one in West Province Area 2 and you can find it roaming around the southwest of the area. You can reach it quickly by fast traveling to the Porto Marinada Pokémon Center.

Girafarigi is extremely weak to Bug  and Dark  and will take 2x damage from them, so you want to use those Pokemon Types which are slightly above its level to lower its health before attempting to catch it.

chapterContent.head: How To Evolve Girafarig Into Farigiraf

chapterContent.content: The requirement for evolving Girafarig Into Farigiraf is to get it up to Level 32 which can be done via a variety of methods. Defeating Trainers that are at a slightly higher level throughout the Paldea region. If you are struggling to locate them, then refer to our map, as we have their locations for all areas in the game! You can also catch or defeat Pokemon which are a slightly higher level then you for large chunks of EXP.

Alternatively, you can complete Tera Raids, as this will reward you with Exp. Candy that you can use to level your Varoom. However, you wont get your hands on the Exp. Candy M until you tackle the 3 star raids. Whilst you’re trying to level your Pokemon you may want to consider giving it an item to hold, such as the Lucky Egg as this will cause them to earn more EXP after battles.

You can also eat Sandwiches which have the Exp. Point Power buff on it to allow you Pokemon to get more exp from defeating Pokemon of that specific type. You can find all the available Sandwiches in the game via this page: Every Sandwich Recipe in Scarlet & Violet. Finally once your Girafarig has reached 32, use the attack Twin Beam once its been learnt, then when you use the attack your Girafarig will evolve.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Evolve Bisharp into Kingambit

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to catch Bisharp and evolve it into Kingambit in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
Kingambit is one of the newly added Pokémon that evolves from an existing Pokémon. However, it has one of the trickiest methods of evolving.

chapterContent.head: Where to Catch Bisharp

chapterContent.content: First, you’ll need a Bisharp. You can evolve one yourself from a Pawniard, but if you haven’t, they’re relatively common in the bamboo forest in North Province (Area Two). That area is right outside the Pokémon Center near the Fairy Crew’s base.

The Bisharp here are over Level 50, so your Pokémon should be a similar level, unless you’re feeling very brave! In any case, it’s a Dark  and Steel  type. So avoid using Fighting moves, as they’re liable to KO it.

To make things easier, you should apply Paralyze or Sleep, with moves like Nuzzle, Yawn, etc. False Swipe is a bit painful to use since Bisharp resists it. So you may prefer to weaken it with low damage moves instead, like Water Gun etc.

chapterContent.head: How to Evolve Bisharp into Kingambit

chapterContent.content: After obtaining a Bisharp, we recommend teaching it a Fighting type move via TM. Brick Break is a solid choice. If you just caught it, obviously heal it up!

Now return to (or head to) the bamboo forest where Bisharp spawn. Keep running around until you find a Bisharp surrounded by a small group of Pawniard–it must be in a group, not a lone Bisharp! This Bisharp will be holding a Leader’s Crest item. Send out your own Bisharp to fight the Bisharp. Then use a Fighting type move to KO the opposing Bisharp.

Afterwards, repeat this two more times. Once you’ve defeated a total of 3 Bisharp leading a group of Pawniard, Level Up your Bisharp. This can be done by battling or using candies, but not by auto-battling with Let’s Go.

chapterContent.aside: You do not need to obtain a Leader’s Crest yourself or give it to your Bisharp. The requirement is to defeat an opposing Bisharp that’s holding one.

chapterContent.content: If you followed our instructions, your Bisharp will evolve into Kingambit. In doing so, it will learn its signature move, Kowtow Cleave, a strong Dark type move that never misses.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How To Evolve Chansey Into Blissey

chapterContent.content: This page explains everything you may wish to know about catching a Chansey and evolving it into Blissey in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. These are hidden throughout Paldea and are required for completing the Pokédex.
Chansey is a Normal  Type Pokemon.

chapterContent.head: How to Catch Chansey

chapterContent.content: If you haven’t yet caught yourself a Chansey , then there’s a few locations where you can find one. It can be found in the West Province Area Two/Three and North Province Area Two/Three. However, Chansey is a rare Pokemon, so you may need to do a little preparation before you can find it. Before you head out into the wild looking for Chansey, head to any Sandwich Shop which can be found throughout Paldea, then you’ll want to make any of the Sandwiches below, as they offer Encounter Power: Normal.

Once you’ve found Chansey you’ll want to use a Fighting  Type Pokemon and will take 2x damage from them, so you want to use those Pokemon Types which are slightly above its level to lower its health before attempting to catch it.

chapterContent.head: How To Evolve Chansey Into Blissey

chapterContent.content: In order to evolve Chansey Into Blissey you’ll need to increase its friendship level which can be done by keeping Chansey in your team and allowing it to run about via the Let’s Go Feature. Additionally, you can purchase a Soothe Bell from any Delibird Presents Shop and give it to Chansey to hold, as this will speed up the process.

You can check your Friendship level by speaking with the NPC in Cascarrafa. It has three categories: You two seem neutral – low friendship, I’m sure you could get way friendlier – middling friendship and You’re the best friends ever – high friendship. Once your Chansey’s Friendship is high enough it’ll automatically evolve when you next level it up.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: What are the Black Stakes?

chapterContent.content: Due to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet being a true open world Pokémon experience, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details about the ominous black stakes.

Paldea is a vast region, and many things lie undiscovered until now. Across the four corners of the region, you’ll come across Black Stakes stuck into the ground in one of four colors; blue, green, orange, and purple.
When you first interact with one, you’ll be given a choice of whether you wish to pull these out of the ground or not. There is no reason not to pull these out as these are part of a longer quest.

chapterContent.head: What do the Black Stakes do?

chapterContent.content: So you’ve found some black stakes stuck all over Paldea and the next question that comes to mind is just what do they do? The answer is simple, each of the four sets of Black Stakes unseal a shrine that houses one of the four Ruin Legendary Pokémon, all of which are Level 60.

You may think that you’ll need to wait until the post-game before taking on this quest, but the good news is you can do all of this long before that. Provided you can survive the battle, you can use Poison-based moves to try and poison your foe, then launch Ultra Balls to collect them. Just be wary as they are Level 60 Pokémon, they won’t obey you until you have all of the Gym Badges from completing the Victory Road Storyline.

chapterContent.head: Black Stake Locations

chapterContent.content: As mentioned above, there are four sets of 8 Stakes to locate in the world, only then will you be able to unseal the shrines. You can find these stakes in any order; you’re not forced to do one or the other. Still, it’s probably in your best interest to tackle one at a time so you can remember how many you’ve pulled out for each respective shrine as the game never divulges information on that (or anything related to this quest).

chapterContent.aside: You’ll know when you’ve found the final stake for a shrine as the game will display a message about something changing and your character will turn to face the direction of the shrine.

chapterContent.content: This will get you started in your hunt for all of the ominous Black Stakes. If you wish to know the location of everyone one, check out our dedicated pages below:

chapterContent.li: All Orange Stake Locations
All Green Stake Locations
All Blue Stake Locations
All Purple Stake Locations

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: All Orange Stake Locations

chapterContent.content: Due to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet being a true open world Pokémon experience, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every Orange Stake and the Shrine.

So you’ve come across a few Stakes in Paldea and have learnt what their use is. Now you wish to discover where you can find every Stake location and Shrine to tackle those Ruin Legendary Pokémon. Well, look no further as this page will show you where to find every Orange Stake.

chapterContent.head: Pokémon Scarlet and Violet Orange Stakes

chapterContent.content: Starting your search at the bottom of the Paldea region, head to South Province (Area Six) and head to this location on the map. You’ll find the stake nestled on the little lip of the large cliff overlooking the river.
Staying in South Province (Area Six), head along the clifftops northeast from Alfornada and you’ll find this stake high on a cliff ledge.

This Orange Stake is close to the previous one but can be tricky to find. Drop down to the ground around here and you’ll find a cave just to the west of the marker. Head inside and you’ll find the stake around the center of this tunnel.

Still in West Province (Area One), this next Stake location is back to the top of a cliff. Climb helps here as you can climb the nearest cliff and head north along it to reach the stake on a cliffside ledge.

Fast Travel to the Pokemon Center at West Province (Area One) - Central and head along the path leading north. Before the bridge, head west and look over the edge of the cliff to spot a crater. The stake can be found inside the crater on a little grass mound surrounded by a moat of water.
Head to the Watchtower in West Province (Area One) and you’ll find yourself at some ruins. Look to the east and you’ll find this stake on top of the grass ledge overlooking the nearby ruins.

This is probably the toughest stake to find, and once again it’s up on the cliffs again. Head east from the previous stake to this location on the map and look inside the nook between the cliffs near to where the Pokémon League is on the map.
The final orange stake is by far the easiest of the lot. Head to Cascarrafa and go to the outskirts of the town to the south, you’ll find the orange stake sitting by a tree.

chapterContent.head: Pokémon Scarlet and Violet Orange Shrine Gate

chapterContent.content: Once you pull up the eighth and final stake, a message will trigger, letting you know something has stirred and you will automatically face the direction of the shrine itself.

If you return to where you found Orange Stake #5 (the one in the crater), head northwest and you’ll find the Orange Shrine Gate along the edge of a cliff. Make sure you’re prepared before going in, however, a battle with Chien-Pao, a Level 60 Ruin Legendary Pokémon awaits.
For an in-depth guide for the Chien-Pao battle, please check our walkthrough here.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: All Green Stake Locations

chapterContent.content: Due to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet being a true open world Pokémon experience, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every Green Stake and the Shrine.

By now, you’ve probably come across a few Stakes in Paldea and have learnt what their use is. Now you wish to discover where you can find every Stake location and Shrine to tackle those Ruin Legendary Pokémon. Well, look no further as this page will show you where to find every Green Stake.

chapterContent.head: Green Stakes

chapterContent.content: Start your search for the green stakes by heading to the Porto Marinada in West Province (Area Two). Head east and you’ll find Colonnade Hollow, where you can find the first green stake underground on top of a pillar in the cave.
This is a simple stake to locate, as you head north from the previous stake, before you cross the bridge to Casseroya Lake, go east to find the stake out in the open.
Cross the bridge over to Casseroya Lake now and head to the far west of this stretch of land, you’ll find the stake on top of a small hill.

The next two stakes can be found on the islands within Casseroya Lake. Head to the south part of the lake and you’ll find two small islands close together, search the smaller of the two islands for the green stake here.
The second of the two lake stakes can be found on the larger islet in the center of Casseroya Lake. HEad to the eastern side of this island to find this green stake.
Leave Casseroya Lake for now and head to the far southeast where you’ll find this green stake behind a rock near the river close by.
Return to Casseroya Lake and cross over the lake to the land to the north. Head to the far west here and search on one of the mounds to find this green stake.
Take a look at your map and look over to the east, you’ll spot the part where Casseroya Lake leads into Glaseado Mountain. Head to the cliff here and you’ll find the final green stake.

chapterContent.head: Green Shrine Gate

chapterContent.content: Once you pull up the eighth and final stake, a message will trigger, letting you know something has stirred and you will automatically face the direction of the shrine itself.

The Green Shrine Gate is a simple one to find, look between the final two stakes and you’ll find some land with some water running around it, this leads directly to the Shrine. Make sure you’re prepared before going in, however, a battle with Ting-Lu, a Level 60 Ruin Legendary Pokémon awaits.
For an in-depth guide for the Ting-Lu battle, please check our walkthrough here.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: All Blue Stake Locations

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet is a true open world Pokémon experience, and with that comes plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every Blue Stake and the Shrine.

If you’ve been exploring every nook and cranny of the world, you’ve probably come across a few Stakes in Paldea and have learnt what their use is. Now you wish to discover where you can find every Stake location and Shrine to tackle those Ruin Legendary Pokémon. Well, look no further as this page will show you where to find every Blue Stake.

chapterContent.head: Blue Stakes

chapterContent.content: The first blue stake can be found by heading to the top of the plateau to the northwest of Levincia Lighthouse.
Return to the sight of where you took out the Poison Crew for Starfall Street and climb up the mountain path to the west to find this blue stake on the only bit of grass here.
Still in the Tagtree Thicket area, head to the northeast of this area to find the next blue stake on a higher elevation that overlooks the area, next to a tree.
Head east into North Province (Area Two) and you’ll find a waterfall, Fury Falls. Climb the waterfall and you’ll find some grass where the blue stake sits.

The next blue stake can be found in the ruins to the southeast of the last. If you’ve yet to defeat the Fighting Crew in Starfall Street, you’ll have to approach from the south as you’ll be taken out of the area if you haven’t. Once you reach the ruins, you’ll find the blue stake on the ground.
To find the next blue stake, head to the North Province (Area Two) Pokemon Center and then go up the cliff to the northeast to find the blue stake sitting near a tree.

Head for the North Province (Area One) Pokemon Center next and head north to find a large mound. You’ll need Climb or to Glide from a higher elevation to reach the ground up here, but when you do, you’ll find the blue stake out in the open.
For the final blue stake, head far to the northwest from the previous one to find a tree close to the border of Glaseado Mountain, the blue stake sits near a rock here.

chapterContent.head: Blue Shrine Gate

chapterContent.content: Once you pull up the eighth and final stake, a message will trigger, letting you know something has stirred and you will automatically face the direction of the shrine itself.

Return to Fury Falls (where blue stake #4 was) and climb up the waterfall to reach a small pool of water. Head inside the cave here and you’ll find the Shrine Gate. Make sure you’re prepared before going in, however, a battle with Chi-Yu, a Level 60 Ruin Legendary Pokémon awaits.
For an in-depth guide for the Chi-Yu battle, please check our walkthrough here.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: All Purple Stake Locations

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet is a true open world Pokémon experience, and as such, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every Purple Stake and the Shrine.

So you’ve come across a few Stakes in Paldea and have learnt what their use is. Now you wish to discover where you can find every Stake location and Shrine to tackle those Ruin Legendary Pokémon. Well, look no further as this page will show you where to find every Purple Stake.

chapterContent.head: Purple Stakes

chapterContent.content: Start your purple stake hunting at the Los Platos Pokemon Center and go southwest to the pool of water here, the purple stake sits overlooking the town.
The second purple stake is nearby, head northeast from Los Platos and climb up to find this purple stake overlooking Mesagoza city.
Another purple stake that is close by. Take a look at the map and you’ll spot a spiral hill to the northeast, climb to the top of this to locate the purple stake.

Make your way to the southwest of South Province (Area Five), or southeast from the last stake you got, and you’ll find some ruins. On the plateau to the east of here, overlooking them, you’ll find another purple stake.

The next purple stake is a simple one to find, head to the northeast of South Province (Area One) and you’ll find a bridge leading to South Province (Area Three), the purple stake sits above the bridge to the south.
Go to the South Province (Area Three) Pokemon Center and go west, along the top of the cliffs, to find the purple stake facing the city.
Once you’ve found the Watchtower in South Province (Area Three), head north and you’ll find some canyons. Go to the north side of these canyons and you’ll find the purple stake overlooking them.
The final purple stake is the easiest to locate. Simply head to Artazon and from the western Pokemon Center, go south and climb the wall to reach the stake.

chapterContent.head: Purple Shrine Gate

chapterContent.content: Once you pull up the eighth and final stake, a message will trigger, letting you know something has stirred and you will automatically face the direction of the shrine itself.

If you return to where you found Purple Stake #4 (that overlooks the ruins), drop off the cliff where the stake was and you’ll land right at the Shrine Gate. Make sure you’re prepared before going in, however, a battle with Wo-Chien, a Level 60 Ruin Legendary Pokémon awaits.
For an in-depth guide for the Wo-Chien battle, please check our walkthrough here.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Starting a New Game in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for starting a new game in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
The first time you start up the game, you’ll be presented with a choice of in-game language:

chapterContent.li: English
Spanish
French
German
Italian
Japanese
Korean
Simplified Chinese
Traditional Chinese

chapterContent.content: Obviously, you’ll probably want to pick the one you’re most familiar with.
Next, you can choose a look for your trainer character. The ones on the left are the masculine options, while the ones on the right are the feminine options.
After that, choose a nice name for yourself, like “GamerGuides”.

chapterContent.aside: You cannot change the in-game language or your name afterwards.

chapterContent.content: Afterwards, you’ll be taken to the confirmation screen, where you can begin the game straightaway by picking “Ready!” or you can customize your hairstyle and look further.
If you’re not in a rush, go ahead and mess with the hairstyle and look settings.

chapterContent.aside: You can change your hairstyle and look afterwards, but changing your hairstyle will cost money (not a problem later on, but may hurt your wallet near the start).

chapterContent.content: When you proceed, you’ll see your enrollment application for Naranja Academy (in Pokémon Scarlet) or Uva Academy (in Pokémon Violet).

chapterContent.aside: By default, auto-save will be enabled. When you see “Now saving…” near the top-left corner of the screen, don’t turn off the game or you may lose your progress!

chapterContent.content: Now enjoy the cutscenes! Welcome, Pokémon trainers, to the vast and wondrous Paldea region!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Cabo Poco - Choosing a Starter Pokémon

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for Cabo Poco in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. It covers choosing your starter Pokémon, as well as your first battle with Nemona, your rival.

chapterContent.head: Your House

chapterContent.content: You’ll begin the game proper inside your house at Cabo Poco, by the south coast of the Paldea region. Your character will be sitting at their desk reading. Unless you want to stay there forever, press any direction on the circle pad to move off the seat.

chapterContent.aside: Press  outside of battle to bring up the main menu.

chapterContent.content: When you’re ready, go down the stairs on the left. Near the bottom of the staircase, a little Skwovet will run into the room on the left. That’s your cue to follow it. Past the living room, you can find your Mom at the kitchen. As you’re talking, somebody will knock on the door.

Go back near the staircase to check the door. Lo and behold, the director of the academy, Clavell, has come to pay you a personal visit. Once you regain control, return upstairs and inspect your bag and hat near the corner of your bed. Go ahead and put them on!
Now go back downstairs, back into the living room. Clavell will ask you to follow him outside. Head towards the door yourself to leave the house.

chapterContent.head: Cabo Poco

chapterContent.content: Outside, Clavell will introduce you to the three starter Pokémon in the Paldea region.

chapterContent.li: Sprigatito, the Grass cat.
Fuecoco, the Fire crocodile.
Quaxly, the Water duck.

chapterContent.content: You’ll eventually choose one of these three, as your first companion. But before that, all three will briefly follow behind you, as you walk. And, oh boy, do you walk slowly. Your Mom will also hand you a Rotom Phone.

chapterContent.aside: Press  outside of battle to use your Rotom Phone. It will display a map of the Paldea region, which you can reference during your journey. By the way, we have a much more detailed map on our website!

chapterContent.content: To begin with, follow the path forward (east on your mini-map/map). Keep going until you approach a lady standing in the grass, just past a red signpost on the left side of the road. At this point, you can run by holding the circle pad all the way in one direction. Finally, that slow walking was driving us bonkers!

Continue in the same direction, up the white stairs ahead. At the top of the stairs, enjoy a cute little cutscene featuring the starter Pokémon. You’ll also meet a girl called Nemona who looks to be around your age.

chapterContent.head: Your First Pokémon

chapterContent.content: You can now choose one of the three starters to be your first Pokémon.
There is no right or wrong choice, so choose whichever tickles your fancy. Regardless of who you choose, you can build up a solid team of Pokémon.

chapterContent.aside: If you need advice though, please read our guide for picking a starter Pokémon.

chapterContent.content: After choosing your Pokémon, Nemona will choose one of the two remaining Pokémon. It will always be the one who’s weak to yours. Meanwhile, Clavell will take in the leftover Pokémon that neither of you chose. Poor thing.

Next, Nemona will request a Pokémon battle from you. Follow the path to the right of the building in front, towards the beach. At the beach, there’s a battle court where Pokémon trainers can battle against each other. Nemona will be standing in the center of the court. Speak to her to begin the battle.

chapterContent.head: Pokémon Trainer Nemona

chapterContent.content: As mentioned above, Nemona has the starter with a type disadvantage against yours. For an easy win, choose the non-Normal attack at the bottom.
This will be one of the following:

chapterContent.li: Leafage (Grass ) if you have Sprigagito
Ember (Fire ) if you have Fuecoco
Water Gun (Water ) if you have Quaxly

chapterContent.content: The move will deal super-effective damage, which is double damage. On the next turn, use it again to KO Nemona’s starter.

chapterContent.aside: All Pokémon belong to one or two types. For example, Sprigatito is a Grass type Pokémon.

chapterContent.content: After the battle, Clavell will upgrade your Rotom Phone to add the Pokédex function. Now when you encounter a Pokémon species in battle, your Pokédex will automatically register some of its data. To obtain its full data, you need to catch the Pokémon species. We’ll get to that bit soon!
Once you’re ready, return to the base of the white stairs, in front of the building. Your Mom will come over to check your progress. Before leaving, she’ll hand you a Sandwich.
Right, it’s off to school! Follow the path forward (west on the mini-map), then take a right at the T-junction, towards Poco Path.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Poco Path - Catching Pokémon

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for Poco Path, near the beginning of Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. Here, you’ll get to catch your first Pokémon!
As you enter Poco Path, Nemona will teach you about catching Pokémon. Rather than showing you herself, you’ll get some hands on practice!

You’ll be thrown into a battle with a Level 3 Lechonk. Use your damaging moves to weaken the Lechonk until it has under half HP. The lower, the better, but don’t KO it. Once Lechonk is weak, press  and select a Poké Ball. With luck, the Lechonk should stay in the ball.
Afterwards, you’ll receive an extra 10 Poké Balls from Nemona.
Now you’re free to wander around and catch Pokémon!

To catch a Pokémon, you first need to battle them. You can do so by touching them on the field. Or you can press  when near and facing them to throw your Pokémon at them, to trigger a battle that way. This is the only way to battle Pokémon in the air.
Additionally, if you throw a Pokémon at a wild Pokémon when they’re facing away from you, they’ll be stunned during the first turn of battle.

chapterContent.aside: You can hold  to lock onto nearby wild Pokémon. Use the right stick to focus on a Pokémon. After locking on, you can move the right stick left/right to focus on a different Pokémon and lock onto them.

chapterContent.content: Your goal is the lighthouse towards the north-east. Simply follow the path to reach it.
However, we recommend spending a bit of time catching some of the Pokémon here–of which there are many! There are also lots of item balls (shaped like Poké Balls) dotted around, containing items.

When you’re halfway to the lighthouse, near Inlet Grotto, Nemona will catch up to you. Suddenly, a loud noise will come from the direction of Inlet Grotto. Just past where Nemona is standing, head towards the narrow side path, through the gap in the fence.

You’ll spot the source of the noise all the way down and accidentally slip. Thankfully, the power of technology saves you from certain death. Approach the collapsed Pokémon by the water. When it regains its strength, follow it inside Inlet Grotto.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Best Victory Road Route in Pokémon Scarlet and Violet

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet is a true open world Pokémon experience and as such, you are free to tackle the three main storylines in any order. This page will guide you on the best route through the Victory Road storyline.

chapterContent.head: Best Victory Road Gym Order

chapterContent.content: If you’ve decided to focus only on Victory Road to begin with, or you want to see what Level the next Gym is, you can refer to the table below:

As you can see from the above, you won’t be going in one direction as you tackle the Gyms, the Psychic Gym is an easy one to go to early as it’s featured in the southwest of Paldea but is actually one of the highest ones out there. You can find a few tips about each Gym below:

This is the lowest level Gym in the game, so it shouldn’t cause you too many problems. Since you’re fighting at the Bug Gym, you’ll want to make-up a team of Pokémon that do well against Bug-types. Rock , Flying  and Fire  Pokémon are all good options because they’ll do x2 damage (super effective). For those of you who took the Fire Starter, Fuecoco, you’ll have no issues here at all.
For an in-depth strategy on how to tackle the Bug Gym, head on over to our guide on How to Defeat Bug Gym Leader Katy.

Grass-type Pokémon are weak to Bug , Poison , Ice, Flying  and Fire , two of which were strong against the previous Gym. Once again, if you have the Fire Starter, Fuecoco, you’re in luck here as you won’t need to make many changes to the previous party.
For an in-depth strategy on how to tackle the Grass Gym, head on over to our guide on How to Defeat Grass Gym Leader Brassius.

The Electric Gym is the first one that may cause a few issues, as their only weakness is against Ground  Pokémon. With that said, both the Grass and Fire Starters are not weak to Electric and Electric has no resistances making them still useful here.
For an in-depth strategy on how to tackle the Electric Gym, head on over to our guide on How to Defeat Electric Gym Leader Iono.

Water-type Pokémon have two weaknesses, Electric  and Grass . As you may expect, this is the Grass Starter’s time to shine and it will make short work of the Gym. You can also get a Pichu as early as the first main area you can explore that you can raise.
For an in-depth strategy on how to tackle the Water Gym, head on over to our guide on How to Defeat the Water Gym Leader Kofu here.

This is one of the trickier Gyms, as Normal-type Pokémon have just the one weakness, to Fighting. On the other hand, the Normal-type is not strong against any other type, so you’re almost free to go with any team here.
For an in-depth strategy on how to tackle the Normal Gym, head on over to our guide on How to Defeat the Normal Gym Leader Larry here.

The Ghost Gym has some oddities to it, as Ghost-type Pokémon are weak to Dark  and Ghost  which may catch out newcomers to Pokémon. On top of that, Fighting  and Normal  moves will have no effect against Ghost Pokémon.
For an in-depth strategy on how to tackle the Ghost Gym, head on over to our guide on How to Defeat the Psychic Gym Leader Ryme.

The Psychic Gym can also be a little tricky, as outside of its weakness to Bug , the other two weaknesses, Dark  and Ghost  are less common. They’re also resistant to Fighting on top of their own Type so you’ll need to select a specific team for this Gym.
For an in-depth strategy on how to tackle the Psychic Gym, head on over to our guide on How to Defeat Psychic Gym Leader Tulip.

The Ice Gym is the final destination for those on the Victory Road path, and you’ll find them weak to Fire , Fighting , Steel , and Rock , that’s a lot of weaknesses. As always, if you have the final evolution of the Fire Starter, you should make short work of this Gym.
For an in-depth strategy on how to tackle the Ice Gym, head on over to our guide on How to Defeat the Ice Gym Leader Grusha.

chapterContent.head: Victory Road Rewards

chapterContent.content: Victory Road is the most traditional Pokémon storyline out of the three available in Scarlet & Violet. You’ll be tasked with visiting each of the Gyms to defeat the Gym Leaders that are there.

For completing each one, you’ll obtain a TM pertaining to the Type that you fought at the Gym along with a Badge. Each Badge will allow higher level Pokémon obey you more so you’ll want to sprinkle Gyms in between whatever other activities you undertake (such as the Titans).
If you wish to know a bit more detail about specific routes (for example, if you wanted to focus on one at a time), then head to the following pages for more information:

chapterContent.li: What is the Best Story Order in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet?
Best Starfall Street Route in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet
How to Progress Path of Legends in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: When Do You Fight Your Rival?

chapterContent.content: As with most Pokemon games, you will have a rival that occasionally challenges you in Pokemon Scarlet and Pokemon Violet. This time around, your rival will choose the weaker typing when choosing their starter Pokemon and will be friendly toward you. Below we go over every rival encounter and how to easily make short work of their Pokemon team.

chapterContent.head: Rival Battle One

chapterContent.content: This will take place right after you choose your starter. Nemona will choose the typing that’s weak to the starter you chose. Here’s who she will choose based on your starter choice.

chapterContent.li: Quaxly: Nemona Chooses Fuecoco
Fuecoco: Nemona Choose Sprigatito
Sprigatito: Nemona Choose Quaxly

chapterContent.content: To win the battle, simply use the elemental attack that your starter comes equipped with.

chapterContent.head: Rival Battle Two (Your First Day of School)

chapterContent.content: Nemona will want a rematch on your first day of school. Here is a look at her slightly updated team.
In addition to this, she will have her starter at level 8. Simply use yours to counter her.

chapterContent.head: Rival Battle Three (After Entering Third Gym)

chapterContent.content: After you obtain two gym badges, you will encounter Nemona as soon as you enter the third gym you wish to challenge. This time she will have three Pokemon on her team. Here are her two new additions.
These two are pretty weak. You can take Rockruff down with water, grass, fighting, steel, or ground attacks. As for Pawmi, you simply need to use a ground type attack to take them down.

Once you have taken them out, she will send out the level 22 starter that is opposite of yours. She will use a Tera Orb on them, but this should not make too much difference as it doesn’t change their type. Simply send your own starter out and use super effective attacks to make quick work of her last Pokemon.
