Ice Pokémon are fantastic, since they deal 4x damage. Fairy and Rock types are also great. However, beware that Noivern is fast and loves using Super Fang to drop your Pokémon to half health, so avoid fielding your trump card at the start, unless it can outspeed Noivern!
Haxorus is a pure Dragon that’s pretty straightforward. It’s carrying Dragon Claw for STAB, Iron Head to punish Fairy types, Rock Tomb to slow down Ice types and Crunch for coverage.
Despite taking super-effective damage from Iron Head or Rock Tomb, Fairy and Ice-types are your safest bet here.
Dragalge is a Poison and Dragon type. Hassel’s can use Sludge Bomb and Dragon Pulse for STAB, Hydro Pump to scare off Ground types and Thunderbolt for additional coverage.
Keep your Fairy types away; instead, Ice and Psychic types should fare well here. Dragalge is on the slow side, so you shouldn’t struggle too much, overall.
Flapple is a Grass and Dragon type. This one knows Seed Bomb and Dragon Rush (for Grass and Dragon STAB), Aerial Ace (to counter Bug types) and Leech Seed (to steal health).
Ice types are the best choice, for their 4x damage. Otherwise, go with Fairy types.

For his last stand, Hassel will send out and swiftly Terastallize his Baxcalibur. Normally a Dragon and Ice type, it’ll become a pure Dragon type, enhancing its Dragon attacks and retaining its Ice type STAB.

For attacks, it can use its signature move Glaive Rush, which deals heavy Dragon damage, but renders it vulnerable on the next turn: all attacks will hit it, regardless of accuracy, and deal double damage.
Besides that, it’s got Icicle Crash for Ice STAB and Brick Break to terrorize opposing Ice types.

Fairy types are highly recommended, so you don’t get hit by Tera-boosted Glaive Rush. Otherwise, if your Pokémon does get hit, you should be fine so long as it’s not your only Pokémon. On the next turn, you can deal massive damage to Baxcalibur due to the secondary effect of Glaive Rush.
After defeating Hassel, you’ll have triumphed against the Elite Four. Yet one more challenge awaits until you’re a Champion yourself–and that’s the Top Champion, Geeta!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Top Champion Geeta (La Primera)

chapterContent.content: This page details how to beat Top Champion Geeta, aka La Primera. This is a part of the Pokémon League’s Champion Assessment and comes at the end of the Victory Road Walkthrough.
Below you’ll find information on Geeta’s Pokémon and what Pokémon you should bring in to counter hers!

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Top Champion Geeta

chapterContent.content: Like most Champions in the past, Geeta has a varied team, so you can’t pick a few Types and call it a day. That said, good Types to bring include Fighting (strong versus half of her team), Bug (strong versus half), Dark (strong versus two) and Ground (strong versus two).
Her Pokémon are around Level 61, so you should aim to bring Pokémon of around Level 60+ into the fight.
If in doubt, here are some Pokémon suggestions:

chapterContent.li: The Level 75 Tera Lucario at Dalizapa Passage, in the underground tunnel. A strong Fighting type that you can fairly easily catch. Try and sneak behind it to stun it for 1 turn. Immediately Paralyze it, then whack it until it returns to normal–at which point, you can catch it.
Skuntank, a Poison and Dark type. Found at Socarrat Trail.

chapterContent.aside: After entering the Pokémon League building, you cannot leave.

chapterContent.head: What Pokémon does Top Champion Geeta have?

chapterContent.content: Geeta leads with Espathra, a pure Psychic type. So no need to strain your brain too much. It can use its signature move Lumina Crash, a Psychic type attack that lowers the opponent’s Special Defense stat by two stages.
In addition, it’s carrying Dazzling Gleam to annoy Dark types, Quick Attack to deal chip damage before you can react and Reflect to weaken your physical attacks for 5 turns.

Dark types will be super-effective and are immune to Lumina Crash, but may get hurt by Dazzling Gleam. There are some that take neutral damage though, like the recommended Skuntank or Bisharp/Kingambit.
Ghost and Bug types should be OK, if they’re fast and not weak to Fairy/Psychic. Otherwise they may not survive two hits of Lumina Crash.
In case of Reflect, make sure at least one of your Pokémon knows Brick Break or have some special attackers handy.

Gogoat is a pretty average Grass type. Geeta’s goat can use Horn Leech for STAB and to drain health, Zen Headbutt to counter Poison types, Play Rough for additional coverage and Bulk Up to bolster its Attack and Defense stats.
Most Fire, Ice, Bug and Flying types should have no problems here. Even though Skuntank is Poison, it doesn’t care about Zen Headbutt because it’s also Dark.
Finally, a dual type Pokémon! Water and Psychic. For attacks, it can use Liquidation and Psycho Cut for STAB, Aqua Jet to try and attack first and Ice Fang to combat Grass types.
Annoyingly, Veluza has a pretty robust move set. Try using Electric, Bug, Ghost or Dark types. As long as they’re not weak to Water or Psychic (especially Water), they should manage.

Oh, another mono type. This Ice type Pokémon can use Avalanche, which deals more damage if the user has received damage on the same turn, Earthquake to mess up Fire, Steel and Rock types, Body Press just in case and Crunch for additional coverage.

Avalugg is slow, so it can easily take advantage of Avalanche. Also, it has exceptional Defense: you absolutely want to combat it with special attackers. The Tera Lucario is great here, with its Aura Sphere. Otherwise, any super-effective special attacker (Fire, Fighting, Steel or Rock) should suffice.

Kingambit is possibly Greeta’s scariest Pokémon, excluding her ace. This Dark and Steel type can use its signature move Kowtow Cleave, which deals impressive Dark damage and never misses. In addition, it’s got Iron Head for Steel STAB, Stone Edge to wreck Fire types and Zen Headbutt to counter Fighting types.
Furthermore, its Supreme Overlord ability slightly boosts its Attack and Special Attack stats for each KO’d team member. If it’s the 5th Pokémon that Geeta sends out, it could be troublesome.

Despite Zen Headbutt, Fighting types are highly recommended since they deal quadruple damage. Kingambit is slow, so unless yours is even slower, you should one-shot it before taking damage (the Tera Lucario won’t break a sweat). Otherwise, Ground types are a solid choice.

For her final Pokémon, Geeta will send out Glimmora and Terastallize it as the earliest opportunity. It will become a pure Rock type, boosting its Rock attacks further while retaining its Poison STAB.
For attacks, it can use Tera Blast to deal heavy Rock damage, Sludge Wave for Poison STAB, Earth Power to bully Steel types and Dazzling Gleam to hurt Fighting types.

If you have the Tera Lucario, it should one-shot Glimmora with its Aura Sphere. But if you prefer a fairer match, go with Ground types since they’re super-effective and resist both Tera Blast and Sludge Wave.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: Demolish the crystallized flower and the title of Champion is yours! Outside, Nemona will demand a real Pokémon battle now that you’re both Champions. However, you only just beat the Pokémon League, so now’s not the time for a battle.
When you’re ready though, head to the central plaza of Mesagoza for your final battle with Nemona!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Champion Nemona

chapterContent.content: This page offers a guide on how to beat Champion Nemona during your final battle with her at Mesagoza in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet as part of the Victory Road story path. You will first need to defeat the Pokémon League and become a Champion to challenge her.
Below you’ll find information on Nemona’s Pokémon and what Pokémon you should bring in to counter hers!

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Champion Nemona

chapterContent.content: As usual Nemona has a varied team, so your team should also be varied. A Fighting type or two is highly recommended since they’re strong against half of Nemona’s team (more if you picked Fuecoco).
Her Pokémon are Level 65 to 66, so you should aim to bring Pokémon of around Level 65+ into the fight.
If in doubt, here are some Pokémon suggestions:

chapterContent.li: Your starter fully evolved. Pretty much a no-brainer, since Nemona will use the starter that’s weak to yours. That said, if you benched your starter, don’t fret.
The Level 75 Tera Lucario at Dalizapa Passage, in the underground tunnel. High level and a good all-rounder.
The Level 75 Tera Dragonite at the eastern edge of Paldea. High level with exceptional Attack.

chapterContent.head: What Pokémon does Champion Nemona have?

chapterContent.content: To begin with, Nemona will send out a Midday Form Lycanroc. It can use Stone Edge for hard-hitting STAB, Accelerock to sneak in an attack before you, Drill Run to damage Steel types and Stealth Rock to damage switch-ins.
Ground or Fighting types would be perfect here, to deal super-effective damage and resist Stone Edge. A fast victory is advised, in case it sets up Stealth Rock. The Tera Lucario won’t break a sweat.
This gooey dragon can use Dragon Pulse for STAB, Muddy Water to lower accuracy, Sludge Bomb to damage Fairy types and Ice Beam for additional coverage.
We recommend fielding an Ice type. If you caught the Level 75 Tera Dragonite, you can demolish it with Outrage though.

Amazingly, Nemona has a 1/100 three-segment Dudunsparce. Hers can use Hyper Drill for STAB, Drill Run to get through Steel types, Dragon Rush for… reasons and Coil to boost its Attack, Defense and Accuracy.
Fighting types are the natural choice here. If you have the Level 75 Tera Lucario, it’ll be gone before you can say “Aura Sphere.”

This pure Steel type (not a Bug!) can use Iron Tail for STAB, Earthquake to punish Fire types, plus Body Press and Rock Blast for coverage. It has the Earth Eater ability, which absorbs Ground type damage.
Again, you should use a Fighting type here. Another easy job for the Tera Lucario.

Did anybody else have trouble trying to evolve Pawmo into this? Anyway, Nemona’s Pawmot can use Double Shock for massive Electric STAB damage, but removes its Electric type afterwards, Close Combat for powerful Fighting STAB, but lowers its defensive stats, Ice Punch to tickle Ground types and Quick Attack to try and attack first.
We recommend Psychic or Fairy types. Double Shock is a little dangerous, but after using it, Pawmot will lose its Electric STAB, making it less threatening.

chapterContent.aside: Nemona will use this fully evolved Fuecoco if you picked Quaxly at the start.

chapterContent.content: Nemona will Terastallize her ace into a pure Fire type, further boosting its Fire attacks and retaining its Ghost STAB.
Her Skeledirge can use Torch Song for Fire STAB and to boost its Special Attack, Shadow Ball for Ghost STAB, Snarl to lower your Special Attack and Earth Power to hit Rock and opposing Fire types.

Water types, especially your starter–hopefully fully evolved into Quaquaval–are highly recommended. Besides dealing super-effective damage, it’s a good idea to find ways to mitigate the damage from Tera-boosted Torch Song.

chapterContent.aside: Nemona will use this fully evolved Sprigatito if you picked Fuecoco at the start.

chapterContent.content: Nemona will Terastallize her ace into a pure Grass type, further boosting its Grass attacks and retaining its Dark STAB.

Her Meowscarada can use Flower Trick for Grass STAB (never misses and always criticals), Thunder Punch to target Flying types, Play Rough to counter Fighting types and Shadow Claw for additional coverage.
Fire types are highly recommended. If using your starter Skeledirge, you may want to Terastallize it so it loses its Ghost weakness.

chapterContent.aside: Nemona will use this fully evolved Quaxly if you picked Sprigatito at the start.

chapterContent.content: Nemona will Terastallize her ace into a pure Water type, further boosting its Water attacks and retaining its Fighting STAB.

Her Quaquaval can use Aqua Step for Water STAB and to boost its Speed, Brick Break for Fighting STAB and to shatter screens, Ice Spinner to hurt Grass types and destroy terrain and Aerial Ace just in case.

This one’s a tough cookie. Grass types would’ve been ideal, but Ice Spinner can take a good chunk of their HP. Meanwhile Electric types will take the full brunt of Aqua Step, which isn’t ideal, especially since Quaquaval is likely to outspeed you afterwards.
Your starter Meowscarada is also susceptible to STAB Brick Break, although you can Terastallize to remove the Fighting weakness.

If you’re stuck, try grabbing the Tera Tsareena from Socarrat Trail. You can use its Trop Kick to deal super-effective damage and lower Quaquaval’s Attack at the same time. Most likely, Quaquaval will try and use Ice Spinner or Aerial Ace, but you can Terastallize to remove your weakness. After one Trop Kick, Quaquaval should be less dangerous.

chapterContent.head: After the Fight

chapterContent.content: Congratulations, Nemona will stop hounding you for a battle… for 10 seconds anyway!
Afterwards, you’ll need to complete the Path of Legends and Starfall Street story paths to unlock the Area Zero story.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Best Route for Path of Legends Story

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet is a true open world Pokémon experience and as such, you are free to tackle the three main storylines in any order. This page will guide you on the best route through the Path of Legends storyline.

chapterContent.head: Best Way to Progress the Path of Legends Story

chapterContent.content: If you’ve decided to focus only on Path of Legends to begin with, or you want to see what Level the next Titan is, you can refer to the table below:
Out of all of these, Surf and Climb are by far the most useful, as they’ll allow you to reach places that were otherwise unavailable. You can find a few tips about each Titan below:

As the first Titan you encounter, Klawf shouldn’t pose too much of a threat. As a Rock-type, Klawf has weaknesses to Fighting , Grass , Ground , Water , and Steel  with both Water and Grass offering a 4x increase in damage. That’s a lot of weaknesses, so it should be simple to come up with a team for it.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat Klawf, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

Bombirdier is close in Level to Klawf, so you can almost do both of these back-to-back. As a Flying-type Pokémon, it has weaknesses to Electric , Ice , and Rock  and there’s a few useful Electric-type Pokémon available at this early stage such as Pikachu.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat Bombirdier, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

Just under a 10 Level jump to the next Titan, Orthworm so you may wish to do some of the other storylines in between. As a Steel-type, it has weaknesses to Fire , Fighting , and Ground  so if you went with the Fire Starter, you should be able to make short work of this overgrown worm.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat Orthworm, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

As you can see, you’ll be facing a different Titan in this battle based on what version you have. This Titan battle is against a Ground-type and as such, their weaknesses are Ice , Grass , and Water  so as long as you don’t have the Fire Starter, your Starter should be incredibly useful for this encounter.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat Great Tusk, head on over to our Walkthrough here.
Alternatively, if you’re looking for how to defeat Iron Treads, head on over to our [Walkthrough] here.

The Final Titan is a bit of an odd one, because you will actually fight two Titans here. You’ll begin by fighting Dondozo twice (with Arven joining for the second battle), which is a Water-type. After the second battle, the real battle will begin against Tatsugiri which is a Dragon-type. As a Dragon-type, its weaknesses are Dragon , Fairy , and Ice  so it may be a bit trickier finding a team to take it on. Thankfully, there are a lot of Ice-type Pokémon found to the northeast of Paldea.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat Tatsugiri, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

Once you take out all of the Titans, there will be one final battle that will finish this storyline. We don’t want to spoil this here for you though, if you’re looking for an in-depth strategy on how to win the final battle, head on over to our [Walkthrough] here.

chapterContent.head: Path of Legends Rewards

chapterContent.content: The Path of Legends storyline is focused on tracking down Titan Pokémon throughout Paldea. These will be a two-phase boss battle with Arven joining for the second part, this will give you an idea of the Level of the Titan Pokémon which is otherwise hidden.

For completing each one, you’ll obtain a new travel ability which will give you access to parts of Paldea you never had before, like the sea. This is where you can sequence break a bit, as it is possible to defeat the higher-level Titans with moves that Poison for example.
If you wish to know a bit more detail about specific routes (for example, if you wanted to focus on one at a time), then head to the following pages for more information:

chapterContent.li: What is the Best Story Order in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet?
Best Victory Road Route in Pokémon Scarlet and Violet
How to Progress Starfall Street in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We have details on where to find it, what Pokémon we recommend you bring along and ultimately, how to defeat it.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find The Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan

chapterContent.content: Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan can be found by roaming around the east side of the Naranja Academy between the South Province (Area Three) and East Province (Area One). Alternatively, you can head northwest from the Artazon West Pokemon Center.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan

chapterContent.content: Ideally, you should attempt the Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan when your Pokémon are at least Level 17.

Klawf is a Rock  type, so you’ll ideally want to bring along Grass  or Water  Pokémon due to these being Klawfs biggest weaknesses, so if you picked Sprigatito or Quaxly, they’ll be great candidates here. Additionally, you can use Ice , Fighting , Ground , Steel  in this battle, as Klawf is still weak to these elements but just not as much as Grass  or Water,

If you didn’t pick Sprigatito or Quaxly at the start of the game or you would like to bring along some other Pokémon to help out in the fight, then you should consider these options which you would’ve seen whilst adventuring towards the Stony Cliff Titan:

chapterContent.head: Best Strategies for Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan

chapterContent.content: You’ll end up fighting Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan twice, although there’s a brief pause in-between the two fights, if you need to rest etc. If you’ve selected any of the Pokémon mentioned above, then some of these attacks will be useful for the upcoming battle. Psyduck Water Gun, Makuhita Arm Thrust, Skiddo Leech Seed or Razor Leaf and Hoppip Sleep Powder.

For attacks Klawf can use Vise Grip which can deal decent damage to your Pokémon depending on your level. Rock Tomb which will cause Speed Down on your Pokémon, so it could increase the chance of Klawf being able to take it’s turn before you. Once you take Klawfs health below 50% it will activate the ability “Anger Shell” which will increase its Attack, Sp. Atk and Speed but at the cost of lowering its defense. Next up, Klawf can perform Rock Smash will lower your defense which means your Pokémon will take more damage from regular attacks.

Once you’ve taken Klawfs health down into the red it’ll flee and you’ll need to find it in order to complete the battle. Simply, walk down the hill you took to reach him the first time and you’ll see it waiting at the bottom. During this phase Klawf will be buffed after chowing down on a Herba Mystica, but dont worry too much as Arven will be fighting alongside you this time with Shellder which is a Water  type. Shellder will use Leer against Klwarf to lower its defense and its Water Gun which will deal a lot of damage due to it hitting its elemental weakness.

All of Klawfs attacks in phase two are the same as phase one, but can just deal more damage, so you’ll want to make sure your Pokémons HP is topped up. The only real difference between these phases is that Klawfs will use Anger Shell again to increase its overall stats, but at the cost of lowering his sp. defense and regular defense.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: Upon defeating Klawf and completing the Rock Titan you’ll gain access to Dash which is a new travel ability. This can be used by pressing  button on the joycons or pro controller to hop onto Miraidon or Koraidon, then press in the  to dash. This will allow you get through areas quicker, but be careful of nearby Pokémon or Trees as hitting them will initiate a battle.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We have details on where to find it, what Pokémon we recommend you bring along and ultimately, how to defeat it.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find The Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan

chapterContent.content: Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan can be found by roaming around the West Province (Area One) which is reached by exiting the Naranja Academy via the west entrance. Alternatively, you can head northwest from the “West Province (Area One) - Central Pokémon Center. However, when you approach it you’ll need to avoid rocks falling down the mountain, so you’ll want to swerve out of the way and use the rocks along the way, as cover.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan

chapterContent.content: Ideally, you should attempt the Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan when you are at least Level 20.

Bombirdier is a Flying  Dark  type, so you’ll ideally want to bring along a atleast one of Electric  Ice  Rock . It doesn’t matter which of the three elements you choose as Bombirdier is weak to all three by the same amount. If you haven’t got you hands on any Electric  Ice  Rock  yet, then you should consider these options which you would’ve seen whilst adventuring towards the Open Sky Titan:

chapterContent.head: Best Strategies for Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan

chapterContent.content: You’ll end up fighting Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan twice, although there’s a brief pause in-between the two fights, etc. If you’ve selected any of the Pokémon mentioned above, then some of these attacks will be useful for the upcoming battle. Nacli Rock Throw, Pawmi, Thunder Shock.

For attacks Bombirdier can use Rock Throw, Pluck and Wing Attack which can deal decent damage to your Pokémon depending on your level and type, so throughout the battle you’ll want to make sure you keep topping up your health with Potions or Super Potions to avoid it being defeated. Outside of the above attacks, Bombirdier can use Torment which will prevent your Pokémon from using the same attack twice.

Aditionally, you’ll want to avoid using Pokémon Types its strong against which are  and . Unlike some of the Titans for example Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan, Bombirdier doesn’t have any attacks that can inflict stats, such as Speed Down nor can it use any attacks that improves its own stats, so that will make the battle slightly easier.

Once you’ve taken Bombirdiers health down into the red it’ll flee and consume a Bitter Herba Mystica which will buff it up, but dont worry too much as Arven will be fighting alongside you this time with Nacli who is a Rock  type. Nacli will use Smack Down and Rock Throw which will deal a lot of damage due to it hitting its elemental weakness. Here you could just keep healing up your Pokémon and wait for Arven to finish Bombirdier off.
All of Bombirdier attacks in phase two are the same as phase one, but can just deal more damage, so you’ll want to make sure your Pokémons HP is topped up.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: Upon defeating Bombirdier and completing the Flying Titan you’ll gain access to Surf which is a new travel ability. This can be used by pressing  button on the joycons or pro controller to hop onto Miraidon or Koraidon, then simply walk into a pool of water and you’ll automatically begin swimming. This will now allow you to find and catch Pokémon which can only be found in water.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We have details on where to find it, what Pokémon we recommend you bring along and ultimately, how to defeat it.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find The Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan

chapterContent.content: Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan can be found by roaming around the East Province (Area Three) which is reached by exiting the Naranja Academy via east gate and working your way up north through East Province (Area One) and East Province (Area Two). Alternatively, you can head northwest from the Levincia Pokémon Center. However, when you approach it you’ll notice the battle doesn’t trigger, so simply keep dashing into him with your Legendary Pokémon two or three times and eventually the battle will begin.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan

chapterContent.content: Ideally, you should attempt the Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan when you are at least Level 29.

Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan is a Steel  type, so you’ll ideally want to bring along a atleast one of Fire , Fighting  or Ground  It doesn’t matter which of the three elements you choose as Bombirdier is weak to all three by the same amount. If you haven’t got you hands on any Fire , Fighting  or Ground , then you should consider these options which you would’ve seen whilst adventuring towards the Lurking Steel Titan:

chapterContent.head: Best Strategies for Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan

chapterContent.content: You’ll end up fighting Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan twice, although there’s a brief pause in-between the two fights, etc. If you’ve selected any of the Pokémon mentioned above, then some of these attacks will be useful for the upcoming battle. Diglett Sand Attack, Mudbray Bulldoze, Charcadet Flame Charge, Mankey Low Kick.

For attacks Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan can use Iron Tail which will lower your defense which means your Pokémon will take more damage from regular attacks. Headbutt which can deal decent damage to your Pokémon depending on your level and type, so throughout the battle you’ll want to make sure you keep topping up your health with Potions or Super Potions to avoid it being defeated.

Next up, we have Wrap which will inflict damage to your Pokémon for 2-5 turns, so as long you use potions this attack shouldn’t cause you too much of a problem. Additionally, you’ll want to avoid using Pokémon Types its strong against which are Dragon  Bug  Fairy  Ice  Flying  Grass  Normal  Psychic  and Rock

Once you’ve taken Orthworm health down into the red it’ll flee and you’ll need to find it in order to complete the battle. Simply, walk down through the tunnel it created to find it, then keep running into it like you did at the last to trigger the battle. However, this time around the Orthworm has consumed a Herba Mystica which will buff it up, but dont worry too much as Arven will be fighting alongside you this time with Toedscool who is a Grass  type. Toedscool will use Grass Knot and Supersonic, but these dont seem too effective against the Orthworm.

All of the Orthworm attacks in phase two are the same as phase one with one addition, Sandstorm which will cause you to take damage. Outside of Sandstorm the other three attacks mentioned above will just deal more damage due to the Orthworm being buffed, so just make sure you heal up throughout.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: Upon defeating Orthworm and completing the Steel Titan you’ll gain access to Jump which is a new travel ability. This can be used by pressing  button on the joycons or pro controller to hop onto Miraidon or Koraidon, then press and hold  and you’ll now jump higher than before. This will be great for when you’re traversing the world.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Great Tusk, the Quaking Earth Titan (Scarlet)

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Great Tusk, the Quaking Earth Titan in Pokémon Scarlet. We have details on where to find it, what Pokémon we recommend you bring along and ultimately, how to defeat it.

chapterContent.aside: Great Tusk only appears in Pokémon Scarlet.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find the Quaking Earth Titan (Scarlet)

chapterContent.content: Great Tusk, the Quaking Earth Titan, can be found roaming the west side of Asado Desert, between West Province (Area One) and West Province (Area Two). Also west from Cascarrafa, where the Water gym is. It’s incredibly hard to miss Great Tusk when you’re nearby, because it’s absolutely gigantic.
We recommend heading to Cascarrafa, if you haven’t done so already. This water-themed town is located north from Cortondo, where the Grass Gym is; you can head west from Mesagoza to reach Cortondo.

From Cortondo, travel north-west until you go past the bridge across the river. West from here is a Pokémon Center that acts as a pit stop. Continue west a short distance, then follow the road north, then north-east after the next bridge. Halfway towards Cascarrafa, there’s another PMC. After that is Cascarrafa itself.
When you’re at Cascarrafa, the Asado Desert is directly west from the town. Make your way west through the desert and you’ll find your destination easily.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Quaking Earth Titan (Scarlet)

chapterContent.content: Ideally, you should attempt the Quaking Earth Titan when your Pokémon are at least Level 45.
Great Tusk is a Paradox (ancient) Donphan that’s a Ground  and Fighting  type.
Offensively, the best Pokémon to use are Water , Grass , Flying , Psychic  and Fairy .
Defensively, Fairy  is the best, when considering what moves Great Tusk can use. Avoid Psychic  unless they take neutral damage from Dark (eg. if they’re part Fighting, Dark or Fairy).
If you picked Quaxly, they’ll be great here, when fully evolved. Meanwhile if you fully evolved Sprigatito, exercise caution because they’re weak to Fighting .
Other Pokémon you could consider:

chapterContent.li: Gyarados (Water  and Flying ), which you can evolve from Magikarp, commonly found in rivers everywhere.
Azumarill (Water  and Fairy ), evolved from Azurill, found around south Paldea. Or caught around north-west Paldea.
Scovillain (Grass  and Fire ), evolved from Capsakid, found around Asado Desert. Or you could catch one around south-west or north-east Paldea, etc.
Lilligant (Grass ), evolved from Petilil, found near south-west Paldea or the far west, below Asado Desert.
Dachsbund (Fairy ), evolved from Fidough, found near Los Platos etc. Or caught from south-west Paldea or north-east from Asado Desert.

The Tinkatink line (Fairy  and Steel ). Tintatink is found near ruins (one south-west from the Dark Crew base, another north-east from Cortondo). Tinkatuff is also found near ruins (try north-east Paldea or the area just above the massive, central crater).

chapterContent.head: Best Strategies for the Quaking Earth Titan (Scarlet)

chapterContent.content: You’ll end up fighting Great Tusk twice, although there’s a brief pause in-between the two fights, if you need to rest etc.
Great Tusk resembles a prehistoric version of Donphan. Its Attack and Defense are high, but its special-based stats are poor.

For attacks, Great Tusk can use Rapid Spin, which used to be a real weak Normal-type move. Now it does decent damage and boosts the user’s Speed, on top of its usual effects: dispelling moves like Leech Seed and Wrap.
Also, watch out for Brick Break, a Fighting-type move that shatters protection from Reflect and Light Screen.

At this point, a Ghost-type would’ve been ideal, since they’re immune to Rapid Spin and Brick Break. Sadly, Great Tusk can use Knock Off, a Dark-type move that removes your Pokémon’s held item (and if does remove your item, deals increased damage).
Strangely, Great Tusk does not seem to know any Ground-type moves, just those three. So any Pokémon weak to Ground may have a fighting chance.

As mentioned above, Water , Grass , Flying  and Psychic  Pokémon are great for dealing damage. However, they can potentially get worn down by Great Tusk’s merciless onslaught. Psychic-types may also take super-effective damage from Knock Off.

Fairy  types are super-effective too, while also resisting Brick Break and Knock Off. Rapid Spin will still hurt, but you can’t have everything! The Tinkatink line can resist Rapid Spin too, but takes neutral damage from Brick Break.
Although Great Tusk can be intimidating, there are two things you can try.

One, Great Tusk only uses physical attacks and has no way to boost its Attack. As such, you can massively impair it by using moves that lower Attack, such as Growl. Better yet Baby-Doll Eyes, if Great Tusk is faster than your Pokémon (can happen if it spams Rapid Spin). You could also repeatedly switch in and out Pokémon with the Intimidate ability.
Keep in mind critical hits from Great Tusk will ignore Attack drops, but unless you’re unlucky, it shouldn’t happen too often.

Two, unlike Iron Treads in Pokémon Violet, Great Tusk is susceptible to poison. When poisoned, it will lose a large chunk of health each turn. You could then spam healing items or Protect (learned from TM) while Great Tusk succumbs to poison damage. Poison can be applied using moves like Poison Powder or Toxic. Or you could gamble on Poison Point from Clodsire, for instance.
After defeating Great Tusk, it will retreat. When you catch up with it, you’ll fight it again, but stronger. However, Arven will lend a hand with his own Pokémon:
As far as we can tell, Great Tusk fights exactly the same as before, but is slightly stronger. However, Arven’s Scovillain should make the fight go down faster with its super-effective Razor Leaf.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: Triumph against the Quaking Earth Titan and Arven will obtain the Sour Herba Mystica. Your travel buddy–Koraidon or Miraidon–will steal one of your Herba Mystica sandwiches and obtain the Glide ability.
When riding Koraidon or Miraidon, press  while in the air to begin gliding. You can do so after jumping or when you’re falling. Press  again while gliding to stop gliding.

chapterContent.aside: Unlike gliding in some other games, there’s a limit to how far you can glide. When you reach this limit, Koraidon or Miraidon will automatically start plunging downwards.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Iron Treads, the Quaking Earth Titan (Violet)

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Iron Treads, the Quaking Earth Titan in Pokémon Violet. We have details on where to find it, what Pokémon we recommend you bring along and ultimately, how to defeat it.

chapterContent.aside: Iron Treads only appears in Pokémon Violet.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find the Quaking Earth Titan (Violet)

chapterContent.content: Iron Treads, the Quaking Earth Titan, can be found roaming the west side of Asado Desert, between West Province (Area One) and West Province (Area Two). Also west from Cascarrafa, where the Water gym is. It’s incredibly hard to miss Iron Treads when you’re nearby, because it’s absolutely gigantic.
We recommend heading to Cascarrafa, if you haven’t done so already. This water-themed town is located north from Cortondo, where the Grass Gym is; you can head west from Mesagoza to reach Cortondo.

From Cortondo, travel north-west until you go past the bridge across the river. West from here is a Pokémon Center that acts as a pit stop. Continue west a short distance, then follow the road north, then north-east after the next bridge. Halfway towards Cascarrafa, there’s another PMC. After that is Cascarrafa itself.
When you’re at Cascarrafa, the Asado Desert is directly west from the town. Make your way west through the desert and you’ll find your destination easily.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Quaking Earth Titan (Violet)

chapterContent.content: Ideally, you should attempt the Quaking Earth Titan when your Pokémon are at least Level 45. We did however have success at Level 30 by using Water  type Pokemon.
Iron Treads is a Paradox (future) Donphan that’s a Ground  and Steel  type.
Offensively, the best Pokémon to use are Water , Ground , Fighting , and Fire .
Defensively, Water  and Fire  are the best, when considering what moves Iron Treads can use. Avoid Rock , Ice , and Fairy  unless they have a second typing to balance out the damage.
Two of the starter choices are useful in this battle, with Quaxly and Fuecoco both being a solid choice. Due to Iron Treads Fire Fang move, you will want to avoid using Sprigatito.
Other Pokémon you could consider:

chapterContent.li: Gyarados (Water  and Flying ), which you can evolve from Magikarp, commonly found in rivers everywhere.
Azumarill (Water  and Fairy ), evolved from Azurill, found around south Paldea. Or caught around north-west Paldea.
Makuhita (), can be picked up right above the Asado Desert in the field outside of Porto Marinada.
Crawlbrawler ( ), can be picked up on the beach shore near Porto Marinada and is easily one of the best choices for this fight.
Finizen (water ), is also a useful pick in the battle that can be found swimming close to the beach near Porto Marinada.

chapterContent.head: Best Strategies for the Quaking Earth Titan (Violet)

chapterContent.content: You’ll end up fighting Irons Treads twice, although there’s a brief pause in-between the two fights, if you need to rest etc.
Iron Treads resembles a futuristic version of Donphan. Its Attack and Defense are high, but its special-based stats are poor.

Iron Treads can use Rapid Spin, which used to be a real weak Normal-type move. Now it does decent damage and boosts the user’s Speed, on top of its usual effects: dispelling moves like Leech Seed and Wrap.
Also, watch out for Iron Head, a steel-type move that has a chance to flinch your Pokemon. Fire Fang also has a chance to burn you so make sure to have some burn heal on hand just in case.
As mentioned above, Ground , and Fighting  Pokémon are great for dealing damage. However, they can potentially get worn down by Iron Treads merciless onslaught.

Fire  Pokemon and Water  Pokemon are your best choice here. Arven will be using a Fire-type move against Iron Treads that does sizable damage and has a chance to burn him. You can either try to burn him yourself with fire-type moves, or hit Iron Treads hard with water and fighting moves.
Although Iron Treads can be intimidating, there are two things you can try.

One, Iron Treads only uses physical attacks and has no way to boost its Attack. As such, you can massively impair it by using moves that lower Attack, such as Growl. Better yet Baby-Doll Eyes, if Iron Treads is faster than your Pokémon (can happen if it spams Rapid Spin). You could also repeatedly switch in and out Pokémon with the Intimidate ability.
Keep in mind critical hits from Iron Treads will ignore Attack drops, but unless you’re unlucky, it shouldn’t happen too often. Keep in mind that Iron Treads is immune to poison.

Iron Treads is susceptible to burn. When burned, it will lose a large chunk of health each turn. You could then spam healing items or Protect (learned from TM) while Iron Treads succumbs to burn damage.
After defeating Iron Treads, it will retreat. When you catch up with it, you’ll fight it again, but stronger. However, Arven will lend a hand with his own Pokémon:
As far as we can tell, Iron Treads fights exactly the same as before, but is slightly stronger. However, Arven’s Scovillain should make the fight go down faster with its super-effective Fire Fang.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: Triumph against the Quaking Earth Titan and Arven will obtain the Sour Herba Mystica. Your travel buddy–Koraidon or Miraidon–will steal one of your Herba Mystica sandwiches and obtain the Glide ability.
When riding Koraidon or Miraidon, press  while in the air to begin gliding. You can do so after jumping or when you’re falling. Press  again while gliding to stop gliding.

chapterContent.aside: Unlike gliding in some other games, there’s a limit to how far you can glide. When you reach this limit, Koraidon or Miraidon will automatically start plunging downwards.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We have details on where to find it, what Pokémon we recommend you bring along and ultimately, how to defeat it.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find The Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan can be found on a small island on the right side of Casseroya Lake. However, before you can reach it you’ll need to unlock the Travel Ability “Surf” which is obtained by defeating Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan which is a level 19 Flying Type. The easiest way to reach it is by traveling to the Glaseado Mount Pokémon Center and swimming west.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: Ideally, you should attempt the Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan when you are at least Level 56.

Dondozo is a Water  type, so you’ll ideally want to bring along a at least one of Electric  or Grass . It doesn’t matter which of the two types you choose as Dondozo is weak to all three by the same amount. If you haven’t got you hands on any Electrci  or Grass  yet, then you should consider these options which you would’ve seen whilst adventuring towards the False Dragon Titan:

chapterContent.head: Best Strategies for Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: You’ll end up fighting Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan twice, although there’s a brief pause in-between the two fights, etc. If you’ve selected any of the Pokémon mentioned above, then some of these attacks will be useful for the upcoming battle. Shroomish Leech Seed, Scovillain Razor Leaf, Luxray Volt Switch, Mareep Thunder Shock.

For attacks Dondozo can use Body Slam which can deal decent damage to your Pokémon depending on your level and type, so throughout the battle you’ll want to make sure you keep topping up your health with Potions or Super Potions to avoid it being defeated. Water Pulse which is another attack that mainly deals damage but it has chance to inflict Confusion which means your Pokémon may attack itself for 2-5 turns.

Finally, for Phase 1 Dondozo can use the ability Oblivious which will prevent it from being affected by Intimidate or Taunt. Additionally, you’ll want to avoid using Pokémon Types its strong against which are Ice  Water  and Steel

Once you’ve taken Dondozo health down into the red it’ll flee and you’ll need to find it in order to complete the battle. Simply, jump back into the water on your Legendary Mount and swim west until you reach a shallow area near another island. Here Dondozo will appear and phase 2 will begin! However, this time around the Dondozo has consumed a Herba Mystica which will buff it up, but dont worry too much as Arven will be fighting alongside you this time with Greedent who is a Normal  type. Greedent will primarily use Take Down.

During the second battle against Dondozo it’ll have two additional attacks which is Order Up and Aqua Tail. These two attacks mainly deal damage, so make sure to heal up afterwards. Alongside these two attacks the remaining attacks you saw in the first battle will just deal more damage this time around due to the buff of the herb.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: Upon defeating Dondozo you’ll need to face and defeat Tatsugiri in order to complete the Dragon Titan which will then give you access to Climb which is a new travel ability. This can be used by pressing  button on the joycons or pro controller to hop onto Miraidon or Koraidon, then press in the  button when you’re facing a wall to jump onto it.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Tatsugiri, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Tatsugiri, the False Dragon Titan in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We have details on where to find it, what Pokémon we recommend you bring along and ultimately, how to defeat it.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find The Tatsugiri, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: Tatsugiri, the False Dragon Titan can be battled after you’ve defeated Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan which is the first part of the Dragon Titan. However, before you can reach Dondozo you’ll need to unlock the Travel Ability “Surf” which is obtained by defeating Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan which is a level 19 Flying Type. The easiest way to reach it is by traveling to the Glaseado Mountain Pokémon Center and swimming west.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Tatsugiri, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: Ideally, you should attempt the Tatsugiri, the False Dragon Titan when you are at least Level 56.

Tatsugiri is a Dragon  type, so you’ll ideally want to bring along a at least one of Fairy  Ice  It doesn’t matter which of the two types you choose as Tatsugiri is weak to all three by the same amount. If you haven’t got you hands on any Fairy  Ice yet, then you should consider these options which you would’ve seen whilst adventuring towards the False Dragon Titan:

chapterContent.head: Best Strategies for Tatsugiri, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: You’ll have to fight Tatsugiri once, but the battle starts right after defeating Dondozo, so you’ll want to make sure you set your team up for both battles beforehand. If you’ve selected any of the Pokémon mentioned above, then some of these attacks will be useful for the upcoming battle. Cyclizar Breaking Swipe, Florges Fairy Wind and Igglybuff Disarming Voice or Sweet Kiss.

For attacks Tatsugiri can use Muddy Water which can deal decent damage to your Pokémon depending on your level and type, so throughout the battle you’ll want to make sure you keep topping up your health with Potions or Super Potions to avoid it being defeated. Additionally Muddy Water can cause Accuracy Down which means there’s an increased chance of missing your attack.

Icy Wind which will cause Speed Down on your Pokémon, so it could increase the chance of Tatsugiri being able to take it’s turn before you. Taunt which will prevent your Pokémon from being able to use status skills for 3 turns.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: Upon defeating Dondozo and Tatsugiri and completing the Dragon Titan you’ll then gain access to Climb which is a new travel ability. This can be used by pressing  button on the joycons or pro controller to hop onto Miraidon or Koraidon, then press in the  button when you’re facing a wall to jump onto it.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Pokémon Trainer Arven

chapterContent.content: This page offers a guide on how to beat Arven during the Path of Legends story in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. In order to battle Arven, you must first defeat all of the titans:

chapterContent.li: How to Beat Klawf, the Stony Cliff Titan
How to Beat Bombirdier, the Open Sky Titan
How to Beat Orthworm, the Lurking Steel Titan
How to Beat Great Tusk, the Quaking Earth Titan (Scarlet) OR How to Beat Iron Treads, the Quaking Earth Titan (Violet)
How to Beat Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan
How to Beat Tatsugiri, the False Dragon Titan

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve fought all the titans, you’ll need to head back to the Lighthouse near Poco Path to battle Arven.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Battling Arven

chapterContent.content: Arven is tougher than you might expect. For starters, your Pokémon should be around Level 63 as this is the highest level Pokémon in Arven’s team. Arven has a total of six Pokémon that he’ll bring out during this battle and he doesn’t just collect Pokémon of one type unfortunately. As you’ll see in the table below, Arven has a wide range of different Pokémon types. With this in mind, you’ll need to make sure your team is quite varied! At this stage in the game you’re probably already crafting the perfect team to go up against the Elite Four and Top Champion Geeta.

You’ll want to bring a good Fighting  Pokémon will be good for dealing extra damage to Greedent, Garganacl and Mabosstiff. A strong Grass  Pokémon is also a good shout, as they can deal extra damage to Cloyster, Garganacl and Toedscruel (x4 damage!) - the Sprigatito evolution, Meowscarada, is particularly strong for this battle.

chapterContent.head: Arven’s Pokémon

chapterContent.aside: The order that Arven brings out his Pokémon is dependent on the Pokémon you put out. He’ll try to counter your Pokémon wherever possible. Mabosstiff is always the final Pokémon.

chapterContent.content: Since Arven can bring out any of the Pokémon to counter your current Pokémon, you may want to think carefully about which Pokémon is your first to battle. You don’t want your strongest Pokémon to be one shot by a good counter!

Greedent is the lowest level Pokémon of Arven’s bunch. It’s a normal-type and it’s biggest attack is the Body Slam move, which does quite a lot of damage! You’ll want to bring out a Fighting-type Pokémon to do x2 damage! Close Combat is a strong fighting type that you can one-shot Greedent with!

Cloyster is a water and ice-type Pokémon that you’ll be able to deal with easily if you have a strong grass type. It does possess the psychic move Light Screen, which reduces damage from special attacks for five turns. This hopefully won’t be too much of an issue if you have strong grass-type moves like Seed Bomb or Meowscarada’s signature move, Flower Trick.
Light screen

Scovillain is a Fire and Grass-type so it knows some strong fire and grass moves. It seems to mostly use Fire Blast, which is a powerful fire move that will do a ton of damage. Try not to bring out any of Pokémon weak to fire as they’ll likely get one-shot! A Grass and Fire type Pokémon can be a bit annoying to navigate as you’ll find that Pokémon that do x2 damage to Fire types often do x0.5 damage to Grass types. Rock types do x2 damage to Fire types and Flying and Poison do x2 damage to Grass types so those are your best bets.

Toedscruel might be one of the most brutal Pokémon in Arven’s team. Toedscruel uses the move Earth Power very frequently. It looks like a fire move but it’s actually a special ground-type move which inflicts a lot damage. Avoid bringing out Fire, Electric, Poison, Rock and Steel-type Pokémon as they’ll undoubtedly get one shot. Try to bring out something that takes x0.5 damage to increase longevity, such as a Bug or Grass-type. A strong Bug-type could would take x0.5 damage and deal x2 damage against the Toedscruel!

Toedscruel also knows the grass-type move Spore, which can put the target to sleep. Naturally, this can be quite devastating so ensure you have a strong Pokémon that can take Toedscruel out in one or two turns!

Garganacl is quite the tanky Rock-type Pokémon. It uses Stone Edge and Stealth Rock. Stone Edge is a damaging move and has a high critical rate, whilst Stealth Rock will make an entry hazard in which opponent Pokémon will be damaged upon entering the battlefield. Bring out a strong water, grass, ground, steel or fighting type to deal x2 damage to Garganacl.

Mabosstiff, the cute dog you’ve been helping cure this whole time, is your final opponent! It comes into the battle and is immediately terastallized. It knows the fairy move Play Rough, which may catch you off guard. It will do x2 damage to Fighting types. We would still advise using Fighting Types, just ensure that you have plenty of healing and revives to keep your strong Fighting type alive. The Fighting type move Close Combat is great for doing big damage!
Once you defeat Mabosstiff, you’ll have concluded the battle against Pokémon Trainer Arven and finish up the Path of Legends story path.
You’ll need to finish the Starfall Street story and Victory Road to access Area Zero and the post-game content!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Begin Starfall Street in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This page serves as an explanation on the Starfall Street story path in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet and will help you find where to begin the story path itself.

chapterContent.head: What is Starfall Street?

chapterContent.content: Starfall Street is one of the three story paths in Scarlet & Violet. In this path, you’ll take on the various squads of the notorious Team Star and ultimately bring their downfall. You can undertake this story path at the same time as the other story paths.

chapterContent.head: When Can You Begin Starfall Street?

chapterContent.content: You can begin Starfall Street around the 2 hour mark, after you’ve reached Naranja (Scarlet) or Uva (Violet) Academy at Mesagoza, the biggest city in Paldea, located just below the massive, central crater.

chapterContent.aside: Just before you reach the academy, you’ll actually run into a pair of Team Star Grunts. This is part of the main story and mandatory for progression. Since this occurs before Starfall Street, you can consider it a prologue of sorts.

chapterContent.content: Inside the academy building, you’ll meet up with Nemona, who shows you to your classroom. After introducing yourself to the class, you’ll be free to wander around the academy. Head for the exit of the classroom and select the Cafeteria or Staff Room (we chose the Cafeteria).

After the events at the Cafeteria or Staff Room, attempt to leave. You’ll then get a call from your Rotom Phone, from a mysterious individual known as Cassiopeia. They’ll ask you to help defeat Team Star, but you won’t get a lot of details yet.

Now keep progressing the story for a short while until Director Clarvell announces the beginning of the Treasure Hunt. When you regain control, begin to leave campus. Nemona will chat to you while you walk. At the end, you’ll run into Arven and the two will have a friendly argument.

At this time, Cassiopeia will call you again and fill you in about Team Star. They will register five locations on your map, where Team Star’s bases are located. Your task is to go to all five and beat the stuffing out of the Team Star bosses. Pretty straightforward, eh?

chapterContent.aside: You can tackle the bosses in any order, but each boss has a specific Level range of Pokémon, so there’s a recommended order.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Best Starfall Street Route in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: Pokémon Scarlet & Violet is a true open world Pokémon experience and as such, you are free to tackle the three main storylines in any order. This page will guide you on the best route through the Starfall Street storyline.

chapterContent.head: What is the Best Way to Progress the Starfall Street Story?

chapterContent.content: If you’ve decided to focus only on Starfall Street to begin with, or you want to see what Level the next squad is, you can refer to the table below:
As you can see, once you defeat all five squads, the storyline will end with two final battles. You can find a few tips about each of the squads below:

The first Starfall Street battle serves more of an introduction to how they go down, so it shouldn’t cause too many problems. With the leader being a Dark-type, its weaknesses are Bug , Fairy , and Fighting  and you’ll encounter a lot of Bug Pokémon in and around the area which should help out.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat the Dark Crew Leader, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

You’ll have to head over to eastern Paldea for the next Team Start squad. With the leader being a Fire-type, its weaknesses are Ground , Water , and Rock  so if you chose the Water Starter, you’re in for an easier time here. Alternatively, there are Water-type Pokémon found near the sea here.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat the Fire Crew Leader, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

The Poison Crew are your next target, and with them being a Poison-type, their weaknesses are just Ground  and Psychic  making it trickier to create a team that will target their specific weakness. You’ll also want to make sure you have protection or items to deal with the Poison you’ll be suffering here.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat the Poison Crew Leader, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

The Fairy Crew follows the Poison Crew and like that squad, you’ll find they’re only weak to Poison  and Steel , even tougher Types to try and add to your team. You can get a few Poison-types early on and they help against some of the Titans so are well worth looking out for.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat the Fairy Crew Leader, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

The Fighting Crew is one of the tougher squads to deal with as the Pokémon they use at this stage of the game can be tricky. As Fighter-types, their weaknesses are Fairy , Flying , and Psychic  and Flying-types are easy to find out in the wild, making them a good choice for these battles.
For an in-depth strategy on how to defeat the Fighting Crew Leader, head on over to our Walkthrough here.

As with all the other storylines, once you take out all of the objectives, there will be some final battles to end this storyline. We don’t want to spoil this here for you though, if you’re looking for an in-depth strategy on how to win the final battles, head on over to our [Walkthrough] here (coming soon).

chapterContent.head: Starfall Street Rewards

chapterContent.content: The Starfall Street storyline is focused on tracking down the bases of the infamous Team Star and defeating each of their leaders in the hope you can get them to disband. Before you can take on the leader, though, you’ll need to participate in a raid battle by tossing out three of your Pokémon to auto-battle the current team’s grunts.

For completing each one, you’ll obtain a new TM along with materials and new recipes to use at the TM machine found at Pokémon Centers. The bases often block certain areas off too, so you’ll need to gain access (unless you have all of the travel abilities) to get around the world. In terms of rewards, Starfall Street has the least useful rewards.
If you wish to know a bit more detail about specific routes (for example, if you wanted to focus on one at a time), then head to the following pages for more information:

chapterContent.li: What is the Best Story Order in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet?
Best Victory Road Route in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet
Best Route for Path of Legends Story in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat the Dark Crew in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This page serves as an explanation on how to beat Team Star’s Dark Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We go into detail about where exactly you can find their base, the best way to reach the base and when you should take on the task of fighting the Team Star Dark Crew and their leader, Giancomo.

chapterContent.head: Where is the Dark Crew Located?

chapterContent.content: Team Star’s Dark Crew is located west from the massive, central crater. More precisely, their base is found a short distance south from the town of Cascarrafa, at the north-east corner of West Province (Area One).

To reach the Dark Crew’s base, we suggest venturing west from Mesagoza’s west gate. Make your way west through South Province (Area Two) towards the town of Cortondo. Halfway along, there’s a Pokémon Center you can use to rest.

From Cortondo, travel north-west, following the zigzagging trail, towards a bridge going across a river. Past the bridge, keep following the trail west to another Pokémon Center. Next, continue west for a short distance, then head north towards another bridge across a river.

After crossing this bridge, travel north-east, following the trail once more. There will be a Pokémon Center halfway between the bridge and the town of Cascarrafa. Before reaching Cascarrafa, there’s a trail going south-east that leads to the Dark Crew’s base.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Dark Crew?

chapterContent.content: We recommend attempting the Dark Crew when your Pokémon are above Level 20. Also, since your opponents will primarily use Dark  type Pokémon, you’ll want at least one or two Dark-type counters in your team.
In general, Fighting , Bug  and Fairy  Pokémon are recommended. In particular, we highly encourage bringing a Fighting  type.
Here are some suggestions:

chapterContent.li: Makuhita is a common Fighting  type found all across western and eastern Paldea.
Mankey is another common Fighting  type, found in western Paldea.
Flamigo is a Flying  and Fighting  type found in the ponds east from Los Platos.
Tarountula is a common Bug  type found in southern Paldea.
Nymble is a common Bug  type found in western Paldea.
Fidough is a Fairy  type found around Los Platos and the western outskirts of Mesagoza.
Tinkatink is a rare Fairy  and  Steel type found near ruins (one right near the Dark Crew base, another north-east from Cortondo).
If you evolve Pawmi (found in southern Paldea) into Pawmo, it gains the Fighting  type.

chapterContent.head: Attacking the Dark Crew’s Base

chapterContent.content: First things first, head straight for the barricade in front of the Dark Crew’s base. There will be two Grunts blocking the way. After some chit-chat, one of the Grunts will fight you.
For this, Electric , Rock , Ice  and Fairy  Pokémon have an advantage.
After kicking her butt, ring the doorbell at the gates when you’re ready to begin the gauntlet.

chapterContent.aside: Make sure to place your Dark-type counters in the first 3 slots of your team. Place a Fighting  type in the first slot, if possible.

chapterContent.content: In a Star Barrage, you must take on opposing Pokémon by auto-battling with . Simply press the button to throw your Pokémon; it will then target whatever is in front. You can send out up to three Pokémon simultaneously.

If your Pokémon take damage, you can speak to Clarv… Clive to heal your Pokémon. If any get knocked out and you’ve ran out of Revives, look for a vending machine. Finally, if it’s not looking good, you can press  to give up.
You’ll lose the Star Barrage if all of your Pokémon are KO’d or you run out of time before defeating the required amount of Pokémon. On this occasion, you have 10 minutes to defeat 30 Pokémon.

Team Star Grunts should send out their Pokémon when you’re somewhat near them. After beating up those Pokémon, keep moving, in search of other grunts. There should be more than enough Pokémon and more than enough time. We managed to clear within 2 minutes.
Here are the Pokémon we encountered:
If you’re up against Stunky, the common counters won’t be super-effective. But hopefully your Pokémon are strong enough. Otherwise, you could consider bringing a Ground  type along.
Against Pawniard, of the common counters, only Fighting  is super-effective. But these Pawniard aren’t exceptionally strong. Ground  is also good here, if you’re uncertain.
Versus Murkrow, hopefully you remember their weakness, from when you fought one outside the gates. Bug and Fighting deal neutral damage, while Fairy  remains super-effective.
Finally, if you’re combating Sableye, only Fairy  is super-effective, while Fighting deals no damage.
After conquering the Star Barrage, you’ll jump straight into a battle with their head honcho…

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Team Star's Dark Crew Leader, Giacomo

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Giacomo, Boss of Team Star’s Dark Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
You can fight Giacomo after completing the Star Barrage at the Dark Crew’s base in West Province (Area One), just south of the town of Cascarrafa (where the Water Gym is).

chapterContent.aside: You’ll battle Giacomo straight after the Star Barrage, so make you’re fully prepared before beginning the Star Barrage.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Giacomo

chapterContent.content: Your Pokémon team should ideally be Level 20 or higher for this battle.
In general, Fighting , Bug  and Fairy  Pokémon are recommended. In particular, we highly encourage leading with a  type.
For a list of recommended Pokémon species, please refer to the previous page.

chapterContent.head: Giacomo of the Team Star

chapterContent.content: Giacomo leads with Pawniard. If you were smart, you can easily one-shot with a Fighting  type. Since it takes quadruple damage from those moves. Fairy-types are at a disadvantage since it has Steel-type moves. Fire and Ground-types are also good here.
After Pawniard, this is where the battle really begins. Giacomo will send out a Revavroom, but it’ll be a Segin Starmobile, which is bulkier than usual and a pure Dark  type.
The Segin Starmobile seems to alternate between Metal Sound, which lowers your Special Defense, and Snarl, which deals Dark-type damage and lowers Special Attack.

What you want here is a Fighting  or Fairy  type that’s a physical attacker. This allows them to resist the damage from Snarl and prevent their damage output from dropping due to Snarl’s Special Attack reduction.

However, if your Pokémon keeps getting hit with Metal Sound, they might take substantial damage from Snarl. In which case, you should switch them to cancel the stat drops. This will also cancel the Special Attack drops from Snarl, if they’re a special attacker.
Tinkatink is a really good Pokémon to use, since it takes a quarter damage from Snarl. However it’s quite rare and only has special-based attacks until it reaches Level 35.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: For defeating Giacomo, you’ll receive a Star Badge from him and TM062 Foul Play. This teaches a Dark-type move that uses the foe’s Attack for inflicting damage.
While leaving the base, Cassiopeia will call you again, unlocking additional TMs that you can craft at the TM Machine. Also, their helper will supply you with some materials for crafting TMs.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat the Fire Crew in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to beat Team Star’s Fire Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We go into detail about where exactly you can find their base, the best way to reach the base and when you should take on the task of fighting the Team Star Fire Crew and their leader, Mela.

chapterContent.head: Where is the Fire Crew Located?

chapterContent.content: Team Star’s Fire Crew can be found in south-east Paldea. It’s a stone’s throw away from Artazon, where the Grass Gym is.
To reach the Fire Crew’s base, you’ll probably want to head east from Mesagoza’s east gate.
Follow the road through South Province (Area Three) to reach Artazon. This area looks a bit complicated from the map, but if you stick to the road, it’s very simple.
About one third of the way there, there’s a Pokémon Center where you can rest and restock. Two thirds of the way there, there’s a path leading to the Rock Titan.

Upon reaching Artazon, do what you need to do, then exit via the east gate. Follow the road north, through East Province (Area One), until you arrive at a nearby Pokémon Center. Afterwards, proceed west along the road to find the entrance to the Fire Crew’s base.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Fire Crew?

chapterContent.content: We recommend attempting the Dark Crew when your Pokémon are above Level 25. Also, since your opponents mainly use Fire  type Pokémon, you’ll want at least one or two Fire-type counters in your team.
In general, we highly recommend Water  and Rock  type Pokémon. Ground  is also super-effective, but doesn’t resist Fire like the other two.
Here are some suggestions:

chapterContent.li: Drednaw, a Water  and Rock  type found near rivers around east Paldea and north-west Paldea etc.
Psyduck, a silly Water  type found all over Paldea, near rivers and at wetlands. Especially if it has the Cloud Nine ability.

Most of the Water  types found around the East Paldean Sea (requires the Surf ability from the Flying Titan), such as:
Mareanie
Skrelp
Buizel and Floatzel
Finizen
Gyarados
Mareanie
Skrelp
Buizel and Floatzel
Finizen
Gyarados
Naclstack a Rock  type, evolved from Nacli or found in various parts of north Paldea, near beaches etc.
Klawf, a Rock  type common to South Province (Area Three), near Artazon side.

chapterContent.head: Attacking the Fire Crew’s Base

chapterContent.content: Approach the barricade to let your presence be known. The Grunt guarding the entrance will try and make you go home. No way, not after coming all this way.

Against this fearsome mutt, Water , Ground , Rock  and Fighting  are super-effective. It’s only one Pokémon so you shouldn’t struggle–and if you are struggling, that’s a sign you should come back when you’re better prepared.
When you regain control, ring the doorbell at the gates when you’re ready to begin the gauntlet.

chapterContent.aside: Make sure to place your Fire-type counters in the first 3 slots of your team. Ideally, your first Pokémon should be Rock  or have some way of dealing with Sunny Day.

chapterContent.content: In a Star Barrage, you must defeat opposing Pokémon by auto-battling with . Simply press the button to throw your Pokémon; it will then attack whatever is in front. You can send out up to three Pokémon simultaneously.

If your Pokémon take damage, you can speak to Clive to heal your Pokémon. If any get knocked out and you’ve ran out of Revives, look for a vending machine. Finally, if it’s not looking good, you can press  to give up.
You’ll lose the Star Barrage if all of your Pokémon are KO’d or you run out of time before defeating the required amount of Pokémon. On this occasion, you have 10 minutes to defeat 30 Pokémon.

Team Star Grunts should send out their Pokémon when you’re relatively close. After beating up those Pokémon, keep moving, in search of other grunts. There should be more than enough Pokémon and more than enough time. We managed to clear within 2 minutes.
Here are the Pokémon we encountered:
There’s not a lot of variety here.
As a reminder, Houndour is weak to Water , Ground , Rock  and Fighting .
Meanwhile Numel takes 4x damage from Water ; otherwise it takes regular 2x damage from Ground.
The other two–Torkoal and Growlithe–are pure Fire types, so take double damage from Water, Ground and Rock.
After whupping their butts, the boss lady of the Fire Crew will come to greet you.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Team Star's Fire Crew Leader, Mela

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Mela, Boss of Team Star’s Fire Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
You will fight Mela after completing the Star Barrage at the Fire Crew’s base in East Province (Area One), north-west of the town of Artazon (where the Grass Gym is).

chapterContent.aside: You’ll fight Mela straight after the Star Barrage, so make you’re fully prepared before beginning the Star Barrage.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Mela

chapterContent.content: Your Pokémon team should ideally be Level 25 or higher for this battle.

In general, Water , Rock  and Ground  Pokémon are recommended. Especially the first two, since they resist Fire. Of note, we suggest leading with a Rock  type or a Pokémon that can handle Sunny Day (weakens Water moves).
For a list of recommended Pokémon species, please refer to the previous page.

chapterContent.head: Mela of the Team Star

chapterContent.content: Mela leads with Torkoal. If you sent out a pure Water  type, you might be in trouble because Torkoal’s Drought ability summons Sunny Day, boosting the power of Fire attacks and weakening the power of Water attacks.

Hopefully you led with a Rock  type like we suggested; even Ground  is good. If you have a Water-type, you can still win by brute-forcing it, but make sure they’re not your only one because they’ll likely take a battering.

Alternatively, Psyduck can ignore the effects of Sunny Day if it has the Cloud Nine ability. Another thing you could try is using Rain Dance (learned by Gyarados at Level 28 etc. or TM) to turn the tables, weakening Fire attacks and boosting Water ones.

For her next Pokémon, Mela will send out a Revavroom, but it’ll be a Schedar Starmobile, which is bulkier than usual and a pure Fire  type. Each turn, its Speed will increase from its Speed Boost ability.

The Schedar Starmobile loves using Blazing Torque, a Fire attack with a high chance to Burn. Occasionally, it may use Screech to lower your Defense by two stages. On rare occasions, it can also use Overheat, a powerful Fire attack that lowers its Special Attack by two stages.

Pokémon that resist Fire-type attacks–namely Water  or Rock  will perform very well here. Physical attackers should be somewhat cautious of being burned, since it lowers Attack. Drednaw is amazing since it takes a quarter damage, but is susceptible to Burn.
If your Pokémon’s Defense has been impacted by Screech, remember that you can cancel the debuff by switching out. Just make sure to switch in a Pokémon that resists Fire.
Unless you’re seriously underleveled or brought the wrong Pokémon, this is a pretty one-note fight, despite Mela’s mean looks.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: After putting out Mela’s fire, you’ll receive a Star Badge from her and TM038 Flame Charge. This teaches a Fire-type attack that also boosts the user’s Speed.

While leaving the base, Cassiopeia will call you again, unlocking additional TMs that you can craft at the TM Machine. Also, their helper will supply you with various Pokémon materials for crafting TMs.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat the Poison Crew in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to beat Team Star’s Poison Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We go into detail about where exactly you can find their base, the best way to reach the base and when you should take on the task of fighting the Team Star Poison Crew and their leader, Atticus.

chapterContent.head: Where is the Poison Crew Located?

chapterContent.content: Team Star’s Poison Crew is located next to Tagtree Thicket, around north-east Paldea.

To reach the Poison Crew’s base, we suggest heading north-west from Levincia, where the Electric Gym is. To reach Levincia from Mesagoza, exit via the east gate and pass through South Province (Area Three) towards Artazon. Leave via the east gate of Artazon and follow the road north-west and eventually east.

At Levincia, exit via the north gate into East Province (Area Three). Follow the road north, then west. Halfway along, you can encounter the Steel Titan. At this point, travel west-north-west to reach a Pokémon Center outside Tagtree Thicket. The base entrance isn’t far from here.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Poison Crew?

chapterContent.content: We recommend attempting the Dark Crew when your Pokémon are above Level 33. Also, since your opponents mainly use Poison  type Pokémon, you’ll want at least one or two Pokémon that can handle them in your team.
In general, Ground  and Psychic  types are strong, while Steel  is immune from Poison damage.
Here are some suggestions:

chapterContent.li: Paldean Wooper or its evolved form Clodsire, both Poison  and Ground . You can find these around southern Paldea.
Mudbray or its evolved form Mudsdale, both Ground . You may find these in mountainous areas.
Gible or Gabite, both Dragon  and Ground . These wander inside Colonnade Hollow, east from Port Marinada.
Flittle or its evolved form Espathra, both Psychic . These are found in desert or mountainous areas.
Girafarig or its evolved form Farigiraf, both Normal  and Psychic . The former roams West Province (Area 2). You can then evolve it after Level 32, when it learns Twin Beam.
Bronzor or its evolved form Bronzong, both Steel  and Psychic . These are found near ruins–of note, there are Level 35 ish Bronzong at the ruins near Medali.

chapterContent.head: Attacking the Poison Crew’s Base

chapterContent.content: Walk towards the barricade to trigger a cutscene. If you decide to fight, a fellow student will run in to assist Team Star.
Two very weak Pokémon, so nothing to worry about. Unless you’ve wandered in at a low Level.
Gulpin is susceptible to the standard Ground  and Psychic  types. Shroodle is the same, but don’t bother using Ghost moves.
When you regain control, ring the doorbell at the gates to begin the gauntlet.

chapterContent.aside: Make sure to place your Poison-type counters in the first 3 slots of your team. Ideally, your first Pokémon should be Ground .

chapterContent.content: In a Star Barrage, you must defeat opposing Pokémon by auto-battling with . Simply press the button to throw your Pokémon; it will then attack whatever is in front. You can send out up to three Pokémon simultaneously.

If your Pokémon take damage, you can speak to Clive to heal your Pokémon. If any get knocked out and you’ve ran out of Revives, look for a vending machine. Finally, if it’s not looking good, you can press  to give up.
You’ll lose the Star Barrage if all of your Pokémon are KO’d or you run out of time before defeating the required amount of Pokémon. On this occasion, you have 10 minutes to defeat 30 Pokémon.

Team Star Grunts should send out their Pokémon when you’re relatively close. After beating up those Pokémon, keep moving, in search of other grunts. There should be more than enough Pokémon and more than enough time. We managed to clear within 2 minutes.
Here are the Pokémon we encountered:
Unlike the previous Star Barrage, there’s a decent variety of Pokémon here.
Seviper, Grimer, Gulpin and Swalot are pure Poison, so weak to the usual Ground  and Psychic  mons.
For Venonat and Venomoth, prioritize Psychic  over Ground. Fire , Rock  and Flying  are also great if you have them.
Shroodle and Grafaiai are in a similar boat to the first four.
Paldean Wooper and Clodsire have additional weaknesses in Water  and Ice .
Gastly and Haunter have additional weaknesses in Ghost  and Dark .
Finally, for Varoom, prioritize Ground  over Psychic. Fire  is also a great choice.
After proving your skills, the leader of the Poison Crew will show their face.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Team Star's Poison Crew Leader, Atticus

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Atticus, Boss of Team Star’s Poison Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. Atticus is a fairly challenging Poison-type trainer so be prepared to bring some good counters with you!
You can challenge Don Atticus after completing the Star Barrage at the Poison Crew’s base in Tagtree Thicket, accessible via East Province (Area Three.

chapterContent.aside: You’ll fight Atticus straight after the Star Barrage, so make you’re fully prepared before beginning the Star Barrage.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Atticus
