chapterContent.content: Your Pokémon team should ideally be Level 33 or higher for this battle.
In general, Ground  and Psychic  Pokémon are the way to go.
For a list of recommended Pokémon species, please refer to the previous page.

chapterContent.head: Atticus of the Team Star

chapterContent.content: If your Pokémon is a Psychic type, you’ve fallen for Atticus’s trap. Since Skuntank is part Dark , Psychic deals no damage. Only Ground  is super-effective. If you don’t have any for some reason, you’ll have to brute force it somehow.

Next, Atticus may send out Revavroom, but it’ll be a regular Revavroom this time and not the Starmobile. This time Psychic deals neutral damage, but it’s better than nothing. Meanwhile Ground  has a huge advantage, dealing 4x damage. Fire  is also great.
Muk is a pure Poison  type, so if you brought a Psychic  type, you could use them here. Or stick with your Ground type.

Finally, Atticus will bring out his Navi Starmobile. This part of the battle is a bit strange. The Navi Starmobile likes using Flame Charge to deal Fire-type damage and boost its Speed and Spin Out, a powerful Steel-type attack that lowers its Speed by two stages.
Your Ground  and Psychic  types should do very well here, although they may get worn down by the Starmobile’s Spin Out spam.
If you brought out a Steel-type for walling purposes, keep in mind that they’re susceptible to Flame Charge, although the damage shouldn’t be that much.

Of note, Water  Pokémon can resist both Flame Charge and Spin Out. Slowpoke and its evolved forms happen to be Water and Psychic . Meanwhile, Whiscash and Gastrodon are Water types that are also Ground .

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: After neutralizing Atticus’s toxins, you’ll receive a Star Badge from him and TM102 Gunk Shot. This teaches a powerful Poison-type attack.

While leaving the base, Cassiopeia will call you again, unlocking additional TMs that you can craft at the TM Machine. Also, their helper will supply you with various Pokémon materials for crafting TMs.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat the Fairy Crew in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Team Star’s Fairy Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We go into detail about where exactly you can find their base, the best way to reach the base and when you should take on the task of fighting Team Star’s Fairy Crew and their leader, Ortega.

chapterContent.head: Where is the Fairy Crew Located?

chapterContent.content: Team Star’s Fairy Crew is located at the northernmost area of Paldea, within North Province (Area Three).
The quickest, most direct way to reach the Fairy Crew is by cutting through Glaseado Mountain, in northern Paldea.
If you already completed the Ghost Gym, you can simply travel north-west from Montenevera, towards the North Province (Area Three) Pokémon Center. The journey is downhill, so should be very easy.

However, if you haven’t done the Ghost gym yet, start from Medali (where the Normal Gym is) and follow the road leading north-east. At one point, you’ll need to cross the river, but there should be a bridge. If there’s no bridge, use the Jump ability from the Steel Titan to leap across.

If that doesn’t work, try heading east from Medali instead, then go north where the signpost is, before entering Dalizapa Passage. Follow the mountain trail around until you reach the snowy part of Glaseado Mountain. Then climb up from there, towards Montenevera, perhaps.

By the way, if you obtained the Climb ability, from defeating the Dragon Titan, you can climb across Glaseado Mountain with minimal hassle. However, the Dragon Titan is higher Level than the Fairy Crew, so you may prefer to wait after beating the Fairy Crew instead.

Furthermore, if you have the Surf ability from the Flying Titan (can be obtained fairly early on), you can swim around the outer edge of Paldea, towards the northern shore. For example, by starting at Porto Marinada and traveling clock-wise. This will take a long time, but there won’t be much blocking your path.

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Fairy Crew?

chapterContent.content: We recommend fighting the Fairy Crew when your Pokémon are above Level 50. Also, since your opponents mainly use Fairy  type Pokémon, you’ll want multiple Pokémon that can handle them in your team.
In general, Poison  and Steel  types should be your go-to Pokémon here.
Here are some suggestions:

chapterContent.li: Revavroom, which is Poison  and Steel . You can find some in North Province (Area One). There’s also a Level 55 Tera somewhat nearby.
Grafaiai, a Poison  and Normal . There’s a Level 48 Tera at Tagtree Thicket.
Tinkaton, evolved from Tinkatuff, which can you find at the nearby ruins. This is a Fairy  and Steel  type with a great signature move: Gigaton Hammer.
Toxtricity, an Electric  and Poison  type found around Alfornada.
Copperajah, a pure Steel  type that you can catch at the nearby highlands.

chapterContent.head: Attacking the Fairy Crew’s Base

chapterContent.content: Like usual, approach the barricade to trigger a cutscene. If you decide to fight, your opponent will be a visiting instructor.
Despite being a dual type, Morgrem is weak to Poison  and Steel , so you should be sorted.
Hattrem isn’t a Fairy, so be wary. Batter it with a Dark , Bug  or Ghost  type.

chapterContent.aside: You should place your Fairy-type counters in the first 3 slots of your team. Ideally, your first Pokémon should be Poison .

chapterContent.content: You probably know the drill by now, but just in case…

In a Star Barrage, you must defeat opposing Pokémon by auto-battling with . Simply press the button to throw your Pokémon; it will then attack whatever is in front. You can send out up to three Pokémon simultaneously.

If your Pokémon take damage, you can speak to Clive to heal your Pokémon. If any get knocked out and you’ve ran out of Revives, look for a vending machine. Finally, if it’s not looking good, you can press  to give up.
You’ll lose the Star Barrage if all of your Pokémon are KO’d or you run out of time before defeating the required amount of Pokémon. On this occasion, you have 10 minutes to defeat 30 Pokémon.

Team Star Grunts should send out their Pokémon when you’re relatively close. After beating up those Pokémon, keep moving, in search of other grunts. There should be more than enough Pokémon and more than enough time. We managed to clear within 2 minutes.
Here are the Pokémon we encountered:
Versus Kirlia and Gardevoir, Ghost  is also great.
For the Impidimp line, stick with the common counters: Poison  or Steel .
Against Tinkatink and Tinkatuff, Steel is OK, but avoid Poison. Use Fire  or Ground  if you have them.
Jiggly, Wiggly and the bread dogs are weak to the common counters.
If facing Mimikyu, Poison is OK. Besides Steel , Ghost  is also strong.
Finally, Florges is another pure Fairy, so blast it with the common counters.
After making a right ruckus, the leader of the Fairy Crew will show their face.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Team Star's Fairy Crew Leader, Ortega

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Ortega, Boss of Team Star’s Fairy Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. Ortega is an experienced Fairy-type trainer so be prepared to bring some good counters with you!
You can challenge Ortega after completing the Star Barrage at the Fairy Crew’s base in North Province (Area Three), accessible via Glaseado Mountain

chapterContent.aside: You’ll fight the young master straight after the Star Barrage, so make you’re fully prepared before beginning the Star Barrage.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Ortega

chapterContent.content: Your Pokémon team should ideally be Level 50 or higher for this battle.
In general, you’ll want to bring along Poison  and Steel  types.
For a list of recommended Pokémon species, please refer to the previous page.

chapterContent.head: Ortega of the Team Star

chapterContent.content: Ortega leads with Azumarill. Steel-types merely deal neutral damage here; Poison  is the way to go. Grass  and Electric  are also great. But Grass should be mindful of Bounce. Also, physical attackers won’t like Charm, which greatly lowers Attack.

Next up may be Wigglytuff. The usual counters work here: Poison  and Steel . Likewise, it can use Charm to weaken physical attackers. Furthermore, if your Pokémon is male and its attack makes contact with Wigglytuff, it may fall in love!

Dachsbun is a pure Fairy-type, so susceptible to the usual Poison  and Steel . Similar to the two before it, it can weaken physical attackers by using Baby-Doll Eyes. This only lowers Attack by one stage, but it has increased priority.

chapterContent.aside: If any of your physical attackers have lowered Attack, you can switch them out to remove the stat drop.

chapterContent.content: Finally, Ortega will bring out his ride: a Fairy-type Starmobile. This one has the Misty Surge ability, which summons Misty Terrain when it enters battle, preventing status ailments. However, it may use Steel Roller, a Steel-type attack that removes terrain effects…

Additionally, it can use Confuse Ray to inflict confusion–probably the most annoying move it has. It can also use Spin Out, like the Poison Crew’s Starmobile–a strong Steel-type attack that greatly lowers its own Speed. Plus an actual Fairy attack: Magical Torque, which deals high damage and has a high chance of confuse. Ouch.

With that said, a solid Poison  or Steel  type should easily hold its ground. Now’s the ideal time to send your own Revavroom to laugh at its face. Besides that, a Fire  type can wall the Ruchbah Starmobile really good as well.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: After demolishing Ortega’s dreams (you jerk! Just kidding), you’ll receive a Star Badge from him and TM079 Dazzling Gleam. This teaches a Fairy-type attack that hits both opposing Pokémon during Double Battles.

While leaving the base, Cassiopeia will call you again, unlocking additional TMs that you can craft at the TM Machine. Also, their helper will supply you with various Pokémon materials for crafting TMs.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat the Fighting Crew in Scarlet & Violet

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Team Star’s Fighting Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. We go into detail about where exactly you can find their base, the best way to reach the base and when you should take on the task of fighting Team Star’s Fighting Crew and their leader, Eri.

chapterContent.head: Where is the Fighting Crew Located?

chapterContent.content: Team Star’s Fighting Crew is located at the north-east corner of Paldea, near North Province (Area 2).
The Fighting Crew’s base is kind of far away from most points of interest.

If you obtained the Climb ability, from the Dragon Titan, you don’t really need a guide at this point. Simply open the in-game map, navigate here, set it as your destination, then dash and climb your way there.
Otherwise, if you don’t have Climb, it’s a bit tricker.

If you’ve beaten the Ice Gym or at least visited, you should begin your journey from there. Simply head east, down the mountain. When the snowy part ends, there’s a watchtower you can stop by at. After that, keep going east, downhill, towards the Pokémon Center at North Province (Area One).

Next, go around from the south, to reach North Province (Area Two) where the bamboo trees are. From there, travel north-west towards the next Pokémon Center. The Fighting Crew’s base is located a short distance east.
If you haven’t visited the Ice Gym, make your way there first!

chapterContent.head: When to Fight the Fighting Crew?

chapterContent.content: We recommend fighting the Fairy Crew when your Pokémon are above Level 55. Also, since your opponents favor Fighting  type Pokémon, you’ll want multiple Pokémon that can handle them in your team.
Generally speaking, Flying , Psychic  and Fairy  Pokémon are the best medicine to deal with Fighting-types. Ghost  are also good because they’re immune to Fighting moves.
Here are some suggestions:

chapterContent.li: Mimikyu is a sneaky  and  type. You can catch a Tera one at a pond in North Province (Area Two).
Sylveon is the Fairy  evolution of Eevee. There’s a Tera one east of the Fairy Crew’s base.
Azumarill is a Water  and Fairy  type. You can encounter a Tera one at Casseroya Lake, north of where the Dragon Titan was.
Gyarados is a fearsome  and Flying  type. There’s a Tera One at Casseroya Lake as well, south-west from the Dragon Titan fight.
Veluza is a Water  and Psychic  type found throughout Casseroya Lake.
Espathra is a Psychic  type found around North Province (Area One).

chapterContent.head: Attacking the Fighting Crew’s Base

chapterContent.content: Like usual, approach the barricade to trigger a cutscene. If you decide to fight, your opponent will be a friend of the leader.
Don’t lead with a Fairy; instead, go with a Flying  or Psychic  type. Ground  also works.
Against Primeape, all three counters work: Flying , Psychic  and Fairy .
When you regain control, ring the door bell when you’re ready to properly begin the raid.

chapterContent.aside: You should place your Fighting-type counters in the first 3 slots of your team. Ideally, your first Pokémon should be Flying .

chapterContent.content: Most likely you know all about Star Barrages, but just in case…

In a Star Barrage, you must defeat opposing Pokémon by auto-battling with . Simply press the button to throw your Pokémon; it will then attack whatever is in front. You can send out up to three Pokémon simultaneously.

If your Pokémon take damage, you can speak to Clive to heal your Pokémon. If any get knocked out and you’ve ran out of Revives, look for a vending machine. Finally, if it’s not looking good, you can press  to give up.
You’ll lose the Star Barrage if all of your Pokémon are KO’d or you run out of time before defeating the required amount of Pokémon. On this occasion, you have 10 minutes to defeat 30 Pokémon.

Team Star Grunts should send out their Pokémon when you’re relatively close. After beating up those Pokémon, keep moving, in search of other grunts. There should be more than enough Pokémon and more than enough time. We managed to clear within 2 minutes.
Here are the Pokémon we encountered:
Against Gallade or Medicham, Psychic is OK. Flying  and Fairy  are still great. Ghost  also deserves a shout out.
Versus Crabominable, the three counters remain the superior choice: , Psychic  and Fairy . However, Flying should be somewhat careful.
If there’s a Hawlucha or Flamigo blocking your way, the three counters still work. But you also have the extra option of Electric .
For Toxicroak, Fairy is merely OK. Smash it with Flying , Psychic  or Ground .
Meanwhile, if you stumble upon a Breloom, you can rely on the same three counters or shake things up with some Fire .
Anything else on the list, they’re pure Fighting-types so stick with the good old three: , Psychic  and Fairy
After taking out the trash, the leader of the Fighting Crew will show their face again.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Team Star's Fighting Crew Leader, Eri

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Eri, Boss of Team Star’s Fighting Crew in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. Eri is a mighty Fighting-type trainer so be prepared to bring some good counters with you!
You can battle Eri after completing the Star Barrage at the Fighting Crew’s base near North Province (Area Two), east from Glaseado Mountain.

chapterContent.aside: You’ll fight Eri straight after the Star Barrage, so make you’re fully prepared before beginning the Star Barrage.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Eri

chapterContent.content: Your Pokémon team should ideally be Level 55 or higher for this battle.
In general, your team should have plenty of Flying , Psychic  and Fairy  types.
For a list of recommended Pokémon species, please refer to the previous page.

chapterContent.head: Eri of the Team Star

chapterContent.content: First up is Toxicroak. Keep your Fairy types away. Psychic  types are very strong here, but make sure they can survive Sucker Punch, which has increased priority if you choose an attacking move. Otherwise, Flying  and Ground  are great.
Next may be Passimian. This is a pure Fighting type, so nothing too tricky. Flying , Psychic  and Fairy  are all strong, but Flying types should be mindful of Rock Tomb.
Lucario can be tricky, since it’s part Steel. The three standard counters all deal neutral damage here. Instead, Fire , Fighting  and Ground  are super-effective.

Annihilape is a new evolution of Primeape, gaining the Ghost type. Flying , Psychic  and Fairy  remain strong and you have the extra option of Ghost  too. That said, Flying types should be careful of Ice Punch and Ghosts are susceptible to Rage Fist.

chapterContent.aside: When fighting Eri’s 4th Pokémon, it might help if you have a Pokémon that’s well suited to handle the Starmobile as well, since you don’t get a chance to switch after her 4th Pokémon is defeated.

chapterContent.content: Finally, Eri will send out her Caph Starmobile. It has the Stamina ability, which boosts its Defense stat when hit by an attack. We highly recommend fielding a special attacker, because if you let it stack Defense, it can get really bulky. Absolutely do not use any multi-hitting attacks like Bullet Seed.

For attacks, it can use Shift Gear to boost its Speed by two stages and Attack by one stage. Its signature attack is Combat Torque, a strong Fighting-type attack with a high chance to Paralyze. In addition, it can use High Horsepower, a strong Ground-type attack. Plus Spin Out, a strong Steel-type attack that lowers the user’s Speed.

The one thing you don’t want is for this fight to drag on. It’s easy for the Caph Starmobile to get tons of Defense boosts because of you attacking it, which will make it hard to defeat and give it more opportunities to use Shift Gear. Too many Shift Gears and your Pokémon will struggle to outspeed the Starmobile and likely get one-shot due to its boosted Attack.

If you have a special attacker, you can at least get around the Defense boosts. So it’s a matter of quickly finishing it off before it shifts gears too much. If push comes to shove, don’t hesitate to Terastallize to boost your damage output for your super-effective Pokémon.

Most Psychic  types should do fine, since most resist Combat Torque and many are special attackers. Fairy  types may need to be careful, if they’re susceptible to Spin Out. Flying  types should be careful too, as a lot more are physical attackers and some (if they’re also Normal, Ice, Rock or Steel) don’t resist Combat Torque.

chapterContent.head: After the Battle

chapterContent.content: After knocking Eri out of the ring, you’ll receive a Star Badge from her and TM167 Close Combat. This teaches an extremely powerful Fighting-type attack that lowers the user’s defensive stats.

While leaving the base, Cassiopeia will call you again, unlocking additional TMs that you can craft at the TM Machine. Also, their helper will supply you with various Pokémon materials for crafting TMs.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Team Star Clive Fight

chapterContent.content: At the end of the Team Star route, two extra fights remain. One is against Team Star’s leader, but before that, you will need to take on Clive, who is secretly Director Clavell. Depending on your team, this can be a rather tough fight to get through. Below we go over how to easily make your way through the fight, what Pokemon Clavell will use, and how to counter his team.

chapterContent.head: Starting Director Clavell’s Fight

chapterContent.content: Once you beat all five bosses of Team Star, the director will be waiting for you in front of the academy to fight. You can challenge him at any time during the day.

chapterContent.head: Clive’s Team

chapterContent.content: Director Clavell or Clive, has six Pokemon on his team covering a wide variety of types. The fight can be brutal if you don’t come prepared with proper counters for each Pokemon and medicine to cure status effects. In fact, grabbing a few full restore before battle may be a good idea.

Oranguru is a Normal/ Psychic type Pokemon that can use light screen to make your attacks less effective. He also has yawn, which will put you to sleep, along with Dream Eater, which will damage your Pokemon as they snooze. You can use a Bug or **Dark-type ** Pokemon to make quick work of him.

Abomasnow is his second Pokemon, an ice/grass-type, and it loves to use Wood Hammer, which will easily wipe out water and rocky-type Pokemon. The move does recoil damage as well. He also has Aurora Veil, which decreases the amount of damage you can deal to him. Along with this, Abomasnow has the ice-type move Blizzard. Luckily, a fire-type Pokemon can easily wipe out Abomasnow without breaking a sweat.

Next you will likely be facing Houndoom, a dark/fire-type. This Pokemon has the ability to poison you and has Thunder Fang, as well as Fire Blast. This makes him a generally well-rounded opponent, but he is weak to water-type moves. To avoid falling victim to Thunder Fang if your Pokemon isn’t quick, use a Ground, Rock, or fighting-type Pokemon.

Gyarados is a powerful flying/water-type Pokemon in Pokemon Scarlet and Pokemon Violet with a fatal flaw. It can easily be taken down by an electric-type move. Be wary as he does have earthquake and will lower your attack upon entering the battlefield. Use your fastest type Electric Pokemon to hit him hard and make short work of Gyrados.
Amoonguss is a grass/poison Pokemon. For this battle, you will need to avoid status effects, but this Pokemon can easily be dealt with using fire, psychic, flying, or ground-type Pokemon.

The next Pokemon that the director throws out will be the opposite starter of the one you chose. He will use his Tera Orb on them as well. Here is what each of the starters is weak to give you a good gauge of what Pokemon to use against it.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Team Star Cassiopeia Fight

chapterContent.content: The very last fight of the Team Star route puts you against the group’s boss. Surprisingly, this fight is much easier to tackle than you initially would have thought. Before going into it, though, you will want to have a bit of a strategy worked out to guarantee that you don’t lose. Below we go over how to start the final fight and the Pokemon types you need to bring with you in order to guarantee your victory.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Cassiopeia

chapterContent.content: Once you defeat Director Clavell, you will be able to challenge Cassiopeia. To do this, you must wait until night. This can take around 35 minutes of in-game time if it’s day currently. Once this is done, enter the academy and use one of the displays to move to the schoolyard for your final fight on the Team Star route.

chapterContent.head: Penny’s Team in Pokemon Scarlet and Pokemon Violet

chapterContent.content: Penny has a team made up of six different Eeveelutions. Below are all six along with what level they will be when you fight them.

Interestingly enough all of Penny’s Pokemon can use baby-doll eyes, which will lower your attack. The rest of their attacks are quite standard and easy to beat if you know basic type advantages. Eeveelutions aren’t necessarily weak, but they are only one type, which makes them pretty vulnerable with the right team. In fact, every one of Penny’s Pokemon can be easily countered and quickly wiped out. Here is what to counter every one of her Pokemon with.
Penny will use her Tera Orb on Sylveon, but as long as you have a poison of steel-type Pokemon, this won’t be an issue.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Enter Area Zero (The Great Crater of Paldea)

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to enter Area Zero, within the Great Crater of Paldea in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: What is Area Zero?

chapterContent.content: Area Zero is an isolated region located within the Great Crater of Paldea, in the very center of the map. It lies underneath the white clouds obscuring the view of what’s underneath.
Within Area Zero is a verdant, ethereal landscape inhabited by exceptional powerful Pokémon and also bizarre creatures known as Paradox Pokémon.

chapterContent.head: How to Enter Area Zero?

chapterContent.content: The only way to enter Area Zero is via the Zero Gate, located on the highlands south-east from Medali (where the Normal Gym is).
Access to the Zero Gate is barred until you’ve completed all three story paths:

chapterContent.li: Victory Road
Path of Legends
Starfall Street

chapterContent.aside: You cannot enter Area Zero before this point.

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve finished all three story paths, you’ll receive a call from Arven telling you to go to the Zero Gate.

Head to the Zero Gate, by traveling south-east from Medali. You can either use the Climb ability to ascend the cliff or follow the road from Medali’s south-east exit. There will be a passageway that was previously closed, which goes through the mountains, leading to the Zero Gate.

As you approach the Zero Gate, Arven will greet you. This will begin the Area Zero story “The Way Home.” After the cutscenes, walk forward and say you’re ready. You’ll then jump down towards Area Zero, on the back of Koraidon or Miraidon.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Professor Sada (Scarlet)

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Professor Sada at the end of Area Zero in Pokémon Scarlet. We’ll explain what Pokémon she uses, their moves and the best Pokémon to counter them!

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Professor Sada

chapterContent.content: Sada has a varied team of Paradox Pokémon, so you’ll need a varied team yourself. At the very least, we suggest bringing a Fairy and a Fighting type.
Your Pokémon should be Level 66 or higher, since Sada’s Pokémon are all Level 66 to start with.
Here are some Pokémon you could use, if you’re low on ideas:

chapterContent.li: The Level 75 Tera Lucario at Dalizapa Passage, in the underground tunnel. A good all-rounder that’s super-effective against two of Sada’s Pokémon.
The Level 65 Tera Garchomp at Colonnade Hollow. An excellent Ground type.
The Level 65 Tera Mimikyu at North Province (Area Two). A sneaky Ghost type that can absorb one hit with Disguise.
Corviknight, a Flying and Steel type. Common within Area Zero. Can wall Sada’s first Pokémon.
Farigiraf, a Normal and Psychic type. You can occasionally find them in Area Zero or evolve the Girafarig commonly found there.
Scream Tail, a Fairy and Psychic type common within Area Zero, especially towards the end. Sometimes you have to fight fire with fire!
Venomoth, Frosmoth or Volcarona, all Bug types found in Area Zero.

chapterContent.head: What Pokémon does Professor Sada have?

chapterContent.content: This ancient Volcarona is a Bug and Fighting type. For attacks, it can use Lunge to deal Bug damage and lower your Attack, Leech Life to deal Bug damage and restore its own health, Low Sweep to trip up heavy targets and Zen Headbutt just in case.
Flying types are ideal, since they deal quadruple damage. Fire and Fairy are also solid picks.
You already fought this ancient Jiggypuff before. Sada’s can use Play Rough and Zen Headbutt for STAB, Ice Punch for coverage and Drain Punch to combat Steel types and restore HP.
We recommend fielding a Ghost type. Steel is a bit risky because of Drain Punch.

Another ancient Pokémon that you fought along the way here. Sada’s can use Giga Drain for Grass STAB and to steal HP, Sucker Punch to try and attack first if you’re readying an attack move, Payback for increased damage if it goes second and Earth Power to punish Fire and Poison types.
Bug types are perfect, since they deal 4x damage. Ice, Fairy, Flying and Fighting are good choices too.

Yet another ancient Pokémon that you’re familiar with. Sada’s can use Shadow Ball for Ghost STAB, Mystical Fire to melt Steel types, Power Gem for additional coverage and Thunderbolt to remind you of Iono’s Mismagius.

No singular type is completely safe here. Options include fielding a Pokémon that’s Normal (to resist Shadow Ball) and a second type: Farigiraf and Grafaiai come to mind. Or a Pokémon with high Special Defense and/or can set up Light Screen.
It’s the Magneton on stilts! This one can use Discharge and Earth Power for STAB, plus Flash Cannon and Power Gem for general coverage.
Ground types are great here. Grass is also good.
Sada’s last Pokémon is an ancient Salamence, resembling its Mega form. She won’t Terastallize it, but it is holding a Booster Energy, which will trigger Protosynthesis, boosting its Attack stat.
For attacks, it’s got Dragon Claw and Night Slash for STAB, Stone Edge to smash Ice and Bug types and Earthquake for good measure.
Fairy types are its bane, dealing quadruple damage and resisting its STAB moves. Fighting also works.
After defeating Sada, it’s not quite over just yet. As you’ll face one more challenge!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Professor Turo (Violet)

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Professor Turo at the end of Area Zero in Pokémon Violet. We’ll explain what Pokémon he uses, their moves and the best Pokémon to counter them!

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Professor Turo

chapterContent.content: Turo has a varied team of Paradox Pokémon, so you’ll need a varied team yourself. At the least, you should bring an Electric, a Psychic and a Ground type.
Your Pokémon should be Level 66 or higher, since Turo’s Pokémon are all Level 66 to start with.
Here are some Pokémon you could use, if you’re low on ideas:

chapterContent.li: The Level 75 Tera Lucario at Dalizapa Passage, in the underground tunnel. A good all-rounder.
The Level 75 Tera Dragonite at the eastern edge of Paldea. Has great raw power.
The Level 65 Tera Garchomp at Colonnade Hollow. An excellent Ground type.
The Level 65 Eelektross on an island towards the far north-east. A slow Electric type, but gets the work done.
The Level 60 Tera Raichu on an island north-west from Porto Marinada. Not the strongest Pokémon around, but good if you need an alternative or additional Electric type.
Corviknight, a Flying and Steel type. Common within Area Zero. Can wall Turo’s last Pokémon.
Farigiraf, a Normal and Psychic type. You can occasionally find them in Area Zero or evolve the Girafarig commonly found there.

chapterContent.head: What Pokémon does Professor Turo have?

chapterContent.content: This futuristic Volcarona can use Fiery Dance and Sludge Wave for STAB, Discharge to counter Water types and Air Slash for extra coverage. Also keep in mind that Fiery Dance has a 1/2 chance of boosting Iron Moth’s Special Attack.
Ground types are definitely the way to go, for the 4x damage. Rock and Psychic are also great.

You’ve fought these robo-Delibird before. Turo’s one can use Freeze-Dry and Water Pulse for STAB, Drill Peck to hurt Grass and Fighting types and Snowscape to summon snow. Freeze-Dry is also super-effective on Water types. During snow, Ice type Pokémon gain boosted Defense.
We recommend a reliable Electric type for this.

You should be familiar with this Hariyama from the future. Turo’s one can use Drain Punch and Thunder Punch for STAB, Iron Head to make Fairy types dizzy and Fake Out for a turn one flinch. As a reminder, Drain Punch also heals Iron Hand.
Ground or Psychic types are the safest bets here.
Again, another Paradox that you fought to get here. Turo’s one can use Dark Pulse and Air Slash for STAB, Flash Cannon to dazzle Rock and Fairy types and Flamethrower to melt Ice types.
This is another job for an Electric type.
Iron Thorns is a futuristic looking Tyranitar. This one can use Stone Edge and Thunder Punch for STAB, Brick Break to shatter screens and Earthquake for general coverage.
Ground types are ideal, since they deal quadruple damage. Fighting and Grass should work well too.
This mechanized Gallade is Turo’s final Pokémon. He won’t Terastallize it, but it’s holding a Booster Energy, which will trigger Quark Drive, boosting its Attack stat.

Attack-wise, it can use Spirit Break for Fairy STAB and to lower your Special Attack, Brick Break for Fighting STAB and to break screens, Psycho Cut to deter Poison types and Poison Jab to hurt opposing Fairy types.
Flying and Psychic types will reign supreme here. Gyarados is great for triggering Intimidate to lower Iron Valiant’s Attack back to normal levels.
After defeating Turo, it’s not quite over just yet. As you’ll face one more challenge!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Koraidon, the Guardian of Paradise (Scarlet)

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to beat Koraidon, the Guardian of Paradise, at the end of Area Zero in Pokémon Scarlet.
After defeating Professor Sada the first time, they will become desperate and send out the second Koraidon.

chapterContent.head: Best Strategy for Koraidon, the Guardian of Paradise

chapterContent.aside: In this fight, you cannot use any of your own Pokémon!

chapterContent.content: When the opportunity arises, select “Pokémon” from the menu and go all the way down to the only Pokémon you can use: Koraidon!
Encouraged by you and your friends, your Koraidon will transform into its battle form. Now the fight can properly begin!
At the start of the fight, the opposing Koraidon’s Orichalcum Pulse ability will trigger, causing harsh sunlight. This sunlight will boost the Attack of the opposing Koraidon and your own Koraidon.
For attacks, we suggest using Collision Course, Koraidon’s signature move. Although Flamethrower is boosted by the sunlight, it’s not effective against the opposing Koraidon.
You’ll notice that Collision Course will take off around 1/10 of the opponent’s health. It’s not a lot, but it’s something. Keep spamming Collision Course for now.

Meanwhile, your opponent can use Taunt to stop you using non-attacking moves (namely Endure), Bulk Up to boost its Attack and Defense, Flamethrower to deal OK damage and Giga Impact for big damage but requires recharging afterwards.

When hit by Giga Impact, you’ll drop to 1 HP. However, on the next turn, your Koraidon’s Attack will rise by 2 stages and the opposing Koraidon will be immobile. If you didn’t use Collision Course during every turn, use a Max Potion or Full Restore to heal. Otherwise, skip healing and use Collision Course for the last time.

The next turn, your Tera Orb will gain energy and all of your Koraidon’s stats will increase. Now Terastallize your Koraidon and pick Tera Blast! Your Koraidon should outspeed its opponent and KO it with the Tera-boosted, super-effective damage. Note that if you didn’t use Collision Course the full 5 times, you may be shy of a KO.

chapterContent.head: After the Fight

chapterContent.content: Triumph against the Guardian of Paradise and the curtains will close on the story. After the credits roll, you’ll return to your room in the academy, ready for postgame adventures!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Miraidon, the Guardian of Paradise (Violet)

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to beat Miraidon, the Guardian of Paradise, at the end of Area Zero in Pokémon Violet.
After defeating Professor Turo the first time, they will become desperate and send out the second Miraidon.

chapterContent.head: Best Strategy for Miraidon, the Guardian of Paradise

chapterContent.aside: In this fight, you’re prevented from using any of your own Pokémon!

chapterContent.content: When the opportunity arises, select “Pokémon” from the menu and go all the way down to the only Pokémon you can use: Miraidon!
Encouraged by you and your friends, your Miraidon will transform into its battle form. Now the real fight begins!

At the start of the fight, the opposing Miraidon’s Hadron Engine ability will trigger, creating Electric Terrain. The electricity will boost the Special Attack of the opposing Miraidon and your own Miraidon.
For attacks, we suggest using Power Gem or Tera Blast. They’re not ideal, but Electro Drift–its signature move–deals a pathetic quarter damage to the opposing Miraidon.
Power Gem and Tera Blast will take off around 1/10 of the opponent’s health. It’s not a lot, but it’s something. Keep using these attacks for now.

Meanwhile, your opponent can use Taunt to stop you using non-attacking moves (namely Endure), Charge to boost its Special Defense, Power Gem to deal OK damage and Hyper Beam for big damage but requires recharging afterwards.

When hit by Hyper Beam, you’ll drop to 1 HP. However, on the next turn, your Miraidon’s Special Attack will rise by 2 stages and the opposing Miraidon will be immobile. If you didn’t use Power Gem or Tera Blast during every turn, use a Max Potion or Full Restore to heal. Otherwise, skip healing and use one of those two moves again.

The next turn, your Tera Orb will gain energy and all of your Miraidon’s stats will increase. Now Terastallize your Miraidon and pick Tera Blast! Your Miraidon should outspeed its opponent and KO it with the Tera-boosted, super-effective damage. Note that if you didn’t use Power Gem or Tera Blast all the time, you may be shy of a KO.

chapterContent.head: After the Fight

chapterContent.content: Triumph against the Guardian of Paradise and the curtains will close on the story. After the credits roll, you’ll return to your room in the academy, ready for postgame adventures!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Defeat Bug Gym Leader Katy (Rematch)

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Katy, the Bug Gym Leader, during her rematch in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.

chapterContent.head: How to Rematch Katy

chapterContent.content: You can rematch Katy after completing the Area Zero story (after seeing the credits roll) and visiting the Director’s Office at Naranja/Uva Academy. Geeta will ask you to visit the eight gyms of Paldea in her place, as part of an inspection. During this time, you can challenge the gym leaders at their full power!

chapterContent.aside: If you’re searching for the very first battle with Katy, during the Victory Road story, please go here instead.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Katy During Her Rematch

chapterContent.content: Katy still uses Bug type Pokémon, so we recommend bringing Fire, Rock and Flying types.
Her Pokémon are all Level 65-66, so your Pokémon should be Level 65+ to match.
If you need some ideas, here are some suggestions:

chapterContent.li: The Level 75 Tera Dragonite at the far eastern edge of Paldea. High Level with exceptional Attack. You can use its Hurricane or relearn Wing Attack, which is weaker, but more accurate and runs off Dragonite’s superior Attack stat.
Chi-Yu, a Legendary Pokémon that’s Dark and Fire type, located in one of the sealed shrines.
Corviknight, a Flying and Steel type common in Area Zero.
Volcarona, a Bug and Fire type found in Area Zero.
If playing Pokémon Violet, Iron Moth and/or Iron Jugulis, Paradox Pokémon found in Area Zero.

chapterContent.head: What Pokémon does Katy Use During Her Rematch?

chapterContent.content: This time, Katy has evolved her Nymble and it’s no longer a complete pushover (just a minor one). It can use Lunge for Bug STAB and to lower your Attack, Sucker Punch for Dark STAB and to try and go first if you’re using an attacking move, Axe Kick to punch through Rock and Ice types etc. and Bounce to fly up for 1 turn.

Fire, Flying, Bug and Fairy types should have an easy time here. The main thing to watch out for is Sucker Punch, which has increased priority if you use an attacking move. If you’re both on low HP, don’t attack thinking you can win, unless you’re using something like Extreme Speed.

Forretress acts as a wall, although it’s not too annoying. It can use Bug Bite and Gyro Ball for STAB, Stone Edge to tickle Fire types and Curse to lower its Speed, but raise its Attack and Defense. It also has the Sturdy ability, preventing one-shots.

Fire types will deal the most damage for sure, but they’re susceptible to Stone Edge. Keep in mind that Forretress has Sturdy, so you won’t be one-shotting them either. Excluding Fire, Forretress has no other weaknesses, but it’s not particularly strong, so you can probably outlast it with neutral choices. Just remember to focus on special attacks, due to its high Defense.

Katy has also evolved her Tarountula into this creeper critter. It can use Skitter Smack for Bug STAB and to lower your Special Attack, Silk Trap to shield itself from damage and lower your Attack if you make contact, Brick Break to punish Rock types and shatter barriers and Throat Chop to disable sound-based moves.
Since it’s a pure Bug type, Fire and Flying types will make quick work of it. Rock types are, of course, weak to Brick Break. That said, if they have high Defense, it shouldn’t do too much damage.
Heracross excels at punching holes. It’s carrying Megahorn and Close Combat, both powerful STAB moves, plus Stone Edge to bash in Fire and Flying types and Night Slash to cut through Psychic types.
Flying types deal quadruple damage, but are weak to Stone Edge. Use them only if they’re faster than Heracross or bulky enough to take a hit. Fairy types may be a safer choice.

Finally, Katy will Terastallize her Ursaring, evolved from Teddiursa. Watch out for Fury Cutter, which deals more damage with continued use, High Horsepower to crush Fire and Rock types, Play Rough to counter confused Fighting types and Crunch for additional coverage.
We suggest using Flying types, especially if Terastallized. That way, they can resist STAB Fury Cutter and take neutral/no damage from Ursaring’s other non STAB boosted moves.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Beat Arven (Academy Ace Tournament)

chapterContent.content: This is a guide for defeating Arven during the Academy Ace Tournament in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet.
Arven is one of the trainers you can fight in the Academy Ace Tournament. In the very first tournament, he will always be your Round 1 opponent.

chapterContent.head: What is the Academy Ace Tournament?

chapterContent.content: The Academy Ace Tournament is a single elimination tournament, consisting of 4 rounds, that you can participate in during the postgame. Your opponents will be trainers and faculty members from Naranja/Uva Academy.
To unlock the Academy Ace Tournament, you must complete the Area Zero story, perform the Gym Inspection for Geeta and report the results to her back at Naranja/Uva Academy.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Pokémon for Arven (Academy Ace Tournament)

chapterContent.content: Arven uses the same team from his final fight during the Path of Legends story, but his Pokémon are higher Level: 66 to 67, to be precise. Ideally, you’ll want a varied team of Level 66+ Pokémon.
Here are some recommendations, if you need help:

chapterContent.li: The Level 75 Tera Lucario at Dalizapa Passage, in the underground tunnel. Can easily take out 4 of Arven’s Pokémon, at least.
The Level 75 Tera Dragonite, north-east from Levincia. To deal with the remaining 2 Pokémon.
Chien-Pao, a powerful Dark and Ice Legendary, found in one of the sealed shrines.

chapterContent.head: What Pokémon Does Arven (Academy Ace Tournament) Use?

chapterContent.content: First up is Greedent, an oversized squirrel. Like before, it can use Body Slam for Normal STAB and to potentially paralyze, Psychic Fangs to scare Fighting types, Bullet Seed to punch through Rock types and Earthquake to shake Steel types.
Despite Psychic Fangs, Fighting is the best choice here; Close Combat can do some hefty damage. Ghost may also work, since they’re immune to Body Slam, provided you have non Ghost moves.

Cloyster has high Defense, but abysmal Special Defense. Like last time, it’s carrying Liquidation and Icicle Spear for STAB, Rock Blast for additional coverage and Light Screen to weaken your special moves. Thanks to its Skill Link ability, Icicle Spear and Rock Blast will always hit 5 times.
Electric and Fighting are the safest options. Lucario with Aura Sphere is great to take advantage of Cloyster’s poor Special Defense.
The double headed pepper creature returns! It has the same moves as before: Energy Ball and Fire Blast for STAB, plus Zen Headbutt to counter Poison types and Crunch for general coverage.
Flying types are ideal. Poison types may also work, if they’re strong enough or their name is Skuntank (who’s immune to Zen Headbutt).
Toedscruel can be somewhat tricky if you lower your guard. It can use Earth Power and Power Whip for STAB, Sludge Bomb to hit opposing Grass types and Spore for guaranteed Sleep.
Ice types are its bane, dealing quadruple damage. Fire, Flying and Bug types should also do well here. If you get hit by Spore, cure it ASAP with a Full Heal etc.

The giant salt golem makes a reappearance. Its moveset is also unchanged: Stone Edge for hard-hitting STAB, Earthquake to hinder Steel types, Body Press for additional coverage and Stealth Rock to damage switch-ins.
Take it out with a reliable Grass, Water, Ground or Steel type.

Finally, Arven will send out his trusty Mabosstiff and Terastallize it. It can use Crunch for Tera and STAB-boosted damage, Psychic Fangs to annoy Fighting types, Fire Fang to scorch Bug types and Play Rough as another means of annoying Fighting types. Its Intimidate ability will also lower your Pokémon’s Attack when it enters battle.
We highly recommend a Fairy type, since they’re super-effective and resist Crunch, Mabosstiff’s strongest move.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Where to Find All Asado Desert Trainers

chapterContent.content: Due to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet being a true open world Pokémon experience, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every trainer within the Asado Desert area.

chapterContent.head: Asado Desert Trainer Rewards

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve found and defeated at least five Trainers within the Asado Desert, speak with the Pokemon League Rep who can be found at the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center for a reward. Here you’ll receive the Earthquake TM which will allow you to teach your Pokemon the Ground  Type Attack Earthquake. If you’re struggling to find the Trainers in this area, then you can see their locations below:

chapterContent.head: All Asado Desert Trainers

chapterContent.aside: We’ve come across 7 trainers in the Asado Desert so far, but if we find anymore then we’ll update this page with their location!

chapterContent.content: Start at the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center, then head west and hug the left wall until you come across Ismael the Student standing beside a rock
Start at the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center and walk northwest and you’ll find Raquel the Student standing out in the open.
Start at the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center, then head west and hug the left wall until you come across Claudia the Musician standing out in the open between two large rocks.

Start at the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center and dash through the Asado Desert until you reach the exit that leads to Porto Marinada. Here you’ll find Gregorio the Poke Maniac standing out in the open at the top of the hill.
Start at the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center and dash through the Asado Desert until you reach the Watchtower, then continue running west and you’ll find Renardo standing close to the rock.
Start at the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center and head west and hug the left wall until you pass Ismael the Student and Claudia, then you should find Belran standing beside the second large rock.
Start at the Cascarrafa (North) Pokemon Center and dash through the Asado Desert until you reach the Watchtower, then continue running west and you’ll pass Beltran. From here, continue running

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Where to Find All East Province Area 2 Trainers

chapterContent.content: Due to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet being a true open world Pokémon experience, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every trainer within the East Province Area 2 area.

chapterContent.head: East Province Area 2 Trainer Rewards

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve found and defeated at least six Trainers within the East Province Area 2, speak with the Pokemon League Rep who can be found at the Levincia (South) Pokemon Center for a reward. Here you’ll receive the Stomping Tantrum TM which will allow you to teach your Pokemon the Ground  Type Attack Stomping Tantrum. If you’re struggling to find the Trainers in this area, then you can see their locations below:

chapterContent.head: All East Province Area 2 Trainer

chapterContent.aside: We’ve come across 9 trainers in the East Province Area 2 so far, but if we find anymore then we’ll update this page with their location!

chapterContent.content: Start from the Levincia (South) Pokemon Center and walk across the bridge and you’ll find Cristian the Office Worker standing over to the left of the path.
Start from the Levincia (South) Pokemon Center and walk across the bridge, then head east towards the beach to find Backpacker Jonathan standing out in the open.
Start from the Levincia (South) Pokemon Center and walk across the bridge, then head east towards the beach to find Anas the Student standing near the ocean.
Start from the Levincia (South) Pokemon Center and walk across the bridge, then continue running along the path to the south and you’ll find Lina standing at the bottom of a small hill.
Return to the path and continue heading west and you’ll find Backpacker Arturo standing over on the right side of the path.
Continue along to the west and you’ll find Cabbie Omar standing over to the left side of the path.
Proceed further along the path and head towards the East Province (Area Two) Pokemon Center and you’ll find Beatriz the Student standing over on the right side of the path.

Cross over to the top portion of East Province Area 2 and climb up onto the large cliff on the left. If you dont have access to climb yet, then you’ll need to defeat Dondozo, the False Dragon Titan which is level 55 Water  Type. Once you’ve climbed up you can find Rebeca the Dragon Tamer standing in the center of the area.
From Rebeca the Dragon Tamers location, jump down and sprint east through the area and you’ll find Rosario standing near a tree.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Where to Find All Dalizapa Passage Trainers

chapterContent.content: Due to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet being a true open world Pokémon experience, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every trainer within the Dalizapa Passage area.

chapterContent.head: Dalizapa Passage Trainer Rewards

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve found and defeated at least four Trainers within the Dalizapa Passage, speak with the Pokemon League Rep who can be found at the [Dalizapa Passage Pokemon Center](https://www.gamerguides.com/pokemon-scarlet-and-violet/maps/paldea-region-map#26309 “Dalizapa Passage Pokemon Center’) for a reward. Here you’ll receive the Expert Belt which boosts any Super Effective Moves when held. If you’re struggling to find the Trainers in this area, then you can see their locations below:

chapterContent.head: All Dalizapa Passage Trainers

chapterContent.aside: We’ve come across 6 trainers in the Dalizapa Passage so far, but if we find anymore then we’ll update this page with their location!

chapterContent.content: Start at the Zapapico (West) Pokemon Center and follow the path north to find Sara the Musician standing on the right side of the path.
Continue following the path along and take the right path at the crossroads to find Teo the Student standing to the right of the path just before the cave entrance.
Enter the cave and follow the tunnel along and you’ll find Mihai the Student standing on the right.
From the Dalizapa Passage Pokemon Center head up the hill to the north and you’ll find Hiker Helana standing by a rock wall to the left.
From Hiker Helena’s location run up to the top of the hill and you’ll find Sandra standing on the left side of the path.
From Sandra’s location, continue heading up the hill and you’ll find Hiker Leire standing over to the left just before the exit.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Where to Find All North Province Area 3 Trainers

chapterContent.content: Due to Pokémon Scarlet & Violet being a true open world Pokémon experience, there is plenty to see and discover in the region of Paldea. This page will give you all the details on where to find every trainer within the North Province Area 3.

chapterContent.head: North Province Area 3 Trainer Rewards

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve found and defeated at least four Trainers within the North Province Area 3, speak with the Pokemon League Rep who can be found at the North Province (Area Three) Pokemon Center for a reward. Here you’ll receive the Leaf Storm TM which will allow you to teach your Pokemon the Grass  Type Attack Leaf Storm. If you’re struggling to find the Trainers in this area, then you can see their locations below:

chapterContent.head: All North Province Area 3 Trainers

chapterContent.aside: We’ve come across 6 trainers in the North Province Area 3 so far, but if we find any more then we’ll update this page with their location!

chapterContent.content: Start at the North Province (Area Three) Pokemon Center and head north to find Desiree standing to the right of the water.
Start at the North Province (Area Three) Pokemon Center and head northeast to find Ester the Office Worker standing over to the right of the path.
Continue heading east from Esters location and you’ll find Tatiana standing in the corner.
Return to the North Province (Area Three) Pokemon Center and this time you’ll want to head northwest and then hug the wall and walk along a narrow path to find Jordi the Poké Maniac.
Continue heading west and then drop down onto the beach below to find Stefan standing out in the open.
Walk along the beach to the east and jump across the water to find Jimena the Student.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Find & Catch Wo-Chien

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to encounter and catch Wo-Chien, one of the Legendary Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet.
Wo-Chien is a Ruinous Pokémon and a member of the Legendary quartet known as the “Treasures of Ruin”.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Wo-Chien

chapterContent.content: Wo-Chien is sealed behind the purple shrine in South Province (Area One), east-south-east from Los Platos.
To release the seal, you must remove 8 purple stakes scattered throughout south-east Paldea. For their precise locations, please refer to our Purple Stakes page.
After doing so, there will be a message saying that a sound is coming from the shrine. Inspect the seal on the shrine (after saving your game first!) to encounter Wo-Chien.

chapterContent.li: All Purple Stake Locations
Purple Shrine Map Marker

chapterContent.head: How to Catch Wo-Chien

chapterContent.content: At the start of the fight, Wo-Chien’s Tablets of Ruin ability will trigger, lowering the Attack of all Pokémon except itself.
Stat-wise, Wo-Chien has exceptional Special Defense, great Defense and otherwise solid stats, except it’s obviously slow since it’s a snail.

The one you’re facing can use Giga Drain and Power Whip for Grass STAB, Ruination to halve your HP and Foul Play to deal damage based on your Pokémon’s Attack stat. Giga Drain will also restore Wo-Chien’s HP according to the damage it deals.

You might’ve gotten away with it earlier, but you’ll almost definitely need to inflict a status ailment for this fight. Paralyze is very simple and lasts forever–you can use moves like Nuzzle, Thunder Wave or Glare. Sleep has better odds, but only lasts a few turns–if you must, use moves like Hypnosis or Yawn; Spore and Sleep Powder do not work on Grass types.

When damaging Wo-Chien, avoid Bug type moves since they deal quadruple damage. Regular super-effective moves are OK, since Wo-Chien is bulky and Tablets of Ruin lowers Attack. As Wo-Chien’s HP begins falling though, you should swap to False Swipe (obtained from Jacq, your homeroom teacher) so you don’t accidentally KO Wo-Chien.

There’s a good chance you’ll experience a tug of war between Wo-Chien using Giga Drain to steal HP and you using False Swipe to keep its HP low. It may help using X Sp. Def to boost your Pokémon’s Special Defense, to reduce the damage (and thus HP recovery) from Giga Drain.

When it’s time to start throwing Poké Balls, Ultra Balls are the straightforward choice. If you’re battling when it’s night time, Dusk Balls are a better choice. If more than 10 turns have passed, Timer Balls are the best choice. If Wo-Chien is asleep, Dream Balls are also great, but you probably don’t have many of those.

A Pokémon that resists Grass would be extremely helpful here. Even better if they take a quarter damage, like Dragonite for instance. This will let your Pokémon survive Giga Drain and Power Whip, while reducing the HP healed from Giga Drain.

If you have a bit of spare time, Kingambit is a great Pokémon to use, since it resists all of Wo-Chien’s moves, minus Ruination, which deals fixed damage. It can also use False Swipe. Plus Iron Defense to protect itself from Power Whip and Foul Play.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Find & Catch Chien-Pao

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to encounter and catch Chien-Pao, one of the Legendary Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet.
Chien-Pao is a Ruinous Pokémon and a member of the Legendary quartet known as the “Treasures of Ruin”.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Chien-Pao

chapterContent.content: Chien-Pao is sealed behind the orange shrine in West Province (Area One), north-west from the central Pokémon Center
To release the seal, you must remove 8 orange stakes dotted around south-west Paldea. For their precise locations, please refer to our Orange Stakes page.
After doing so, there will be a message saying that a sound is coming from the shrine. Inspect the seal on the shrine (after saving your game first!) to encounter Chien-Pao.

chapterContent.li: All Orange Stake Locations
Orange Shrine Map Marker

chapterContent.head: How to Catch Chien-Pao

chapterContent.content: At the start of the fight, Chien-Pao’s Sword of Ruin ability will activate, lowering the Defense of all Pokémon except itself.
Stat-wise, Chien-Pao has exceptional Speed and Attack, and otherwise OK stats, excluding its low Special Defense.

For attacks, it can use Sacred Sword to deal Fighting damage that ignores stat boosts, Sucker Punch to try and attack first if you’re using an attacking move (otherwise it fails), Ruination to halve your HP and Icicle Crash for Ice STAB and chance to flinch.

Like the other Legendaries, Chien-Pao has a very low catch rate. So you should inflict a status ailment to improve your success rate. Paralyze is nice and easy, since it doesn’t disappear–you can apply it with Nuzzle, Thunder Wave or Glare, etc. Sleep has better odds, but only lasts a few turns–you can use moves like Hypnosis or Yawn to apply it.

When damaging Chien-Pao, avoid Fighting type moves since they deal quadruple damage. Regular super-effective attacks are fine, so long as they’re weak ones. As Chien-Pao’s HP begins to fall, you should swap to False Swipe (obtained from Jacq, your homeroom teacher) so you don’t accidentally KO it.

Fortunately, Chien-Pao cannot heal itself, so once you’ve got it down to low or 1 HP, you can relax somewhat. However, Chien-Pao can inflict a lot of damage with its moves, so don’t hesitate to use healing items yourself! If you’re taking big damage, X Defense can help reduce the impact. But keep in mind Ruination doesn’t care about this.

When it’s time to start throwing Poké Balls, Ultra Balls are great by default. When it’s night time, Dusk Balls are a better choice. If more than 10 turns have passed, Timer Balls are the best choice. If Chien-Pao is asleep, Dream Balls are also great, but those are on the rare side.

A Pokémon that resists Icicle Crash would be great here. If you chose Fuecoco, Skeledirge is perfect since it resists Icicle Crash and is immune to Sacred Sword. But only field it for walling purposes, because it’s weak to Sucker Punch. (If you don’t attack, Sucker Punch doesn’t work.)

Ceruledge is another great choice, if you’re playing Pokémon Violet or can trade with somebody. It too can resist Icicle Crash and is immune to Sacred Sword, plus it can learn False Swipe. Otherwise, Mimikyu with X Defense is good and, unlike the other two, isn’t weak to Sucker Punch.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Find & Catch Ting-Lu

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to encounter and catch Ting-Lu, one of the Legendary Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet.
Ting-Lu is a Ruinous Pokémon and a member of the Legendary quartet known as the “Treasures of Ruin”.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Ting-Lu

chapterContent.content: Ting-Lu is sealed behind the green shrine at Socarrat Trail, north of Casseroya Lake.
To release the seal, you must remove 8 green stakes dotted around north-west Paldea. For their precise locations, please refer to our Green Stakes page.
After doing so, there will be a message saying that a sound is coming from the shrine. Inspect the seal on the shrine (after saving your game first!) to encounter Ting-Lu.

chapterContent.li: All Green Stake Locations
Green Shrine Map Marker

chapterContent.head: How to Catch Ting-Lu

chapterContent.content: At the start of the fight, Ting-Lu’s Vessel of Ruin ability will trigger, lowering the Special Attack of all Pokémon except itself.
In terms of stats, Ting-Lu has incredible HP and Defense, great Attack and good Special Defense, but poor Speed and Special Attack.

For attacks, it can use Stomping Tantrum for Ground STAB, Throat Chop for Dark STAB and to disable sound-based attacks, Ruination to halve your HP and Rock Slide to scare Flying types. Beware that Stomping Tantrum becomes stronger if one of its previous attacks failed. This can be from Rock Slide/Ruination missing or being paralyzed.

Ting-Lu has a very low catch rate, so you should inflict a status ailment to improve your chances. This should be Paralyze or Sleep, unless you like gambling with Burn and Poison. Sleep has better odds, but lasts a few turns; you can apply it with Hypnosis, Yawn etc. Paralyze is less effective, but lasts forever; you can apply it using Glare, etc.

When damaging Ting-Lu, super-effective attacks are fine, as long as they’re not super strong (100+ base power), since Ting-Lu is incredibly bulk. As Ting-Lu’s HP begins to fall, you may wish to swap to False Swipe (obtained from Jacq, your homeroom teacher) so you don’t accidentally KO it.

Luckily, Ting-Lu cannot heal itself, so once you’ve got it down to low or 1 HP, you can relax a bit. However, Ting-Lu can still deal hefty damage, so don’t hesitate to use healing items yourself. If you’re taking heavy damage, X Defense can help reduce the impact. But keep in mind Ruination deals fixed damage.

When Ting-Lu has low HP (and afflicted with Paralyze or Sleep), it’s time to start chucking Poké Balls! Ultra Balls are always great. When it’s night time, Dusk Balls are better. If more than 10 turns have passed, Timer Balls are the best. If Ting-Lu is asleep, Dream Balls are also great, but those are very rare.

A Pokémon that resists Stomping Tantrum would go a long way. This is Ting-Lu’s strongest move and it can hurt a lot if powered up by a previous move failing. Flying types are immune, but be careful as most are weak to Rock Slide. Corviknight, Hawlucha and Flamigo are a few Flying types that take neutral damage from Rock Slide.

Actually, Hawlucha is a really good pick, because it can learn False Swipe. In addition, it can use super-effective Fighting attacks to deal heavy damage to Ting-Lu, before swapping to False Swipe. The only thing it lacks is a way to Paralyze Ting-Lu, but you can let a different Pokémon (eg. Dudunsparce or Sandaconda) handle that.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Find & Catch Chi-Yu

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to encounter and catch Chi-Yu, one of the Legendary Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet.
Chi-Yu is a Ruinous Pokémon and a member of the Legendary quartet known as the “Treasures of Ruin”.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Chi-Yu

chapterContent.content: Chi-Yu is sealed behind the blue shrine in North Province (Area Two), inside a cave at the top of Fury Falls.
To release the seal, you must remove 8 blue stakes dotted around north-east Paldea. For their precise locations, please refer to our Blue Stakes page.
After doing so, there will be a message saying that a sound is coming from the shrine. Inspect the seal on the shrine (you may want to save your game beforehand) to encounter Chi-Yu.

chapterContent.li: All Blue Stake Locations
Blue Shrine Map Marker

chapterContent.head: How to Catch Chi-Yu

chapterContent.content: When the fight begins, Chi-Yu’s Beads of Ruin ability will activate, lowering the Special Defense of all Pokémon except itself.
In terms of stats, Chi-Yu has exceptional Special Attack and Special Defense, and otherwise good to OK stats, excluding its abysmal HP (you can’t have everything!).
Also, it’s worth mentioning that Chi-Yu is a Fire type, not a Water type like you might expect by its fishy appearance!

For attacks, it can use Lava Plume for Fire STAB and decent chance to Burn, Bounce to fly into the air for one turn, Ruination to halve your HP and Swagger to confuse your Pokémon while boosting their Attack by 2 stages (so they hurt themselves more when confused).

Chi-Yu has a very low catch rate, so you should inflict a status ailment to improve your chances. Paralyze is a nice, unfussy choice because it doesn’t disappear–you can apply it with Nuzzle, Thunder Wave, etc. Sleep has better odds, but only lasts a few turns–you can use moves like Hypnosis or Yawn for this.

When damaging Chi-Yu, regular super-effective attacks are fine, so long as they’re not super strong (so not 100+ base power ones). As Chi-Yu’s HP begins to fall, you should swap to False Swipe (obtained from Jacq, your homeroom teacher) to avoid accidentally KOing it.

Chi-Yu cannot heal itself, so once you’ve got it down to low or 1 HP, you can relax a bit. However, Chi-Yu can inflict a lot of damage with its moves, so don’t hesitate to use healing items yourself! If you’re taking big damage, X Sp. Def can help reduce the impact. But keep in mind Ruination deals fixed damage.

When it’s time to start throwing Poké Balls, Ultra Balls are great by default. Because you’re inside a cave, Dusk Balls are a better choice. If more than 10 turns have passed, Timer Balls are the best choice. If Chi-Yu is asleep, Dream Balls are also great, but those are hard to come by.

By the way, you might experience Chi-Yu using Bounce to evade attacks/Poké Balls. This could be a good chance to switch out or use an X Sp. Def. If Bounce is really annoying, you can temporarily disable it with Gravity (learned by Stonjourner).

Pokémon that resist Lava Plume are recommended, since Chi Yu has high Special Attack and your Pokémon’s Special Defense is vulnerable from Beads of Ruin. Fire types are ideal, because they can’t get burned. Rock types are also good, because they resist Bounce, but Bounce doesn’t do that much damage anyway.

Ruination is a nuisance as always and the only real way to combat it is via healing. That said, you could use moves like Double Team to boost your evasion and/or Sand Attack or Mud Slap to lower Chi-Yu’s accuracy. Swagger can be dealt with by using a Full Heal or, y’know, not attacking when Chi-Yu is at low or 1 HP.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: How to Find & Catch Koraidon

chapterContent.content: This page explains how to encounter and catch Koraidon, one of the Legendary Pokémon in Scarlet & Violet.
Koraidon is a Paradox Pokémon that’s loosely related to the common Cyclizar.
Near the beginning of your journey, you will encounter and befriend Koraidon and even ride all across Paldea on it. But you cannot use Koraidon for battling–at least not until the end.

chapterContent.head: How to Battle with Koraidon

chapterContent.content: To enable Koraidon’s battle form, you must complete the Area Zero story, available after completing all three story paths. During the final battle, you will finally get to use Koraidon in its full, frankly overpowered glory.

After the credits roll, you can use Koraidon to fight by going to the Pokémon menu, selecting Koraidon at the very bottom of the list and choosing “Yes”. This will move Koraidon into your Pokémon party. You can only do this if you have space in your party.

chapterContent.aside: While Koraidon is in its battle form, you cannot ride with it. Well, you can ride with Koraidon, but in doing so, Koraidon will automatically leave your party and return to the ride slot.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Another Koraidon

chapterContent.content: Now you might be thinking a few things. Like is there an easier way to use Koraidon, without having to swap between ride and battle forms all the time?
Plus, if you want to complete the Pokédex, you need to trade for someone else’s Miraidon–but how’s that possible if they can’t trade it, like you can’t trade your Koraidon?
Well, if you finished the Area Zero story, don’t forget there was a second Koraidon!

You can find the second Koraidon at the bottom level of Area Zero, at the end of a slope leading to the back of the Zero Lab. Interact with Koraidon to battle it. Of course, save beforehand, just in case!

chapterContent.head: How to Catch the Other Koraidon

chapterContent.content: When the fight begins, Koraidon’s Orichalcum Pulse will trigger, creating harsh sunlight. The sunlight will boost Koraidon’s Attack stat.

Earlier, you fought Koraidon, but you had your own Koraidon and the fight was heavily scripted. So keep in mind that Koraidon has exceptional stats, since it’s a restricted Legendary (so strong it’s banned from typical tournaments until near the end). All of its stats are good to great, with its Attack and Speed excelling. Its Special Attack is so-so though.

Move-wise, it can use Collision Course to deal massive Fighting STAB damage (boosted if super-effective), Flamethrower to take advantage of the harsh sunlight, Giga Impact for big damage but requires charging afterwards and Bulk Up to boost its Attack and Defense stats.
Since it’s a Fighting and Dragon type, Koraidon resists:

chapterContent.li: Fire, Water, Electric, Grass, Bug, Rock and Dark.

chapterContent.content: Conversely, it’s weak to:

chapterContent.li: Ice, Flying, Psychic, Dragon and Fairy.

chapterContent.content: Koraidon, being a Legendary, has a very low catch rate, so you should inflict a status ailment to improve your chances. Paralyze is the lazy, ahem, efficient choice, since it doesn’t disappear–you can apply it with Nuzzle, Thunder Wave, etc. Meanwhile, Sleep has better odds, but only lasts a few turns–you can apply it with Hypnosis, Yawn, Spore, etc.

When dealing damage, try to avoid Fairy attacks, as they deal 4x damage. If you’re Level 70 to 80, regular super-effective attacks are fine, so long as they’re not super strong (so not 100+ base power ones). As Koraidon’s HP begins to fall, you could swap to False Swipe (obtained from Jacq, your homeroom teacher) to avoid accidentally KOing it.

Koraidon has no way to heal itself, so once you’ve reduced it to low or 1 HP, you can relax a bit. However, Koraidon can inflict heavy damage with its moves, so don’t hesitate to use healing items yourself! If you’re taking big damage, stacking X Defense can help reduce the impact. Critical hits will ignore Defense boosts, but hopefully it doesn’t happen often!

When it’s time to start throwing Poké Balls, Ultra Balls are great by default. Because you’ve already got a Koraidon, Repeat Balls are better. If more than 10 turns have passed, Timer Balls are the best choice. If Koraidon is asleep, Dream Balls are also great, but those are hard to come by.

Of course, you can opt to use your own Koraidon. It worked well for the story fight, so it should work well here, right? Only if you bothered to Level Up your ride Koraidon though, because it starts at Level 68 and this one is 72. If it’s Level 72+, you could use it for a bit to rough up its rival. Try relearning Breaking Swipe, which lowers the foe’s Attack, and Drain Punch, which heals yourself.

Some excellent common Pokémon that you can use are Mimikyu and, if you picked the croc at the start, Skeledirge. These are both immune to Collision Course and Giga Impact, while Skeledirge also resists Flamethrower. That said, Flamethrower isn’t too scary, when harsh sunlight ends that is. Actually, most Ghost types should work, so long as they’re not weak to Flamethrower and reasonably bulky.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: All Paradox Pokémon in Pokémon Scarlet

chapterContent.content: This page offers an overview of all Paradox Pokémon found in Area Zero in Pokémon Scarlet. You’ll find information on their types and what they look like!
If you’re looking for a complete list of Paradox Pokémon in Pokémon Violet, head over to our page, All Paradox Pokémon in Pokémon Violet.

chapterContent.head: What are Paradox Pokémon?

chapterContent.content: Paradox Pokémon are exclusive Pokémon found in Pokémon Scarlet & Violet. Each version of the game has unique Paradox Pokémon - Violet has futuristic Paradox Pokémon whilst Scarlet has ancient ones. Each of the Paradox Pokémon is a futuristic/ancient version of a pre-existing Pokémon with different types and moves. If you want Ancient Paradox Pokémon but have the Violet version of the game, you’ll need to trade Pokémon with someone who has Scarlet (and vice versa).
You will only be able to capture Paradox Pokémon once you’ve got access to Area Zero - the crater at the center of the Paldea Region. To do this, you’ll need to first complete all three story paths:

chapterContent.li: Victory Road
Starfall Street
Path of Legends

chapterContent.head: Scarlet Paradox Pokémon

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Scarlet Paradox Pokémon Great Tusk

chapterContent.content: This page offers a guide on how to find and catch the Scarlet Paradox Pokémon Great Tusk in Pokémon Scarlet.

chapterContent.head: What is Great Tusk?

chapterContent.content: Great Tusk is a Scarlet exclusive Paradox Pokémon found in Area Zero. Paradox Pokémon are Pokémon that are exclusive to the Pokémon Scarlet and Violet game. They resemble pre-existing Pokémon but have different move sets and types. Scarlet Paradox Pokémon are Ancient whilst Violet’s are futuristic. You will have also seen Great Tusks when you battled The Quaking Earth Titan during the Path of Legends story.

chapterContent.aside: Great Tusk is an Ancient Pokémon that resembles Donphan. It is a Ground  Fighting  type Pokémon.

chapterContent.content: You will only be able to capture Paradox Pokémon once you’ve got access to Area Zero - the crater at the center of the Paldea Region. You’ll have access to this area once you’ve completed the three story paths:

chapterContent.li: Victory Road
Starfall Street
Path of Legends

chapterContent.content: Once you’ve finished the story quest in Area Zero, you’ll also be able to return at any time by fast travelling to the Zero Gate.

chapterContent.head: How to Find & Catch Great Tusk

chapterContent.content: In order to catch a Great Tusk Paradox Pokémon, you’ll want to head into the cave area in Area Zero. The cave entrance is by Research Station No. 3. Inside the cave, you’ll find loads of Great Tusk hanging around the path. Additionally, you’ll find lots of Scream Tails, Brute Bonnets, and a few Flutter Manes near the ground floor area.

chapterContent.head: How to Find and Catch Roaring Moon

chapterContent.content: Roaring Moon is one of the rarer Scarlet Paradox Pokémon and can be tricky to find! First off, you’ll need to find the cave entrance that’s right outside Research Station No. 3. Rather than going into the cave, head to the left and continue until you find a large tree beneath a rock archway. When you’re at the tree turn to the left to face a rocky cliff.

You should be able to spot a small opening between two rocks in this cliff area. Pass through the opening to find a secret tunnel that takes you into a large open cave! Here, you will find several Roaring Moon Pokémon. You might not spot them at first as they fly quite high up and only come down occasionally! The Roaring Moon Pokémon around here are about level 57 so make sure your Pokémon are appropriately levelled if you’re looking to capture one. Sometimes they can be a bit stubborn so we like to use Ultra Balls to make extra sure we catch them!
