One of the tricks that the Light Elf uses in melee combat is to quickly fly away from you if you remain within melee range for too long. They will often flank you in the process, so you’ll need to turn around quickly to face them and avoid any subsequent attacks. The boss will often follow this evasive manoeuvre with a swift charge attack, which can lead into a relentless melee combo which is difficult to parry if you don’t get the timing right. It’s much easier to block all of these attacks using the Stone Wall shield, so try switching to this if you’re having trouble. To make things worse, the boss will sometimes end this flurry of melee strikes with an unblockable ground smash attack. This will be preceded by a red ring, so you’ll know that you need to dodge instead of attempting to block or parry.

Finally, another ranged attack that you need to look out for consists of the boss throwing their weapons at you before calling them back like a boomerang. They can do this multiple times in a row, so you may need to block or parry this attack more than once. You can see when this attack is about to be executed as the boss will raise their weapons in the air to either side, before spinning and eventually launching them at you. It will also be preceded by a yellow ring indicator, so you’ll know that it’s not just another regular ranged attack incoming.

Other than these main offensive attacks, the boss will also utilize a block stance in the same way that many other Light Elves do. It will be preceded by concentric blue circles, and the only way to stop it is by interrupting it with a shield strike attack by double tapping . You will need to be within melee range for this to work, so don’t bother trying it from a distance. Towards the end of the fight the boss will use another variant of this attack, as they slam their weapons on the ground and begin to heal themselves for a significant amount. You can interrupt this in the same way, but you need to make sure that you’re in melee range, so try not to be too far away when the boss is on low health.

The final boss in this Muspelheim Challenge is an Einherjar Captain. These can be tough enemies to deal with, especially since you don’t really get much practice with them elsewhere in the game. They’re relatively rare elite enemies which have a range of special attacks at their disposal, so you need to learn how to avoid each one to beat them reliably.

The first thing you should know about this boss is that they won’t actually seem to emerge from the realm tear like the others. Instead, they will be upon you instantly, as if by teleportation, a few moments after defeating the Light Elf. The first attack they’ll use is a hammer strike which can be blocked or parried, but you can just as easily dodge it if necessary as well. Just make sure that you don’t dodge too soon, since the Einherjar Captain is capable of adjusting where the strike lands if you move too quickly. This is arguably what makes this boss more difficult than the others - many of its attacks are delayed after the initial animation begins, which can easily throw your timing off if you’re not prepared.

Another reason why this boss is more deadly than the others is that it wields Bifrost damage effectively. The boss will often teleport away from you if it’s hit a few times in melee, then immediately raise its hammer before slamming it down on the ground again. At this point a wall of Bifrost will come hurtling towards you, and you’ll need to dodge either left or right to avoid it. Dodging away from this attack will do no good, since its reach is basically as long as the arena itself.

chapterContent.aside: The Einherjar Captain will often use the Bifrost Wall attack multiple times in a row, so you need to be careful not to become complacent after avoiding it once. Be ready to dodge to the side at least once or twice more whenever this happens. You can see a demonstration of this in the gif below. You will also see how you need to keep on your toes to block some attacks (yellow ring), and dodge others (red ring).

chapterContent.content: The Einherjar Captain will also use teleportation in other ways, such as moving from a ranged position to being right on top of you in melee range again, while striking a with its hammer. The only warning you’ll have of this is the blue / purple light which is emitted around the boss just before and while it’s teleporting. As soon as you see this, it’s time to block, parry, or dodge.

Another extremely damaging Bifrost attack that the Einherjar Captain will use is preceded by concentric blue circles as it raises the hammer in the air. If the attack lands, it will send a shockwave of Bifrost in an area around the boss, and you won’t be able to block or parry this. The only thing you can do to stop this is double tapping  to use your shield attack, but you will need to be in melee range for this to work. For this reason you should always try to remain within melee range of the boss, and whenever a gap opens up between you, try to close it by running towards the boss as quickly as possible.

Although you may feel slightly more vulnerable within melee range of the boss, the opposite is true since you’ll be less likely to succumb to an attack by teleportation. You can dodge most of the attacks from the boss, including those preceded by red rings, if you dodge around the boss rather than away from it. Keep this in mind and try not to panic when you’re within melee range, and you should never be caught off guard by the Bifrost shockwave, since you will have plenty of time to interrupt it with a shield attack.

chapterContent.head: Boss Rush Muspelheim Challenge Rewards

chapterContent.content: Aside from the Surtr’s Scorched Girdle armor piece, you can complete this Muspelheim challenge multiple times to earn the same amount of material rewards listed below.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Phantom Muspelheim Challenge

chapterContent.content: This page details a guide for how to complete the Phantom Muspelheim Challenge in God of War Ragnarok. We’ll cover the strategy for defeating the Flame Phantom boss. We’ll cover what you need to do to stun the boss and how to damage the springs / obelisks to defeat it.

chapterContent.aside: To unlock this Muspelheim Challenge, you need to complete one of the Muspelheim Trials from the R + F sword monuments. You can choose any trial from these, but you must complete one from each before interacting with the sword in the central arena to begin this challenge. See our page on How Muspelheim Trials and Challenges Work in GoWR for more information.

chapterContent.head: How to Defeat the Flame Phantom Muspelheim Challenge in God of War Ragnarok

chapterContent.content: This Phantom challenge is appropriately named, since it consists of you fighting a Flame Phantom. This is similar to other Phantom boss fights that you’ve probably experienced in the game by this point, only this one generally inflicts more damage and it has a few extra attacks. The main principles of this fight are the same, though: hit the boss on its rune head until you completely fill its stun bar, then destroy the Springs / Obelisks on the edges of the arena to take a chunk of health from the boss. You then repeat this process until the boss has no health, at which point you can stun grab it to finish the fight.

In addition to fighting the Flame Phantom, there will be a number of Einherjar and Draugr enemies that spawn throughout the challenge. You’ll need to deal with these as soon as possible so that you can return to focus on avoiding the Flame Phantom attacks, while also inflicting stun damage on its rune head where possible. The Einherjar and Draugr are easy enough to deal with, but some of them are quite tough so you may need to use Runic Attacks to deal with them quickly. You should also remember to double tap  when you see the concentric blue rings around them, since this is the only way to interrupt their special attacks.

The Flame Phantom will cause the ground to erupt with fire / lava when you’re at a distance from it. You will get some warning for this attack since it’s preceded by a red ring indicator, but so you should have plenty of time to dodge it. You won’t be able to block or parry this attack, but if you’re close enough to the boss you may be able to interrupt it with a well timed Runic Attack or Relic / Sword Hilt ability. This is the risker option, so just be ready to dodge it if nothing else.

The Flame Phantom has another special attack preceded by the red ring indicator, but this time within melee range. If you get too close to the boss when it’s not stunned, it will rise slightly before slamming its body down at you. This will cause flames to erupt which can inflict the burning status, so you need to be ready to avoid this with a quick dodge. The attack will often be used multiple times, so you’re not necessarily out of the woods after the initial dodge.

This one can easily catch you off guard if you’re not prepared. The best way to anticipate it normally is to look out for the yellow ring indicator as the boss rises slightly, in preparation for swinging its tail in a 360 motion. This attack has a surprising amount of reach, but you can dodge it reliably if you execute the dodge at the right time. To make things more complicated, the boss will sometimes executed this attack with no ring indicator to warn you, so you really do need to pay attention to its body movements.

This is another attack that can be performed without warning, other than the boss rising slightly before launching a flaming wave at you. This will disperse in an arc in front of the boss, so you need to be ready to dodge just at the moment that it’s about to hit you to avoid it, or you can block it if you have the stone wall shield. It’s also possible to just run away from this attack, since it doesn’t have an infinite range, but this is usually more effort than it’s worth if you can just perform a quick dodge.

Once you’ve done enough damage to completely fill the stun bar of the boss, it will hide underground for a short period of time. At this point you need to attack and destroy the Springs / Obelisks which are placed around the periphery of the arena. You can do this easily with a few Leviathan Axe throws, but if you can reach one in melee you might as well use melee combos to destroy it quickly. It’s possible to destroy two Springs / Obelisks in the same phase, but you’ll most likely only have time to destroy one before the boss pops back up. You will need to hit the boss on its rune head until the stun bar is filled and it hides underground again, then repeat the process of destroying the Springs / Obelisks until the boss has no health left.

The process of destroying the Springs / Obelisks is the only way in which you can inflict actual damage on the boss. Once the Flame Phantom has no health remaining, the next time it pops up you will be able to execute a stun attack to finish it off.

chapterContent.aside: The Flame Phantom only has three chunks of health bars, one of which is depleted whenever you destroy a Spring / Obelisk, so you only need to repeat the process of stunning it and destroying these three times, so long as you’re able to destroy them within the time window you’re given.

chapterContent.content: The Flame Phantom will become a lot more aggressive in the last quarter of this fight, so you need to be ready to avoid most of the attacks mentioned above in quick succession. Be sure to make use of Health Burst stones if you can find any on the battlefield, and use any abilities which can replenish health where necessary, such as the variants of Spartan Rage.

chapterContent.head: Phantom Muspelheim Challenge Rewards

chapterContent.content: You will acquire the materials listed below for each time that you complete this challenge, aside from the Muspelheim’s Essence enchantment, which you can find the details of on our Best Amulet of Yggdrasil Enchantments And Upgrades page.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Beigadr the Feared Berserker Boss in Svartalfheim

chapterContent.content: This page details everything you need to know about where to find and how to beat Beigadr the Feared, one of the Berserker Gravestone soul bosses. This one is found on Alberich Island in Svartalfheim. You’ll need the Hilt of Skofnung to activate the gravestone and summon Beigadr, which you’ll get during “The Word of Fate’’ main quest.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Beigadr the Feared Berserker Gravestone

chapterContent.content: You can find Beigadr’s gravestone on Alberich Island in the Svartalfheim region. Teleport to The Watchtower Mystic Gateway, and traverse the sea far north. When you land on the beach, the Gravestone will be right in front of you.

chapterContent.head: How to Activate the Berserker Gravestones

chapterContent.content: To activate the gravestones, you’ll need the key-item Hilt of Skofnung which you’ll acquire during the story mission “The Word of Fate”. With Hilt in hand, interact with the gravestone to place a circular arena around the gravestone, and one or more of the Berserker’s will spawn. If you die, and you most likely will, you’ll start near the gravestone, so there’s no reason not to try them whenever you see one.

chapterContent.head: How to Defeat Beigadr the Feared – Attacks

chapterContent.content: Below you’ll see a list of all the attacks that Beigadr the Feared has in his arsenal.

Beigadr will quickly disappear, and teleport to your location. As this is a Red-Ring attack, you’ll have to avoid it. This will be shown by a green circle beneath you. Simply sidestep/roll to the side just as it’s about to land. This is a great time to get some damage in.

This is your standard two-hit melee combo. Beigadr will teleport to your location, and perform a two-hit combo while his fists are charged with thunder. This is easily avoided by blocking, parrying or dodging.

A rare melee-range attack which is normally used after his melee combo. Beigadr will shortly charge up a small thunder spark strike in front of himself. It’s not worth parrying this attack, instead simply dodge to the side of it, and attack him while he performs the attack.

Beigadr will jump to the back of the arena and quickfire two thunder orbs at your position. This will always be thrown as two orbs in quick succession, so simply dodge or sidestep to avoid them. These can also be blocked if you don’t want to risk taking damage.

Similar to Thunder Orbs, Beigadr will jump to the back of the arena, and proceed to throw a large Thunder Ball at your location. There will be a Red Ring preceding the Orb which means you’ll have to dodge it. To avoid the attack, dodge roll to either side, but wait until the ball closes in on you. Also, you can dodge away from it providing you have the space. Getting hit by this attack will root you in place, and Beigadr will teleport and attack you. Quickly press  repeatedly to get out of the root.

Another attack from ranged, Beigadr will unleash a wave of thunder across the ground. This attack semi-tracks you, so wait until it gets nearer to you before dodging to the side. Another tip for this attack is the bait, and switch. Start moving one direction, and quickly dodge to the opposite side. Finally, this attack is blockable, so you can just stand and block it, but you may get hit by a follow-up attack.

Beigadr will jump into the air, hand held aloft, and cast a ThunderStorm which will place thunderbolts under your feet. There’ll be approximately seven bolts, and they’ll follow you around. Run/roll around in a circle, so right, right, forward, forward, left, left, down, down. You can just sprint around the arena, but you may get caught out by any follow-up attacks, so keep this in mind.

chapterContent.head: Beigadr the Feared Strategy

chapterContent.aside: Always bring a Resurrection Stone with you, you’ll be surprised how much they’re the difference between winning or losing the battle. We prefer the Berserker’s Resurrection Stone, but any will do.

chapterContent.content: Beigadr prefers to fight from ranged with thunder-based attacks. If you get hit by any of them, the majority will stun you, and leave you open to any potential follow-up attacks. This is Beigadr’s typical strategy. For the most part, he is relatively easy, but one attack that may give you trouble is his ThunderBall attack as the timing is tight, and it has to be dodged.

Ideally, you’ll want to wait until the last second before rolling to the side or if you have room behind you, rolling away from it. His other attacks can be blocked, or are easily telegraphed that you shouldn’t be getting hit by them. If you do get hit by any attacks, you’ll most likely be stunned/rooted, and you’ll have to repeatedly press the  to get out of it. This is where most of his damage will come from, so try not to get hit by it, or counter it with Amulet Enchantments. Talking of Amulet Enchantments, the Svartalfheim set is good for increasing your stun damage, and Celestial Panacea is almost a must-have as it’ll give you 25% resistance to all status effects. This means you won’t get automatically stunned if you get hit by one of his attacks. You can find out where to get this enchantment here.

You’re probably thinking that to deal damage to him, you should rush in as he is a ranged attacker, wrong. This will only get you caught by his attacks leading to a quicker death. Instead, use ranged attacks of your own. The Draupnir Spear is best for this as it’s quicker, and you can detonate them for extra damage which may make them flinch too, but a charged up  attack with the Leviathan Axe can deal good damage too. After he gets fed up with you hurling spears into his face, he’ll close the distance himself, most likely with his Teleport Smash attack, and this is where you can punish him up close. Throw your Runic, and melee attacks at him until he retreats again.

Keep your patience, and you’ll take him down in no time. Remember, as the Berserker’s health gets low, they’ll become less likely to get staggered, and they’ll chain their attacks together, so be prepared to ride out the last 10%.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Equipment For Beigadr the Feared

chapterContent.content: Below you’ll find a list of gear that we recommend for tackling the tricky Beigadr the Feared, this is just what we had great success with, and isn’t necessarily the best. A lot of the equipment choice is determined by the build you’re playing, so feel free to use other armor. The Steinbjorn Set gives you so much defense that it gives you a few more hits before you die.

chapterContent.head: Beigadr the Feared Rewards

chapterContent.content: Defeating Beigadr will reward you with the following items:

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Hjalti The Stolid Berserker Boss in The Forbidden Sands

chapterContent.content: As you explore the numerous areas in the world of God of War Ragnarok, you may have passed some gravestones sitting out in the open. These are called “Berserker” Gravestones, and when you interact with them, you’ll be placed in an arena where you’ll have to fight one (or more) of them. There are 13 Berserkers’ in total, but only 10 gravestones to beat them in. Defeating all Berserker’s is required for 100% completion as well as to unlock, and finish the Favor “Fit for a King”. This page will guide you through finding, and defeating the Berserker “Hjalti The Stolid”.

chapterContent.head: How to Activate the Berserker Gravestones

chapterContent.content: To activate the gravestones, you’ll need the key-item Hilt of Skofnung which you’ll acquire during the story mission “The Word of Fate”. With Hilt in hand, interact with the gravestone to place a circular arena around the gravestone, and one or more of the Berserker’s will spawn. If you die, and you most likely will, you will start near the gravestone, so there’s no reason not to try them whenever you see one.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Berserker Hjalti The Stolid

chapterContent.content: You can find Hjalti’s gravestone in the southwest of The Forbidden Sands in Alfheim. Teleport to The Hjarta Mystic Gate, jump on the sled, and follow the tunnel southwest into The Forbidden Sands. As soon as you exit the tunnel, follow the wall southwest, and you’ll find the gravestone. Place your Hilt of Skofnung on the gravestone to start the battle.

chapterContent.head: Hjalti The Stolid Attacks

chapterContent.content: Like all Berserker’s, Hjalti is extremely aggressive, and she has an arsenal of attacks to throw at you. She’ll have her normal melee attacks alongside her more unforgiving attacks listed below.

This is just a simple strike with one of her maces which can be easily dodged or parried. Sometimes she’ll use this, just before a Quadstrike which turns it into a five-hit combos instead of just the four. She can also use this in-between other attacks. This attack can be done with either hand, and will go the opposite direction to the other depending on which hand she uses.

Hjalti will raise both of her maces and she’ll start charging an attack. This will be indicated with the Blue Rings. You’ll only have a few seconds to shield bash it before you take a large amount of damage, and get knocked down. Ideally, you’ll be relatively close to her when this happens, so you can simply stun her out of it, but if you’re further away, you will most likely get hit by it. This is why we recommend taking along the Onslaught Shield as it has the ability to perform the Shield Rush Skill. This will make you charge at the enemy which is great for closing the distance.

Hjalti will jump in the air, and unleash her dual maces at you. This is a ranged attack, and can be quite difficult to avoid. If you are far away from her, dodge just as the maces are about to hit you by rolling backwards, and to the side, if you time it right, you’ll avoid taking damage. If you’re close to her, your reflexes need to be quick, and you can avoid it by rolling to the side. Later on in the battle, she’ll perform two of these in a row, and sometimes follow it up with a Lunging Backhand.

You’ll see this attack a lot. Hjalti will jump in the air, a yellow ring will appear, and she’ll lunge into you while also performing a backhanded attack with her mace. If you have the Stone Wall Shield, you can just block this otherwise you’ll need to either parry or dodge. Parrying is the best way to deal with this attack as you’ll build up some stun damage while also stunning her momentarily which leaves her open for a combo or two. If you’d rather dodge the attack, simply sidestep as the attack is about to land. This also gives you a moment to deal damage, but not as much as parrying her. When Hjalti has less than half of her health, she can sometimes combo this attack into other attacks, even if you parry it.

This is one of her easiest attacks to avoid. Hjalti will leap in the air, and slam both of her maces onto the ground at your location which will be indicated by a red ring. Wait for her to get near you, then perform a sidestep away from the attack, then punish her with a combo or Runic attack.

This can be tricky to avoid. When Hjalti is in front of you, she’ll perform a yellow-ring swipe at you. She stops briefly before she follows up with another yellow-ring swipe. Straight after the second swipe, she’ll perform two normal attacks before finishing the combo off with a double-handed red-ring swipe. In all honesty this combo is best avoided by performing multiple rolls away from her. If you’re good at parrying, you can parry the first four attacks, then sidestep the last. This will result in more stun damage, but it is high risk, high reward. This speeds up when she is nearly dead.

chapterContent.head: Hjalti The Stolid Strategy

chapterContent.content: At the beginning of the fight, she’ll almost always use her blue-ring attack unless you rush her from the get-go. She’ll spend most of the time performing hit-and-run tactics by jumping in, performing one or more of the attacks above, and jumping back out. Trying to hit her when she’s prancing around is almost pointless, although you can hit her by throwing your axe or spear. Instead, wait for one of her attacks, and punish her by parrying or sidestepping away from it. When you do that, you can normally get four or five attacks on her, although you may have to dodge an attack in-between that.

Build up her stun bar by parrying, attacking, and Sonic Arrows from Freya or Atreus, and when the bar fills up, she’ll take a huge chunk of damage. Atreus’ Wrath of the Wolf Runic Summon is great for this fight as they’ll cause her to flinch for the duration that they’re out which leaves ample time for you to lay down some of your own attacks. As mentioned above, the best time to attack Hjalti is after her blue-ring attack, the yellow-ring Lunging Backhand attack, and the red-ring Double Hand Slam attack. After each of these attacks, you can get a few hits on her, and when combined with the sonic arrows, build up the stun bar a fair bit.

The hardest part of this fight is being overconfident. At first, it won’t feel particularly difficult, but as the fight goes on, and you miss one attack, she can combo it with another, and the next thing you know, you’re dead. The hardest attack to deal with has to be either her boomerang or her Quadstrike. The boomerang has weird timing, and although rolling backwards, and to the side appears to make it miss more often, you may still get hit by it. When that happens, she’ll follow it up with a lunge, or if later on in the battle, another boomerang, and then a lunge. With the Quadstrike, it can be hard to judge the parry timings as she’ll perform the first yellow-ring attack, then briefly stop, before doing the second yellow-ring attack. After that the next two normal attacks come quickly, and then she’ll slow down the red-ring attack at the end. This is why we recommend you to dodge the combo instead of parrying it unless you’re competent at parrying.

Finally, save your Rage (Fury) for the last 20-30% of the battle as the berserker goes, well…berserk. She’ll add an extra boomerang to her arsenal, and chain together her other attacks more with more pace, and she’ll end up in your face more often. This is the time to take it slow, and only attack when you have an opening. Do fewer attacks on her after you make her flinch, and wait for the next attack before committing. This is a good time to remember your companion exists, and use their attacks to take her down. When her health is depleted, run over to her and press  to finish the fight. Pick up your rewards, and take the Hilt of Skofnung from the area the grave was to remove the icy barrier.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Equipment For Hjalti The Strolid

chapterContent.content: Below you’ll find a list of gear that we recommend for tackling the tricky Hjalti The Stolid, this is just what we had great success with, and isn’t necessarily the best.

chapterContent.head: Hjalti The Strolid Rewards

chapterContent.content: Defeating Hjalti will reward you with the following items:

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Fraekni the Zealous Berserker Boss in Midgard

chapterContent.content: This page details everything you need to know about where to find and how to beat Fraekni the Zealous, one of the Berserker Gravestone soul bosses. This one is found on the Lake of Nine in Midgard. You’ll need the Hilt of Skofnung to activate the gravestone and summon Fraekni, which you’ll get during The Word of Fate main quest.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Fraekni the Zealous Berserker Gravestone

chapterContent.content: As you probably know by now, before you can activate the gravestone to summon Fraekni the Zealous you’ll need to acquire the Hilt of Skofnung first, during The Word of Fate main quest. Once you have this, you’ll find Fraekni on the Lake of Nine, at the location shown in the screenshot below, west of The Oarsman. The boss fight will begin as soon as you interact with the gravestone, so be ready for the fight. This is likely to be the first Berserker Gravestone fight that you encounter, and it’s probably the easiest.

chapterContent.head: How to Defeat Fraekni the Zealous - Attacks

chapterContent.content: One of the most common attacks that you’ll see Fraekni perform is an unblockable charge attack. This is always indicated by a red circle, so you’ll have a brief moment to prepare a dodge. The key here is to dodge at the last possible moment, rather than as soon as you see the red ring. If you dodge too soon the attack will likely hit you. As with almost any other unblockable attack, you can also stop them by executing a Light or Heavy Runic Attack, or by using the ability from your Relic or Sword Hilt, but you’ll need to make sure that you time this properly and it will be more difficult from a distance. It’s probably best to reserve this method for when you’re sure that Fraekni is close enough to be affected by the ability.

There’s another version of this charge attack which is marked by a yellow circular ring, indicating that it can be blocked or parried. All you need to do to negate this one is hold your shield up if you have one that can outright block yellow ring attacks (such as the Stone Wall shield), or be ready to time a parry just before the attack hits. Fraekni will often follow this attack up with a few more melee strikes, so don’t let your guard down until you’re familiar with exactly how many strikes she tends to use. You can then use your shield ability by double tapping  to inflict stun damage, or retaliate with some melee strikes / abilities of your own.

chapterContent.aside: You may notice that you can’t execute a stun grab attack on Fraekni during this fight. Instead, once the stun bar is completely filled you’ll inflict massive damage to the boss instead. This still makes inflicting stun damage worthwhile, so you should prioritize any stun damage attacks that you have when they’re available.

chapterContent.content: The other attack that Fraekni will use frequently is an overhead strike with her axe. This can also come in an unblockable form, or in a form that can be blocked / parried. If you see the red circular ring, be ready to dodge out of the way. You’ll find that it’s far easier to avoid these attacks by dodging around Fraekni, rather than away from her. This may seem counterintuitive since you’ll remain closer to Fraekni than you would if you were to dodge away, but it ensures that her melee attacks won’t reach you. If you see the yellow ring, you can block or parry this attack instead, and you can do the same for any attack that isn’t marked by a red circle ring.

These are actually the only two main attacks that Fraekni has at her disposal, so it’s incredibly easy to learn the attack patterns and how to avoid them. At the end of the fight, you’ll need to execute a stun grab attack to finish her off.
You can see all of Fraekni’s attacks and how to avoid them in quick succession in the gif below.

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Hardrefill the Callous Berserker Boss in Svartalfheim

chapterContent.content: This page details everything you need to know about how to defeat the Berserker Gravestone boss Hardrefill the Callous, who can be found just outside The Forge in Svartalfheim.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Hardrefill the Callous Berserker Gravestone

chapterContent.content: The first thing you should know before you go looking for Hardrefill the Callous is that you won’t be able to fight him until you’ve acquired the Hilt of Skofnung item, during The Word of Fate main quest. You’ll also naturally encounter this boss during the Forging Destiny main quest, as you exit the dwarf train with Freya, so you might as well complete that to find yourself in the right area before you go searching. The exact location of the boss is shown in the screenshots below.

chapterContent.head: How to Defeat Hardrefill the Callous - Attacks

chapterContent.content: The first attack that you’re likely to face from Hardrefill is a charge attack, similar to the one performed by Fraekni the Zealous but with a slightly different animation. Hardrefill will still fly into the air before descending upon you, so you’ll need to block or parry at the right time to avoid being hit, or be ready to dodge if you see a red circular ring instead, indicating that it’s an unblockable attack. Keep in mind that you can still interrupt these unblockable attacks by performing a Light or Heavy Runic Attack of your own, or by using a Relic or Sword Hilt ability.

This is perhaps the most powerful attack that Hardrefill uses, and it can be easy to get hit by it if you try to dodge it too soon. Instead, all you need to do is keep running around the arena until the attack is over. So long as you’re sprinting in an open space without being blocked by anything (such as Freya or the walls of the arena) the attack will never hit you. It is possible to avoid it by dodging at the last moment, but this is much more risky than simply running away from it. You’ll notice a green substance beneath your feet while Hardrefill is in the area, which indicates the area that he’s going to land up until the final moment. Just keep running until the green substance is gone, and Hardrefill lands.

This is a fairly basic melee attack that Hardrefill will perform whenever you’re close to him in melee combat. It usually consists of one or more slashes with his sword, marked by a yellow circular ring. This means that you can block or parry this attack reliably, so you don’t need to bother with trying to dodge it. However, you can just as easily dodge it if you’d rather do this. Aside from the yellow ring, Hardrefill will raise his sword above his head, which provides another clear indication that the attack is incoming.

chapterContent.aside: As with most other berserker bosses, you won’t be able to stun grab them. Instead, once you fill their stun damage bar, they will receive a massive amount of damage. This means that it’s still worthwhile to prioritize attacks that inflict a lot of stun damage wherever possible.

chapterContent.content: The above are the three main attacks that Hardrefill the Callous will spam throughout the fight, so once you’re familiar with how to avoid them, the rest of the fight should be a breeze. You can see the indicators for each attack in the screenshots below, and we’ve also included a gif to demonstrate the attacks in motion so that you can get a better idea of how to avoid them. In the gif we actually dodge too soon, but we recover by dodging just at the last minute to avoid the unblockable dive stomp attack. This was before we realized that simply running away while he’s in the air is guaranteed to make the attack miss, so be sure to do this instead!

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Haklangr the Bearded Berserker Boss in The Sinkholes

chapterContent.content: As you explore the numerous areas in the world of God of War Ragnarok, you may have passed some gravestones sitting out in the open. These are called “Berserker” Gravestones, and when you interact with them, you’ll be placed in an arena where you’ll have to fight one (or more) of them. There are 13 Berserkers’ in total, but only 10 gravestones to beat them in. Defeating all Berserker’s is required for 100% completion as well as to unlock, and finish the Favor “Fit for a King”. This page will guide you through finding, and defeating the Berserker “Haklangr the Bearded”.

chapterContent.head: How to Activate the Berserker Gravestones

chapterContent.content: To activate the gravestones, you’ll need the key-item Hilt of Skofnung which you’ll acquire during the story mission “The Word of Fate”. With Hilt in hand, interact with the gravestone to place a circular arena around the gravestone, and one or more of the Berserker’s will spawn. If you die, and you most likely will, you will start near the gravestone, so there’s no reason not to try them whenever you see one.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Berserker Haklangr the Bearded

chapterContent.content: You can find Haklangr’s gravestone in The Sinkholes, east side of The Crater in Vanaheim. You won’t be able to access this area until you’ve completed the story mission “Creatures of Prophecy”. Once you gain access to the area, you’ll need to head to The Jungle to complete the Favor “Return of the River”. This will make the river flow again in the entire Crater region allowing you to take your boat to where the gravestone is. Park your boat up at the dock opposite of the gravestone, and jump over the gap to reach the central area where you destroyed the pillars with the dragon.

chapterContent.head: Haklangr the Bearded Attacks

chapterContent.content: Like all Berserker’s, Haklangr the Bearded is extremely aggressive, and has an arsenal of attacks to throw at you. He’ll have his normal melee attacks alongside his more unforgiving attacks listed below.

A large poison circle will appear around Haklangr, and then he’ll slam his Warhammer into the ground to make it explode. If you’re in the circle, you can double-roll backwards a couple of times to avoid it. You’ll have to be quick as he triggers it fairly quickly. You can interrupt this attack by using a heavy Runic or Relic attack.

Throughout the battle Haklangr has the ability to put a shield on himself which will negate any damage you do to him while the shield is up. This can either be a Frost or Fire shield. If it’s frost, switch over to your Blade of Chaos and use your Runic Attacks to deplete his shield. If it’s fire, switch to the Leviathan Axe and do the same. The best Runic attack for the Leviathan Axe is Breath of Thamur while the Blades of Chaos doesn’t really have one, but Tame the Beast does the trick. One thing to note about the shield is that he can’t be staggered while it’s up which means he will attack you through your attacks.
Haklangr will jump towards you while slamming down with his Warhammer at your location. This is easier enough to avoid by dodging to the side.

A simple thrust with the hammer which is preceded with a yellow-ring. Dodging to the side is the safer way to deal with the attack, but you can parry it if you’re good at it. Time the parry just as the weapon is about to hit you.

Similar to the Jumping Slam attack, but he won’t jump beforehand. Haklangr will slam down his hammer at your location, and can do this attack multiple times in quick succession. This attack is preceded with a red-ring, so dodge to the side to avoid it.

Haklangr will jump in the air with his hammer behind his head, and he’ll leap in and swing at you. This attack is indicated with a yellow-ring, and somewhat tracks you. The best way to deal with this attack is to parry it or double roll to the side. Both of them can be tricky to pull off, but rolling is the safer method if you’re not great at parrying. If you go the parry route, wait until the last second before attempting to parry, but if you fail the parry, Haklangr will use his Hammer Thrust straight after as well as some other attacks.

chapterContent.head: Spin to Win

chapterContent.content: With Warhammer in hand, Haklangr will start off with a yellow-ring attack and swing it as he spins. This is then followed-up four more times with normal melee swings before he finishes it in a downwards red-ring attack. The safest way to deal with this attack is to keep rolling away, and wait for it to finish. You could parry the first attack, block the following normal attacks, and finally avoid the final attack, but there’s not much reward, and a lot of risk.

chapterContent.head: Haklangr the Bearded Strategy

chapterContent.content: This fight is a melee brawl. Haklangr won’t worry about any fancy ranged attacks and will take his chances defeating you up close. He doesn’t have too many attacks, but he will chain the few he has into various combos. The combo you’ll see most often is his Leaping Hammer > Hammer Thrust > Hammer Pound, although that isn’t set in stone. Throughout the fight, he’ll use a shield of frost or fire, and you’ll need to deplete it with the opposite element. The Spear can deal damage to both of them, but it’ll do less damage than the opposite element. So switch over to the Blades of Chaos for the frost shield, and the Leviathan Axe for the fire shield and use your Runic attacks to take the shield down as soon as possible.

At first, you’ll most likely take a lot of damage from his poison slam attack. This can be tricky to avoid because he’ll place the large green circle around you while you’re up close, and quickly slam down his hammer to cause it to explode. As soon as you see the green circle, perform two double rolls away from him to get out of the attack. If done correctly, you should have enough time to avoid it otherwise you’ll need to use a Heavy Runic attack to interrupt it. Most of his attacks are easy to avoid, providing that you’re not too aggressive as you’ll normally get caught out by a random Hammer Thrust attack. Instead, be aggressive, but more purposeful, so he can’t catch you out with a cheap attack.

Now that we’ve covered how to avoid taking damage, let’s talk about dealing your own damage back to him. You can punish almost all of his attacks with a combo of your own. Poison Slam attack? Roll out of it, and run back in after it’s exploded. Hammer Pound? Wait a second to see if he does more than one, if it’s just the one, run in and get a few hits. Leaping Hammer attack? Dodge it to avoid the follow-up attacks, and get a quick combo in. Spin to Win? Run away as far as possible, you don’t want to attack him during this.

This fight may take a few tries to understand how the battle plays out, but once you recognize the patterns, you’ll take him down in no time. He isn’t a particularly tough battle, but he can be frustrating to fight as he’ll normally hit you out of nowhere. When you get him down to the last quarter of his health, he’ll become berserk, and use his attacks even more aggressively, and your attacks will be less likely to stagger him. Once you’ve depleted his health, head over to him, and press  to take his head, and end the battle.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Equipment For Haklangr the Bearded

chapterContent.content: Below you’ll find a list of gear that we recommend for tackling the tricky Hjalti The Stolid, this is just what we had great success with, and isn’t necessarily the best.

chapterContent.head: Haklangr the Bearded Rewards

chapterContent.content: Defeating Haklangr will reward you with the following items:

articleData.chapterTitle_bc: Skjorthendi The Unerring Berserker Boss in Niflheim

chapterContent.content: As you explore the numerous areas in the world of God of War Ragnarok, you may have passed some gravestones sitting out in the open. These are called “Berserker” Gravestones, and when you interact with them, you’ll be placed in an arena where you’ll have to fight one (or more) of them. There are 13 Berserkers’ in total, but only 10 gravestones to beat them in. Defeating all Berserker’s is required for 100% completion as well as to unlock, and finish the Favor “Fit for a King”. This page will guide you through finding, and defeating the Berserker “Skjorthendi The Unerring”.

chapterContent.head: How to Activate the Berserker Gravestones

chapterContent.content: To activate the gravestones, you’ll need the key-item Hilt of Skofnung which you’ll acquire during the story mission “The Word of Fate”. With Hilt in hand, interact with the gravestone to place a circular arena around the gravestone, and one or more of the Berserker’s will spawn. If you die, and you most likely will, you will start near the gravestone, so there’s no reason not to try them whenever you see one.

chapterContent.head: Where to Find Berserker Skjorthendi The Unerring

chapterContent.content: You won’t be able to access Skjorthendi’s gravestone until you finish the main story. This is because it’s in the Mist Fields in Niflheim which you can’t get to until the post-game. Once you’ve finished the game, head back to Sindri’s House, and Ratatoskr will give you some Yggdrasil Seeds to open more realms. Hover over Niflheim, and you’ll be able to unlock the Mist Fields area. Now teleport to the gateway there, and follow the snowy path all the way west where you’ll find her gravestone.

chapterContent.head: Skjorthendi The Unerring Attacks

chapterContent.content: Like all Berserker’s, Skjorthendi is extremely aggressive, and she has an arsenal of attacks to throw at you. She’ll have her normal melee attacks alongside her more unforgiving attacks listed below.

This is the toughest attack to deal with for Skjorthendi. At the beginning, and throughout the fight she’ll gain a Bifrost Aura which will continuously cover your health bar with Bifrost. If she attacks you while your health is blue, you’ll take that as damage. It is a devastating attack that can end your life pretty quickly. Unfortunately, there isn’t much you can do to negate this attack, but equipping the enchantments Celestial Panacea, and Remedy of the Bifrost can help. Other than that, keep your distance while your health is affected by Bifrost, and make sure you don’t get hit until it dissipates.

From range, Skjorthendi will unleash a wave of Bifrost energy at your location. The best way to deal with this attack is to start walking in one direction, and quickly rolling to the opposite side. You can block this attack, but you will take a small amount of Bifrost damage, so avoiding it is the best call.

Sometimes Skjorthendi will close the distance, and do a quick blast of Bifrost energy at you. There will be a short charge, so you should see it coming. As soon as you see the attack, roll away from her until she uses it, then close the distance yourself, and punish her with a few attacks of your own.

Skjorthendi will rise into the air with her arms spread out charging a room-wide blast of Bifrost. On harder difficulties, this attack can cover your entire health bar in Bifrost, but thankfully a well-placed spear or axe can interrupt her, and make her drop to the floor.

Skjorthendi will leap to the back of the arena, jump into the air, and hurl several missiles at you. This attack is preceded by a red-ring which means you’ll have to avoid it. The easiest way to avoid the attack is to wait until the missiles get close to you, then roll to the side. This may take you a few tries to get the timing down.

This is a simple lunge attack which is preceded by a yellow-ring. Skjorthendi will lunge across the arena, and throw a forward punch at you. As this is a yellow-ring, it can be parried, but dodging it is the easier option. If you want to parry the attack, wait until she throws the punch before parrying, but be quick as the timing window is short. If you choose the easier method of avoiding the attack, just dodge to the side.

Skjorthendi will jump to the back of the arena before she leaps side to side while throwing a Bifrost projectile each time. These are easily dodge by sidestepping or rolling to the side. She will always throw two at a time. If you mess up the dodge or are too late to react, you can block these.

A simple two-hit attack with her Bifrost covered fists. They’re downward strikes which can make them harder to avoid, but you can either block or dodge them with relative ease. They’re classed as a normal attack, so you don’t have to worry about parrying or anything else.

All the Berserker’s have this attack and Skjorthendi is no different. She’ll teleport/jump into the air, and come crashing down at your location. A simple sidestep or roll will negate this attack. It can be used multiple times in quick succession, so always be ready for another one straight after.

chapterContent.head: Skjorthendi The Unerring Strategy

chapterContent.content: At the beginning of the fight, she will put Bifrost Aura on herself. You have two ways to deal with this, keep your distance, or be aggressive. If you stay far enough away from her, you won’t take much Bifrost damage, but she can, and will close the distance to you with it on. The aggressive method is to keep attacking her, and when your health takes a significant amount of Bifrost damage, jump into rage to remove it. After a short duration, the aura will wear off, and you’ll be free to attack her normally.

The next attack that she does which can end the fight quickly is her “Ranged Bifrost Blast”. She’ll jump into the air at the back of the arena, and charge up the blast. Quickly throw either your spear or axe at her to interrupt the charge, and drop her to the floor. If you get hit by this attack, your entire health bar could be Bifrosted, especially on higher difficulties.

Other than the above attacks, a lot of her attacks are relatively easy to avoid, although her magic missile attack may take you a few tries to get the timing down. The Bifrost wave can be avoided by heading one direction (to make it head that direction) and rolling to the opposite side as it closes in on you. Her Lunging Punch can sometimes be tricky to avoid, as it comes at you with pace, but it is preceded with a yellow-ring, so you can get ready to dodge or parry it. All of her other attacks you should be used to by now as they’re not too different from the other Berserkers.

When Skjorthendi gets too low health (around 20-30%) she’ll cast Bifrost Aura again. This can end the fight quickly for you because she is a lot more aggressive at this stage of the fight, and you most likely don’t have any Rage left to negate it. You may want to sit back and attack more purposefully, or if you have Rage, jump into that, and finish her off. With Skjorthendi defeated, you’ll only have the King left to take care off at the King’s Grave in Midgard which you can read about here.

chapterContent.head: Recommended Equipment For Skjothendi the Unerring

chapterContent.content: Below you’ll find a list of gear that we recommend for tackling the Bifrost Queen Skjothendi the Unerring, this is just what we had great success with, and isn’t necessarily the best.
